PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens showeth that we are totally opposed to the decision of the State and Federal Attorneys-General to recommend the Banning of the `X' classification for videos containing explicit sexual activity between consenting adults, without the introduction of a new classification for the abovementioned material.

We further believe that the recommendation for the removal of the `X' classification without the introduction of a new classification for sexually explicit adult video tapes is undemocratic, authoritarian, morally and socially irresponsible and overwhelmingly opposed by a majority of the Australian public.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate not discontinue the `X' classification without introducing a new classification to cover depictions of sexually explicit actions between consenting adults.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the Senate to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Senate, Parliament of Australia.

We, the undersigned petitioners, humbly request that the Ordinance for the ACT Casino to be tabled by the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, be referred to an appropriate Senate Committee and that it not be allowed to become law until the residents of the ACT have been able to express their opinion through either a locally elected self-governing body or an ACT-wide referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material

We the undersigned,

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in that capacity and in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister would be aware that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has begun ratifying agreements leading to pay rises in line with its national wage case decision. Is it a fact that these rises are being granted on the basis of a promise from unions to do no more than enter into discussions with employers about the restructuring of awards, and without the necessity of guaranteeing that any changes will actually occur? Is the Government concerned that there will be a rapid flow-on of the 3 per cent rise without achieving any productivity improvement? Does the Government believe that its wages target of a 5.5 per cent rise on a survey basis, or a 6.5 per cent rise on a national accounts basis, will be exceeded? What attitude has the Government taken to pay rises sought by its own employees as a result of the last wage case decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that discussions have commenced under the auspices of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to the wage increase to take place not before 1 September 1988. In the course of discussions before the Commission the question of award restructuring is a matter of substance to be discussed. As I recall the Commission's decision-I do not wish to be held to this-whether it is the Commission's decision or a commitment made by the trade union movement it is understood that the second part of the national wage rise, which it is predicated will take place in March or thereafter next year, is dependent on progress with those discussions about award restructuring. That element of the wage rise is, as I say, intimately bound up with progress on award restructuring issues.

ANSWER.PARA: There is within the trade union movement, as I understand it from discussions with trade union representatives in a number of industries, a very strong commitment to the award restructuring process. It seems to me to be one of the most important things that has ever happened in this country, particularly in an area like the area covered by the metal trades award where there is discussion about reducing the number of award classifications from about 300 to fewer than 10. The issue of multiskilling and so on, or some other name for multiskilling, is very much active and being discussed by the parties. These things are enormously important breakthroughs.

I was asked about the Government's discussion about implementing the pay increase awarded by the Arbitration Commission in respect of Commonwealth employees. I understand that those discussions have not yet commenced, but they will probably commence next week. The Budget estimate of the wage increase, or movement of wages, for the current financial year is 6.5 per cent, as I recall it. I, of course, am unable to comment or speculate about that Budget estimate, except to say that this Government's estimates have normally been pretty right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply, but I ask him to consider the question further in consultation with his colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and perhaps give the Senate a further answer. I am not sure that a couple of points the Minister mentioned are exactly accurate. I ask him to check them and let us have the benefit of a more detailed reply after consultation with Mr Willis.

—I will certainly do that. I indicated, in answering the main question, that on most of those issues I felt fairly confident about what I had said, but one or two things could be clarified further. I will do that as soon as possible and give the Senate an answer.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of several recent newspaper reports about the continued security of water resources, including supplies to rural communities, irrigation supplies and water quality? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the direction the Government is taking on this issue to ensure that future generations are assured of adequate, usable water supplies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government identifies, under four broad headings, the requirements of the Australian community in terms of water resources. The first one is to secure for country or rural and provincial centres a secure water supply. That has not always been the case in the past, particularly for small towns. Our program to do that is the country water supply improvement program, which goes under the glorious acronym of COWSIP. The second part is to assist State governments, in particular, with major public works. A good example of what we are doing there is that we have joined the Western Australian Government in financing the construction of the Harris River Dam near Collie in Western Australia. Under the third heading I mention the fact that we, in association with State and local government, run a flood mitigation program. The recent Budget provided extensive funding for flood mitigation works in New South Wales, particularly in the western suburbs areas of Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: The fourth area concerns specific catchment-type programs to lower the level of salinity and/or get rid of waterlogging in river systems or in basins that are the feature of river systems. The Murray-Darling Basin initiative is the most outstanding example of that. In the last Budget we allocated $62.7m for these programs, an increase of 14 per cent on what applied previously-or $10m for those interested in the actual money. The strategy we apply is to look at the whole of the catchment and develop a strategy for that catchment or the particular project rather than simply to have a project based arrangement. The projects that we have funded out of this Budget allocation are, as I have mentioned, the Harris River Dam in Western Australia, the Brisbane Norman Creek flood mitigation project, the Launceston flood mitigation pump station in Tasmania and the Cooktown water supply project; and COWSIP money was allocated to ensure that rural communities have access to water at acceptable standards on the basis that we worked out with the States. As well, half a million dollars has been allocated to the Townsville-Thuringowa water supply project.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the double page $20,000-plus advertisement placed in today's Melbourne Age by the Council for the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS), which again raises the divisive issue of government funding for denominational schools. Does the Minister accept that the Government is directly responsible for reopening this divisive debate by proposing the fourth referendum question? I remind the Minister that on 1 June this year he said that he could not `nor can anyone give an absolute, untempered guarantee' that state aid will be upheld by the High Court of Australia should question four be carried. Should question four be carried, what guarantee can the Minister give that organisations such as DOGS would not seek to reopen through the courts the whole question of state aid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Bishop recalls the history of dealings by governments at both Federal and State level on the funding of church based schools, hospitals and other community organisations she will know that it is the Australian Labor Party which has an extremely proud and enviable record in creating a political situation in Australia in which the divisive state aid debate was brought to an end under the leadership of Prime Minister Whitlam and under the very good work of the then Minister for Education, Mr Kim Beazley, Sr. It was the Labor Party at the Federal level which closed the debate and created a situation such that over the last three or four years, as I have gone around particularly Tasmania opening extensions and new buildings for non-government schools throughout that State, I have seen that parents, church communities and students have been grateful that this Hawke Government, in line with the precedent set by Gough Whitlam, has created more real, practical opportunities for freedom of choice by parents in relation to the school in which they wish their children to be educated than ever was the case under the Liberals. I am not trying to score a political partisan point. I believe that in Australia we have reached a very good situation in which the funding of church based schools in various measures by both Federal and State governments is part of the political scene.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the DOGS case, people can attack the present DOGS ruling at any time of they so wish. My point is that the decision by the High Court in the DOGS case, when one reads it, is so clear in its tenor that those who wish to throw away money on a legal challenge to that decision are free to waste their money if they so wish. It is quite clear that the decision by the High Court in that case provides a very sound foundation for the prediction that such a challenge would be totally unsuccessful.

We have had over the last several weeks an attempt by the Opposition, in relation to this very important question of a further guarantee within our political framework, on what is the quintessence of conscience-that is, freedom of religion-to stir up fear and misgiving in the community, to the extent that Mr Reith, as I quoted yesterday, at a town hall meeting somewhere in South Australia, preferred to leave people in ignorance rather than seek an answer to a question that was put to him along the lines of whether Christmas or Easter would be abolished if this referendum were passed. The Opposition prefers that people be left in a state of ignorance rather than a state of enlightenment on this and many other questions. That is the only way in which it can hope to secure support for its scaremongering campaign.

I believe that the Labor Government has a very enviable record, as I say, in relation to the funding of non-government schools. It would not put that funding in jeopardy. Obviously, it would be political suicide to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why do it? Why take the chance?
—The fact is that I do not believe that there is a chance, when one looks at the very high legal authority, including the Constitutional Commission, chaired by Sir Maurice Byers--
—What about Sir Maurice Byers?

—The honourable senator can spurt out the word `Byers'. I regard Maurice Byers, QC, as a very able lawyer who, as Solicitor-General for the Commonwealth, led the arguments in the DOGS case which secured funding for non-government schools from Commonwealth coffers. If anyone would have an understanding of the law relating to this matter, it would certainly be Sir Maurice Byers. Other eminent lawyers on the Commission, people such as Leslie Zines, Professor of Law at the Australian National University, and Enid Campbell, another Professor of Law, are all held in extremely high esteem. If one adds to that list Sir Rupert Hamer, a former Premier of Victoria and certainly not a partisan supporter of the Australian Labor Party, one sees the group of people whose opinion in this matter I certainly hold in much higher regard than those thoughts emanating from the Opposition benches.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The educational `dogs of war' were certainly unleashed this morning in the Age. I ask the Minister what guarantees he can give that will prevent the DOGS Council taking action, should this proposed referendum question be passed.

—It is not the function of a Federal Minister to prevent anyone approaching the courts if they so wish. I certainly do not intend to stand in the way of anybody who wishes to do so. As I have said in the Senate in the course of the debate on the referendums-one comment I made has been taken completely out of the context of the paragraph in which it was situated-the DOGS case provides a very sound foundation for the prediction that the funding of schools and hospitals of other community groups does not establish any religion within the terms of our Constitution. It does not create a situation in which a particular religious group, denomination or sect is given the privileges and status of a national church, which is what `establishment' is all about. In that situation there is no way in which the mere funding of an educational enterprise, even though it be conducted by a church based organisation, amounts to the establishing of a religion.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to comments on the Government's fiscal policy made by Mr Andrew Peacock and reported in yesterday's Australian Financial Review? Will the Government be modifying its fiscal policies in response to Mr Peacock's criticisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the second part of the question is an unequivocal no, and there are a number of reasons for that. But one of the major reasons comes out of Mr Peacock's own mouth, because he is quoted in the same report as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not an accountant and I do not approach the problem of cutting of government spending as an accounting exercise.

In other words, who needs an accountant when a bottle of snake oil will do? Snake oil, of course, is what has powered the Liberal Party's budget and other economic policies for almost as long as anybody can remember. In the same article Mr Peacock asserted that a person on average weekly earnings was paying $56 a week more in tax than he or she was paying in 1983. In making that assertion he demonstrated an inability to distinguish between the notional nominal tax that would be paid and the real tax that would be paid. The difference between the two is that, if incomes increase and if the income tax rate scale, which is progressive, remains unchanged, the proportion of income paid in taxes increases. If the source of the increase in incomes is equal to the inflation rate over a period, in real terms the amount of tax paid by individuals increases. It increases very much more in nominal terms than it does in real terms. The figure of $56 a week that Mr Peacock quoted was based on a notional nominal increase in the amount of taxation paid over a five-year period. In other words, it was resting upon a fictitious base-something like the Opposition's alternative Budget last year; that also rested on a fictitious base. Mr Peacock, of course, was not responsible directly for that, but the indications are that he is not likely to do any better than his predecessor did.

For a person to have actually paid, in constant dollars, $56 more in taxation, we would have required over that 5 1/4-year period a compound rate of wage increases of 11.4 per cent. That is something that would be pretty easy to achieve if we had the Liberals in government. John Howard presided over a wages explosion of 13 per cent in 1981 and 14 per cent in 1982. Had we had the sort of wages inflation which was associated with the last Liberal Government and which I have no doubt would be associated with the next Liberal Government-unless it drives the economy into a 1930s-type depression-what Mr Peacock says has happened might in fact have happened. Likewise, for there to have been an increase in tax paid of that magnitude, average weekly ordinary time earnings (AWOTE) over the year would have been something above $32,000. I am sure that, if people on AWOTE actually had incomes of that magnitude, they probably would not mind paying an extra $50 a week in taxes; but, of course, they do not have them.

Mr Peacock has demonstrated, in his own words, that he is approaching the question of compiling a budget on the outlay side not from the perspective of an accountant but from the perspective of a snake oil merchant. He has also demonstrated with his further comment that he does not understand the concept of tax indexation. I recall that, when the Fraser Government had its brief flirtation with tax indexation, one of the reasons given by the then Prime Minister for the withdrawal just 12 months later was that people do not understand the concept of tax indexation. I do not know whether people do or not, but, very clearly, Andrew Peacock does not. He understands neither accounting nor the concept of tax indexation. As I said before, who needs to be numerate when a bottle of snake oil will do as a substitute for policy? I might just as a final comment add that given the record of the Liberal Party over recent years his innumeracy and lack of conceptual understanding should provide excellent qualifications for Andrew Peacock to remain as the shadow Treasurer of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. By way of preamble I point out that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) has claimed that the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) has two levels of confidentiality relating to personal medical information held by the Commission; for example a release of more sensitive information to senior political figures and the Governor-General. If this is the case, is the practice continuing? Does this practice not breach the principle of medical confidentiality? Is legislation currently being drafted to ensure proper protection against infringements of a medical practitioner's privacy and that of the patient? If so, will this legislation give individuals more legally enforceable rights over their own confidential medical information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too have seen the reports that Senator Coulter refers to and I might say that the Australian Medical Association is and has been a constant critic of the Health Insurance Commission. When one views the criticisms of the AMA it should be recognised that it has a vested interest in making criticisms of the HIC and in trying to argue that it does not effect its responsibilities properly. Despite the fact that the AMA does have a vested interest one should treat all criticisms properly, and the Government treats these properly.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator's question gives me an opportunity to reply as to what actually does happen and to clear the record. The HIC, I am advised, does not maintain an extra security VIP list as alleged. What in fact does happen and has happened since 1983, when the Medicare computer was first set up, is that certain individuals' medical records are flagged in special circumstances for particular treatment. The records which are flagged are the records of the Health Commission staff because it was believed that staff records should be treated in the same way as or in a similar way to personnel records. Where Health Commission staff deal with each other's records it was felt in those circumstances that it would be better if they were flagged and dealt with by higher authorities within the Commission. There are some individuals whose records are being flagged as well for such a treatment. Those individuals are people nominated by the State Manager of the HIC and it is not something over which the Government has any control nor seeks to have any control. They are individuals who are in a position where there is a need for special sensitivity or where there are particular concerns which the State Manager thinks make it appropriate that those records should be flagged.

The HIC recognises that privacy is of course an important and basic right and believes that its normal privacy standards as applied to the rest of us are adequate to guarantee protection of privacy. Flagging will continue because of the special categories that I have mentioned. The honourable senator asked whether there were any plans to put in amending legislation. I can say that the Government has no plans to change the existing legislation as it believes that, as far as legislative prohibitions are concerned, the current legislation goes as far as is reasonably possible to ensure proper protection against infringements of a medical practitioner's privacy or that of a patient. We point out that legislation cannot prevent the improper disclosure of information but can provide penalties, which the current Act does, and those penalties should act as a deterrent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Can the Minister inform the Senate what the level of Commonwealth Budget outlays will be in 1988-89 as a percentage of gross domestic product? What comparisons can be drawn between the present Government and its predecessor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Budget Papers show in a number of places, outlays for this year of, in round figures, $82 billion comprise 25.6 per cent of gross domestic product. It is worthy of noting that in no year of the seven years that the coalition Government was in office were outlays, as a proportion of gross domestic product, as low as that. Indeed, the lowest that outlays ever reached under the previous Government was 26 per cent of gross domestic product, in 1979-80. That fact stands, even though there has been a substantial change to the base. I refer, of course, to the introduction of the Medicare policy, which shifted a considerable amount of expenditure from the household budget to the Commonwealth Budget and is included in the figure of 25.6 per cent of GDP which I have cited. Were it not for that Medicare transfer, the figure for this year would be 25 per cent or may be lower.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also worth noting that in the last year of the unlamented former Government and in the last Budget which the discredited former Treasurer brought down, in 1982-83, outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product were a full 29 per cent-that is, 3.4 percentage points higher than this year, or in terms of the present size of GDP some $11 billion more. That is how much extra John Howard spent in the last year that he was Treasurer. To convert it into modern figures, John Howard's last Budget spent $11 billion more than the estimate of expenditure for this Budget.

Despite all the Opposition's windy rhetoric-and we still get it-the plain fact is that this Government, despite having absorbed the Medicare cost, has expenditure much more firmly under control than the Fraser-Howard Government did at any stage, and vastly more under control than John Howard had it in that last desperate irresponsible 1982 Budget. They were the big spenders of yesteryear and they are the fiscal ratbags of today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. —I seek guidance on a point of order, Mr President. The question does not relate in any way to the Minister's portfolio, and I submit that it is out of order.

—Can the Minister for Resources provide details on the nature and amounts of assistance given by the Federal Government to the French Government owned chemical giant, Rhone Poulenc, in support of that company's proposal to process monazite sand and to deposit radioactive waste in Western Australia as referred to in press statements of the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, dated 15 January 1987? Can the Minister further explain on what basis this project was endorsed and why financial incentives were provided to Rhone Poulenc before the environmental implications had been assessed and public comment considered, as per the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The development by Rhone Poulenc of a monazite processing plant accords with the broad thrust of Government policy in developing industries in which there is a higher technological input and, in particular, it accords with the thrust of something which keeps me occupied during most of my working day; that is, how we can add value to Australia's raw materials that we export. This project would add considerable value to monazite and in that sense it accords with the broad thrust of our core policy. However, we do not just say that baldly; it needs to and has to conform with environmental protections and safeguards. It needs to and has to conform with health and safety standards and, in this particular project, it has to come within the ambit of our nuclear policy as well. The particular project that Senator Vallentine has referred to requires approval under our foreign investment guidelines and thus automatically comes under the purview of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act that she has referred to.

ANSWER.PARA: The Western Australian Government and the Commonwealth Government-the Commonwealth Government in the manifestation of my colleague Senator Richardson, the Minister responsible for the environment-is currently assessing the environmental aspects of this particular project. I am advised that no direct financial incentives are provided by the Commonwealth. However, if this particular project proceeds it will benefit, as have many other mineral processing projects in Australia, from the lifting of import duty on caustic soda, which is a major agent in the treatment of monazite processing in Australia. So to that extent there would be some advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the Minister for Justice, representing the Attorney-General, has had 24 hours to think about it, and in light of the formal announcement by the Australian Chamber of Commerce that it no longer supports referendum questions Nos 1 and 2, will the Minister name one major business organisation that supports the first referendum proposal, as claimed in the Yes case booklet?

—I am quite content to rest with my answer of yesterday, which makes it quite clear that the referendum proposal to provide a maximum term for both chambers of Federal Parliament enjoys widespread support throughout the Australian community. I am sure that that must include, on the law of averages, many of those involved with the business community.

—I have a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's total inability to justify the misleading claim in the Yes case booklet which ties support for a four-year term to the Government's question No. 1, which is aimed at weakening the power of the Senate-which is the reason business has deserted the Government on this issue-I ask the Minister to apologise to the Australian people for this deceitful and deliberately misleading assertion of business support.
—Order! That was more of a statement than a supplementary question.
—It was, and the trouble with that sort of allegation is that it invites a debating type response, which I know that you, Mr President, would probably rule out of order. The fact is, as you know--
—Only to protect you.
—I think that is a reflection on the Chair, Mr President.
—Order!

—One knows that the Australian Local Government Association has spoken of Mr Peter Reith's campaign, particularly with respect to the local government question, as being composed of `blatant lies which will do an enormous amount of damage to the Liberal Party's credibility'. I believe that is the sort of response that is called for to the sorts of allegations put forward by Senator Newman, but I would not like to get into that sort of swapping of allegations across the chamber.
—You are an expert in lies, and you are doing it right now.
—Order! I ask Senator Michael Baume to withdraw the comment that he just made about the Minister.
—I withdraw.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a letter in today's Australian Financial Review from a senior consultant to the New South Wales Industrial Supplies Office accusing the Federal Government and the Australian people in general of `abject acceptance that our manufacturing has deteriorated since the mid-1970s' and accusing the Government of doing `absolutely nothing' in practical terms to replace imports? The letter also asserts that the Industrial Supplies Office is the only practical cost-effective import replacement scheme that has been put in place. Can the Minister confirm the accuracy of this statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can do all the things that Senator McMullan has asked of me but I might take a minute or two because in order to elaborate on the details I have to find the brief on this matter. The letter was drawn to my attention. I am very grateful to Senator Gareth Evans and my staff.
—What will you do when he is overseas?

—That is something that I will worry about at the time. I am indebted to him. Let me say that the correspondent in the Australian Financial Review was a person intimately associated, I understand, with the New South Wales Industrial Supplies Office. Some of the allegations made in the letter, apart from advertising the services which the Industrial Supplies Office gives, ignore a number of facts to which I want to draw the Senate's attention.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, it is not true to suggest that the manufacturing sector has declined in terms of total output, productivity, and employment. Manufacturing employment has increased over the last three years and the value of goods created in the manufacturing sector has reached record levels. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that for the last five quarters manufacturing production is up and has reached previous peak records. Manufactured exports as a proportion of total exports are at the highest figure ever and private capital investment is budgeted to increase by 12 per cent in the current financial year, which of course means increased manufacturing capacity.

More importantly than that, the writer of the letter ignores the thrust of Government policy, which is to facilitate companies becoming more internationally competitive and exporting. In that process, as industry becomes more part of the international economy there will be increased exports and increased imports into some sectors of manufacturing activity. That is inevitable as specialisation occurs. The writer ignores a number of Government programs intended to boost exports and not just develop import replacement. I remind the Senate that export activity in the manufacturing sector has improved significantly and import replacement has not perhaps improved as much as one might have expected, which is related to the point I just made.

Industry policy is directed towards building industries that can compete in global markets-not supporting them with high tariffs and so on. Companies selling to the Australian Government, for example, are required to make substantial commitments to the Australian marketplace. There is less emphasis on offset deals and encouragement of activities consistent with the vendor's core business. In the information industry we have implemented a particular program-this is an area referred to by the author of the Australian Financial Review article-in the field of information technology. The Government has done a number of other things such as encouraging the formation of a venture capital market in Australia with the management investment company scheme, improving the export market development grants scheme, and so on.

There are a number of matters one could raise in response to an article such as that. There is no substantial evidence which supports that letter in terms of a decline in manufacturing activity in Australia in the context of increased exports and a much greater specialisation in the manufacturing sector. I draw those matters to honourable senators' attention just in case some of them might be misled by that letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer and ask him about the International Labour Organisation (ILO) convention No. 160, which deals with the collection of statistics and which the Government ratified in 1986. Is the Minister aware that article 13, in referring to household expenditure surveys, binds Australia to compiling such surveys `in such a way as to be representative of the country as a whole'? Will the Minister explain why 1,541 households, or just on 20 per cent of the total 7,500 households to be surveyed under the 1988-89 household expenditure survey, come from Tasmania, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, where 5 per cent of the population lives? Why is the Government walking away from a convention it signed two years ago? In other words, what are the Government and the Australian Bureau of Statistics up to in violating this article?

—I do not know what ILO convention 160 is, much less what article 13 of that convention is; nor do I know for sure why 20 per cent of the households to be surveyed cover a geographic area in which only 5 per cent of the total population lives. I would expect, however-I will have this confirmed-that it is done for statistical reasons. If there were a uniform percentage sample taken in those areas with low population, the absolute number of people in the sample would probably be so small that a very large statistical error could be produced; but I will have that checked out.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of the report in the Australian Financial Review on 29 August indicating record productivity levels at Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's (BHP) Port Kembla works?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a matter of continual debate depending on quarterly reports. If there is a bit of industrial unrest at Port Kembla, the Opposition comes in here and moves matters of public importance and censure motions and asks a whole series of questions. That was the March quarter report. When the June quarter report came out and said that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd had messed up its technology, that the technology was not working and that that had caused an enormous downturn in production, there was not a question from Opposition members-not a bleep out of them-which makes a mockery of Senator Chaney's claim in here the other day that the Liberals are not about taking sides in industrial relations issues. There was not a question from the whole lot of them, including Senator Michael Baume, the champion of the steelworks at Port Kembla.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Childs referred to a statement by BHP recorded in the Financial Review on 29 August relating to a continuing trend in productivity figures. I made the point a minute ago that the result for earlier this year was poor, as a result of the mechanical failure of the largest blast furnace at Port Kembla. By March the position had been reversed, with a record productivity level being achieved at Port Kembla.

The latest figures mentioned in the Financial Review show that the improvement has been maintained. Not only is the equipment running well and producing near record quantities of quality steel, but also there are encouraging signs of a cooperative industrial relations climate at all of BHP's plants. They are encouraging as the steel industry plan approaches its scheduled end. The results reported at Port Kembla for recent months show what the industry can achieve now that the investment in high technology equipment is coming good, is in place and is working. The other encouraging sign is that all the parties in the industry seem to be working together towards the post-steel plan period in terms of their industrial relations commitments. That is a matter of ongoing discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Korea and Japan?

—I am sure that the productivity levels are still below those in Korea, as they are in most countries. But the fact remains that there has been an enormous improvement and BHP is once again able to say, as it has said, that it produces the cheapest steel in the world.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: USE OF NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE FACILITIES FOR FUNCTIONS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I refer you to a paper entitled Guidelines: Use of new Parliament House facilities for functions, issued to senators and members, in which it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Functions held by organisations will not be considered where, while the organisation or function is not in itself objectionable, the association of the building with the organisation or function would not be desirable (for example, to have a particular church holding a religious or ecclesiastical function in the building which may offend other religious groups and secularists).

I ask you, Mr President: Have these guidelines been endorsed by you and Madam Speaker? If so, would you and Mrs Child consider reviewing the decision, as it is concerning the Christian community that they may be denied access to the people's House to hold religious functions, whilst business, sports and other organisations can be granted access? I request that in your answer you consider the recent public statements made by church leaders around the country who are worried that the Constitution referendum question on freedom of religion could lead to freedom from religion in the same way that these guidelines restrict religious functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The guidelines which Senator Boswell has quoted from I think were taken from a draft set of guidelines prepared for consideration by the Joint House Committee. Following discussions, which included the Speaker and me, a final set of guidelines was drafted which removed the two guidelines to which Senator Boswell has referred. For the information of honourable senators, I table a set of current guidelines. The Speaker and I have approved these guidelines and they will be subject to discussions at the Joint House Committee meeting on 31 August. To date, a number of functions sponsored by the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship have been held in the new Parliament House, including a service which 2,000 people attended on 21 August. I believe that the annual national prayer breakfast is to be held on 10 October in the Great Hall.

—Has the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, seen a transcript of an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio interview with the Queensland Minister for Finance, Brian Austin, responding to suggestions Senator Walsh made in the Senate yesterday that he would ask the Treasurer to reduce Queensland's financial assistance grants by $2m? Does the Minister accept Mr Austin's statement that the cost of the Queensland Government's campaign against the fair election referendum is only $750,000? Given Mr Austin's statement that the funds for this campaign are `coming from Consolidated Revenue and it's impossible to say whether it comes from grants to the State or taxation by the State', has Senator Walsh's view as to whether the Commonwealth should recover the money been modified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether the correct figure is $750,000 or $2m, or even $50m, disregards the important point that whatever the amount it is being spent improperly. We know that there is nothing at all unusual about the improper expenditure of funds in Queensland under the present National Party Government, the survival of which is of course dependent upon the continuation of the corrupt electoral system to which the taxpayer-funded advertising campaign is directed to preserving. I am not at all surprised, however, that the Queensland National Party Minister for Finance does not know whether the cost of the campaign is coming from State or Commonwealth sources of revenue. The bigger problem in Queensland normally is not where the money is coming from but where it is going to-whether, for example, it is going to some National Party apparatchik up in the north of Queensland who is quite improperly being granted a loan following political intervention by the Minister concerned. The authority responsible for administering drought relief funds had knocked back this particular application, the Queensland National Party Minister intervened, and a Mr Michael Behan-no relation at all to Senator Beahan-got $150,000 from what the Queensland Government clearly regards as a slush fund to be delivered to National Party apparatchiks at the discretion of the State Minister. Again, it is not really surprising that the Minister who is responsible in the State of Queensland for authorising expenditure does not know how much it is.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not the first time that Queensland Government or Commonwealth Government taxpayers who have had money directed through the Queensland Government have seen money misused. Given the state of public accounting in Queensland and the disclosure of public finances, it is unlikely that we will ever know for sure how much the campaign has cost. In closing, I wish to say that the average cost of the advertisements which are being put to air is around $2,000. The Queensland public might like to reflect on the fact that every time one of those advertisements appears, that is $2,000 that is not going into Queensland's schools, hospitals, roads, public transport, public housing and whatever else we can think of, which are quite proper and legitimate areas for the expenditure of State government funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it the Government's intention to reverse its decision to delist 53 drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme?
—No.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister able to explain why his colleague the Western Australian Minister for Health, Mr Wilson, has stated quite publicly that he is satisfied that he will be able to have the Government change its mind?
—I think that is a question that Senator Crichton-Browne should direct to Mr Wilson. I cannot answer on his behalf.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that a number of pilots of Air Nauru have been dismissed from their jobs because of disputes over the airline's operational and safety procedures? Is it also a fact that the New Zealand Ministry of Transport suspended Air Nauru's air service certificate on 24 August 1988 and that, as a consequence, all subsequent flights by Air Nauru have been downgraded to a private category which prohibits carrying passengers or goods for remuneration? Is it a fact that, in spite of operating in a private, non-commercial category and having questionable safety standards, Air Nauru has continued to fly in and out of Australia carrying goods for which freight was paid? If so, why has the Government not taken appropriate action to protect the Australian flying public from the hazards created by Air Nauru operations in Australian air space?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Air Nauru dismissed most of its pilots in June this year in the context of attempts by those pilots to form a union. The reasons for the dismissal action have not been formally conveyed to us. I am unable to comment further on the circumstances of the dismissal. New Zealand has acted as the aviation regulatory authority for Air Nauru for some years, but suspended its air service certificate in June 1988 as the airline had insufficient suitably qualified personnel to manage and operate the airline.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), which came into operation on 1 July this year, did not issue an air operator's certificate to Air Nauru because of the airline's inability to meet the New Zealand requirements. So it is the case that since 1 July Air Nauru has been able to operate only private flights into Australia, The airline has given an undertaking that it will not carry commercial freight, and agents and freight forwarders are aware that Air Nauru is not available for freight services or for fare paying passengers. With regard to the safety aspect, which I suppose is the nub of Senator Sanders' question, the CAA has no reason to believe that the private operations by Air Nauru have not complied with international safety standards or that the safety of the Australian public has been adversely affected. If any event, I am advised that no further flights are planned by Air Nauru in that capacity at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance received any representations to amend the eligibility requirements for loans under the natural disaster relief arrangements (NDRA)? If so, what is the Minister's response to those representations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not received any representations directly but I have had forwarded to me by Mr Kerin a letter from Senator Crichton-Browne regarding natural disaster relief arrangements which are administered by the Department of Finance, not by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It is the custom and practice-if not in all States, certainly in most States-for a State body to administer the distribution of funds, be they rural adjustment funds or natural disaster relief funds. It is administered by a common body in Western Australia which these days is known as the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation, or RAFCOR.

ANSWER.PARA: In the letter Senator Crichton-Browne bemoans that it is not possible for an individual to get drought relief and cyclone relief at the same time. This reminds me of something Senator Puplick said in an earlier incarnation-the best three lines he has ever produced-as National President of the Young Liberals. He said of the National Party, `When the sun shines they want drought relief, when it rains they want flood relief, and if it grows they want a subsidy.' That attitude of mind is by no means confined to the National Party; it has obviously infected the Liberal Party in Western Australia as well, or at least one member of it. But, more importantly, the administration of NDRA and rural adjustment scheme funds in Western Australia a few years ago was extremely slack. Of course, in some States it still is.

On all the evidence available to me it is pretty clear that it is still extremely slack in Queensland, but it was extremely slack in Western Australia until the present Director, Mr Groves, took over the job. It was slack in a number of ways, but the one which is relevant to Senator Crichton-Browne's letter is that people would apply for a loan and get $40,000 or $50,000 at 4 per cent interest and nobody would even inquire what other assets they might have. They might have had $100,000 in the bank, or $100,000 in Commonwealth bonds, or $1m for that matter, and nobody even inquired, when these people made an application for a 4 per cent loan, whether they had any other assets, liquid or otherwise. The new administration in Western Australia has cleaned that up. Honourable senators should remember that Senator Crichton-Browne--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one of the few things they had.
—If there were any rorts going I am sure that the honourable senator would be up to his ears in them if he had half a chance.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, was that Senator MacGibbon interjecting?
—Order!
—Was it Senator Stone? I thought it was Senator Crichton-Browne.
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw that inference.
—Mr President, I certainly withdraw it. I did not think it was Senator Stone who interjected. Senator Crichton-Browne--

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I think the Minister is confused and has got in a complete mess about whom he has abused and who actually made the interjection on him. Clearly, his statement implies that there is some dishonesty on the part of a senator and he should be asked to withdraw the inference without qualification.
—Mr President, I withdraw. Let me quote what Senator Crichton-Browne said:

ANSWER.PARA: Further, the requirement regarding-
and this is a quotation from the guidelines-

`assets not essential for the future viability of the pastoral station operation' is particularly restrictive. This could mean having to mortgage a child's education and depleting investments made for retirement.

Senator Crichton-Browne said that this is an intolerable condition to impose on anybody who wants a $40,000 loan-or two $40,000 loans if he gets his way-at around 4 per cent interest, from the taxpayers. He said it is absolutely intolerable that people should actually be required to look after themselves first before they line up to get a 4 per cent loan from the taxpayers.

What this shows, of course, is that deep down the Liberal Party, especially in Western Australia, has not changed at all. The Western Australian Liberals-one or two of them, who are no longer members of the Parliament-had a reputation for some understanding, some intellectual comprehension of how a market system operates and some personal integrity. In particular, they believed that the expenditure of public money should be subject to close scrutiny and rigorous accountability. The Liberals from Western Australia who believed that were people such as John Hyde and probably Ross McLean, who have now lost their seats. What we have left here is the dregs. So-called small government dries, such as Senator Crichton-Browne, still have the same view that they have always had-that is, that ordinary people should be taxed to accumulate slush funds from which they can then distribute patronage to their cronies.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today Senator Chaney asked me a question about the national wage decision. I undertook to get a further answer from the Minister. I will do that but I just want to supplement what I said by making the point that, under the Commission's decision, any wage increases, including the March one, are dependent on a formal commitment to a review of award structures. The Commission will sit in February 1989 to hear detailed reports on progress in individual award reviews. There may be some aspects of the question which Senator Chaney still wants elaboration on and I will obtain a further answer from the Minister for Industrial Relations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time late last week Senator Lewis asked me a question which in essence was whether companies could meet their partnerships for development commitments by importing equipment, exporting it to New Zealand and re-importing it into Australia, thus apparently achieving an export-import ratio of 50 per cent, the target figure for the partnerships. In relation to that question I just want to make two points. First of all I was somewhat confused by one aspect of the question which was included with others. The question referred to sales tax and customs duties. I was somewhat confused by that because there are no customs duties on computers and associated equipment.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the two main points I want to make these observations: The partnership commitments undertaken by each corporation are part of a corporate mission given by corporate headquarters to its Australian subsidiary. The work program or the investment program has to have some underlying rationale. It is not just a matter of meeting export targets by any means possible, but of developing in Australia some strategic, internationally focused activities of long term significance to each corporation. The activities proposed by companies must be approved by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce as part of the annual review and audit process which is agreed between the company and the Department. Secondly, the export targets referred to in the partnership agreement involve the value added in Australia. The partnership program requires the average Australian content of exports by a partner firm to exceed 70 per cent over the range of its export activities. The imported content of the exported goods-if one were to export to New Zealand and import back again-thus conveys little benefit to firms, which must develop genuine Australian-based export activities to meet their targets. To take Senator Lewis's example: if $1m worth of goods is imported and then exported, the value added is zero. This does not help a corporation to meet its partnership target. The practice would also defy business logic, which underlies the whole partnership program in seeking to produce beneficial situations for the partners, that is the corporation, local firms and Australia overall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

At this stage I would just like to say a few words. I certainly would appreciate some explanation-I know many colleagues on my side of the chamber who would like some explanation-from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) as to what the partnerships for development program is all about. It makes it extraordinarily difficult to understand the matter when all we have is some sort of phraseology called the partnerships for development program. The Minister has elaborated slightly in his answer today and we now grasp some of the details but I put to the Minister that at some stage, and preferably in the very near future, he ought to make a statement in the Senate so that we in the Senate and the people of Australia can find out what this is all about. It should be a statement which sets out the nature of the arrangements.

I am asking not for personal, confidential information about the particulars but, in general, about the nature of the partnerships for development program. I believe the Minister has an obligation to provide that information to the Parliament. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will try to do what Senator Lewis has suggested. The Department's development agreements are aimed at doing something about our current account problem in terms of information industry equipment. That is essentially the underlying strategy. I shall try to put together a statement relating to the details. I simply say that during the Estimates Committee hearings in the Senate on the last occasion discussion on this issue took about two hours. I think Senator Lewis was away at the time, but other senators were involved.

—Yesterday Senator Patterson asked me a question regarding veterans in receipt of disability pension and said that she was concerned that they were being required to answer certain medical questions on the telephone. I have received a response from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. There are occasions when the Department of Veterans' Affairs makes telephone contact with veterans in order to seek information. Such information is required for clarification purposes and is not sought where a medical examination is required. The information is to augment that which already exists on departmental files. This practice is designed to provide a better service for veterans and to expedite the processing of a veteran's claim. It is not considered that any veteran's claim would be adversely affected by these pro- cedures. The Department of Veterans' Affairs at all times considers its responsibilities to the veteran and ensures that everything possible is done to assist the veteran in the presentation of a claim for disability pension to the determining authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the process of purporting to answer a question, Senator Walsh led the Senate to believe that I had applied, by way of representation to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, for drought relief and for cyclone relief at the same time, as if to give the impression that it had been raining but was dry at the same time. Though it may be greatly amusing to those in the Government, led by Senator Walsh, to trivialise the pain, suffering and economic devastation of people affected in the way in which those I represent were affected, it in no way does credit to the senator from Western Australia, who I presume from time to time purports to represent his constituents. There is an area in Western Australia, East Gascoyne, which suffered devastation from a dry cyclone-even Senator Walsh will understand what a dry cyclone is. The wind erosion was enormous, and the loss of stock, fences and windmills was devastating. That came at a time of deep drought in the same area. Honourable senators will understand the combined effect of those two climatic circumstances. But Senator Walsh finds that very amusing. He thinks it very amusing that in a matter of hours people can see a lifetime of effort and work go past them--
—Order! A personal explanation must not be used to attack another senator. Senator Crichton-Browne must confine himself to explaining how he was misrepresented.
—Yes, Mr Deputy President. I would never do that in relation to Senator Walsh. He himself is unaccustomed to such behaviour.
—Don't be uncharitable.

—Senator Button is quite right. To say that of Senator Walsh is to be uncharitable. Senator Walsh purported to be quoting my correspondence. What he was doing was quoting two or three phrases out of context, for which practice he is notorious. As you point out, Mr Deputy President, a personal explanation does not give me an opportunity to go into the details of the representation that I made to the Minister; I shall save that for another time. Suffice it to say that my representation was made on the basis of devastation wreaked upon the pastoralists of Western Australia by way of a drought and a cyclone at the same time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mr President has received a letter from Senator Calvert proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to oppose Labor's empty but dangerous proposal for local government by voting no to the third referendum.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I lead the debate on this matter of public importance with a great degree of honour. I thank my colleagues for the support they have given me in opposing the third referendum question. It is an honour because this debate is a matter of grave public importance to everyone, particularly to the ratepayers of those 800 councils and shires throughout Australia. It is a matter of importance because, put simply, should this question be passed in the forthcoming referendum the very existence of local government as we know it today will be lost. Over 100 years of tradition will be thrown out of the window merely to satisfy this Australian Labor Party Government's hidden agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud to say that I have supporting me two members of the coalition, Senator Panizza and Senator McGauran, who have both had long and distinguished careers in local government. As honourable senators know, Senator McGauran represented the central business district of Melbourne on the very distinguished Melbourne City Council, which has a budget in excess of $200m. Senator Panizza served as a West Australian shire councillor for some 12 years, including five years as shire president. Before he retired he was a delegate to the Country Shire Councils and a delegate to the great eastern areas of the Country Shire Councillors Association. He retired from all these positions in local government to become a senator. It is important to realise that when we speak on the possible effect of this question on local governments and how they would suffer we all speak with considerable experience and practical knowledge.

As a former member of local government for some 12 years and a warden, or shire president as some might interpret the position, for four years, I am well aware of the fervour with which some elements of local government have sought to get some acknowledgment of the system of local government in the Federal Constitution. Since the heady days of the 1970s, recognition has almost become local government's holy grail. Perhaps for those of us who can remember some of the early radio serials, I suggest that it has become a search for the golden boomerang. For some reason there are some local government members who believe that if they can achieve this so-called ultimate aim of achieving recognition in the Federal Constitution, like manna from heaven a great change will occur and the massive taxes which are paid by the ratepayers will be returned to them in bigger lumps and with fewer strings attached. I say categorically that in reality nothing could be further from the truth. I have to make a confession that when this matter was first raised in the party room I gave serious consideration to supporting the proposal for a Yes vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well done.

—However, Minister, I was new to the ways of politics and, thankfully, wiser heads than mine prevailed. Thank goodness they did, because I was wrong and I am quite happy to admit it. Since that time, and as this matter is debated more and more in the public arena, it has become quite evident that this proposal is a trojan horse for local government. It promises much, it delivers little, and it takes away a great deal. It has been condemned in the media and by academics. Smarter men than I, and men of greater esteem, have attacked this proposal. The Australian newspaper's editorial of 2 August made a scathing attack on this proposal. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is an unnecessary intrusion into the internal administration of the States and could be the cause of endless confusion and a deluge of litigation.
Further on it continued:

Nevertheless, it is at best unnecessary and at worst could be confusing, costly and time-consuming. Far from extending democracy it would take the power to determine local government questions away from elected State parliaments and deliver it to unelected judges.

Further, Associate Professor George Winterton from the University of New South Wales Law School mirrored the views of so many constitutional professionals in an article in the Australian with the headline `Local government-leave well alone'. In the article he says:
. . . it would be a mistake to reduce the power of the States to ensure honest and competent local government by introducing Federal constitutional complications into such questions.
There are other quotations, and I refer to the Sunday Mail of 21 August and an article headed `We say ``No'' ', as follows:

The constitutional structure of Australia, and its demography, require that the States remain the principal mode of government. Concentrating further decision-making in Canberra would simply feed the overblown Federal bureaucracy.
The list of quotations is endless and I do not intend to use all my time telling the Government what it already knows.

The question has blown up in the Government's face. The ratepayers of Australia are aware of the duplicity. The Constitution does not recognise the position of Prime Minister, yet we seem to have been able to get along well with quite a few Prime Ministers with only a few minor hiccups over the past 87 years. There is not a ratepayer in this country who does not already know that local government exists. So much for all the grandstanding! What is local government really looking for? I have questioned several of my former local government colleagues on what this question will do for them. I also asked: `What is in it for you?'. In most cases, if I received an answer at all, it seemed to be more influenced by ego rather than an underlying belief that this process was all that was necessary. Answers largely took the form of: `It will give us more status' or `It is a sign of our importance in the overall system of government'. Of course, some raised the furphy that they will be able to deal with the Federal Government without having to go through a State government. I will say more about that and the dangers involved later.

It is interesting to note that Senator Archer, my colleague from Tasmania, when responding to some 150 councils challenged them to write to him about the advantages that recognition would bring to local government. As far as I know, he did not receive one positive answer. So one is forced to question whether or not there are sections of local government that do not understand the implications themselves.

Let us look at what the proposal fails to deliver to local government. One of the principal drawbacks is that it does not mean that local councils need to be democratically elected. I find it amazing, at a time when the Federal Government is making such a big noise about the way that it values local government, that it has not even seen fit to apply the fair elections proposal to local government. Those councils which are subject to gerrymanders will therefore have them permanently entrenched as part of the system. This proposal will not allay the real fears of local government. This is purely a formal and deleterious provision which achieves nothing beyond the recognition of local government in name only.

Let us look at a few of the nots. The proposal will not preclude a State from undertaking the compulsory acquisition of local government bodies. It will not preclude the arbitrary dismissal of councils. It will not preclude the appointment of an administrator pending new elections. It will not compel a State to provide for local government recognition in any part of a State. It will not preclude the withdrawal of local government recognition from any existing area. Finally, it will most definitely not guarantee satisfactory funding for local government. Like most thinking people, this coalition has ascertained that this token recognition will do nothing for local government. However, on the other hand, there are a multitude of problems which could manifest themselves. My advice to local government is: Why put your head in a noose when you do not have to? There are so many potholes in this proposition that it could ruin the local government budget.

To me, it is a question of responsibility. Why should those people who believe in local government so much-and I refer to the councillors and aldermen themselves-be prepared to leave the whole system of local government as we know it today open to the whims and interpretations of the High Court of Australia? Referendum question No. 3, with respect to local government, seeks the approval of voters for a change to the Constitution by inserting new section 119a, and I will read it out just in case some senators have forgotten what it is all about.

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the States.

We all know that the proposal differs from the form of words recommended by the Government's own Constitutional Commission. The Federal Government has not chosen to explain why the words `a system of local government' and the words `the laws of the States' were inserted. The Government's haste will ensure that we cannot be sure of the real meaning of the proposal, even if it is adopted.

Firstly, there is the uniqueness of the provision. Put in plain terms, there is simply no similar provision in the Constitution which may be used as an aid to interpretation. Secondly, by not defining what a system of local government actually is, it is inviting the inevitable legal challenge. Can we assume that this proposal applies exclusively to local government, as is perceived in the community? If not, what is to prevent the proposal from applying to electricity councils, marine boards, water boards and others provided that they are constituted pursuant to State laws? In the past the High Court has been able to give meaning to legislation by reference to the words used in that legislation. In the past the High Court has clarified areas of doubt by using provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act to determine the meaning of the ambiguous and badly worded expressions, referring to other materials such as second reading speeches, explanatory memoranda and parliamentary debates. In this case the Acts Interpretation Act does not apply to imperial Acts such as our Constitution, and the High Court, therefore, would not be able to refer to other materials to assist in determining the will of the Parliament.

The interpretation of this proposal is a minefield into which I would strongly advise that local governments should not choose to venture. No less a person than a former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs, has given his warning on the problems of interpretation. He said:

The history of constitutional interpretation in Australia and the United States shows that it is impossible to predict what meaning will in the future be given to any provision of the Constitution which is expressed in the words of generality.
He went on:

. . . one cannot . . . assume that any general provision . . . will have no more than a symbolic effect. One can understand how some may feel that a constitutional provision recognising the existence of local government may in time prove to be the nether millstone on which the power of the States will be ground exceedingly small; the upper stone, the Commonwealth power, being held firmly in place.

Those areas of local government which are presently being starved of funds by this Government may feel that Canberra will be more generous if it gets its way. I really think that is what is behind it all, why local governments are pushing it. I should like to issue a timely warning to all those who feel that such an option will be of benefit: such funding would bring local government under Canberra control. It is a truism that he who pays the piper most definitely calls the tune, and therein I believe lies the hidden meaning behind Labor's plans. It has long been the intention of the Australian Labor Party to centralise power in Canberra. Mr Hawke, in his 1979 Boyer lecture on ABC radio proudly espoused that intention:
We must have one government with unquestioned powers.

I guess that is the reason why we heard the hysterical outburst in the other place today when the Prime Minister attacked Peter Reith on so-called misquotes he is alleged to have made. I suspect that the Prime Minister's hysteria stems from the fact that he can see his dream of one government slipping away. Before that, in 1978 Neal Blewett of identity card fame, when speaking of Labor's plans for regionalisation, said that they should not be encumbered with `nonsense about local sovereignty'. Senator Burns has made it quite clear that the prospect of encouraging local government as a means of undermining the authority of State governments was still being widely canvassed in government circles. On 23 May this year, during the debate on local government, Senator Burns said:

I am very much inclined to the idea of giving local councils more authority and having the Federal government looking after the rest, thereby getting rid of the State governments. That seems to me to be a good idea.

If the proposal is approved, then I am convinced that the Labor Government's trend of funding local government into programs in the first year and then withdrawing and leaving local government to carry the can will continue. I am sure that every member on this side of the House, and perhaps on the other side of the House, who has ever been involved in local government would know the feeling of the great expectation that one gets from this Government when it comes along and promises--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or any government.

—Well, fair enough-any government. Local Government always ends up carrying the can. Local government must be made aware that by paving the way for Labor to reincarnate Whitlam's dream of bypassing the States through powerful regional bodies controlled from Canberra they are selling themselves out, giving the green light for this and future Federal governments to have unparalleled rights to intervene in local affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government is once again guilty of the worst kind of hypocrisy in its treatment of local government. Let the record speak for itself, and I know that my colleagues will be elaborating more on this. The last Liberal-National Party Government gave local government a fixed funding arrangement through personal income tax sharing. It provided for local government representation on the State Grants Commission and provided for the distribution of tax revenue. It maintained the bicentennial road funding levy of 2c per litre to provide more road funding. It established a very honourable forum for local government in the Advisory Council for Intergovernment Relations (ACIR).

In contrast, this Government's real record is abysmal. It is obvious to me that there are many on the other side of the chamber who speak with forked tongues. Why else, I ask myself, would they be prepared to sit idly by and watch the ACIR be dismantled, and federal road funding cut by 35 per cent in real terms over the past four years, including a massive $35m in the May economic statement? Coincidentally, that happens to be the same amount of money that this Government has spent on this useless campaign. In addition to introducing quarterly payment grants as a cost saving measure for itself, it has pegged back the 2 per cent of personal income tax and introduced a much less favourable formula for local government. What should local government think of a Federal government which says, `We will allow you to rate our Commonwealth properties'-this is very recent-and in the next breath says that it will reduce local government grants accordingly? That is how committed this Government is to local government.

What right has local government and its organisations to levy ratepayers all over Australia to promote its so-called case? What right has the Australian Local Government Association and other like bodies to place at risk local government, the oldest system of government in Australia, and to take it within the State system and leave it open to the power grabbers in Canberra.

In Tasmania, I am very proud to say, we have the oldest area of local government in Australia, the Glamorgan Council. It was there before any other council was established in this land.
