It is a very good council and it has always been a very good council, so why change it? Why put it at risk of being replaced by a regional local government? There is every chance that could happen.

Finally, if we ever needed any proof of how this Government has hoodwinked local government into believing all sorts of things, we only have to look at the Australian newspaper today. An open letter from local government to Australian voters on this issue of the referendum, no doubt paid for by a levy placed on ratepayers, says:
If approved the provision will guarantee--

How can anybody guarantee what this Government or any future government will do? How can anybody guarantee what the decision of the High Court will be? We in Tasmania have seen what High Courts do. The letter says that `a yes vote will not give any extra power to Canberra or give the Commonwealth power to impose a system of regional government'. How does that line up with what we know about the external affairs power that this Government has used so effectively against Tasmania. It is no coincidence that local government has entered into an international compact which lays open the possibility of future Commonwealth governments using the external affairs power to interfere and meddle in the affairs of the States. Madam Acting-Mr Acting Deputy President-

TALK.START.PARA: —I take no offence.

—You may take no offence, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I take offence at this misleading advertising, with the Local Government Association saying that it will give a guarantee. No-one can guarantee anything.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate. I note the commitment of Opposition senators to local government as they all leave the chamber. I am sorry that they are so disinterested that they are not prepared to wait and listen to the facts. Even Senator Boswell is leaving. I would have thought that, given his comments, he at least would have been interested in hearing what I had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some difficulty with the wording of the matter of public importance. On the one hand it describes the third question as being `empty'-if it is empty, why are we bothering to debate it this afternoon?-and on the other hand describes it as dangerous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Right.
—I have always thought of Senator Chaney as a logical debater. I defy him to debate logically how something can be both empty and dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: The final words of the matter of public importance say something about voting no to the `third referendum'. For the information of voters, I remind them that they are being asked to vote in one referendum for four questions. The matter of public importance this afternoon relates to the third question.

I am rather disappointed in Senator Calvert. I think he is genuine in his commitment to local government. He has experience. I have visited the council he used to represent. I am surprised that he would exhibit such paternalistic, arrogant attitudes to local government. In speaking in this debate today he as good as said that local government all over Australia does not know what it is talking about-that more than 8,000 elected representatives and over 130,000 employees in local government do not know their own minds. I find that paternalistic. I find it arrogant. It is consistent with the attitude of the Victorian Liberal Party which, apparently, exhibited the same fundamental distrust of local government during the debate last year on the local government Bill that was then before the Parliament. The Opposition signalled that it would not agree to councils being given wider powers in the rating area; that it could not be trusted.

In voicing its opposition to differential rating, the Liberal Party said that those councils on the other side of politics might use the increased flexibility as a means of redistributing wealth. The proposal, apart from anything else, indicates to me that the Liberal Party does not trust local government. I find that distasteful. We can have all kinds of debate in this chamber about resources and priorities, which I will move on to in a short time. But I would have thought that the Liberal Party, even if it is not prepared to support this referendum question, would recognise the fundamental worth and value of local government as the third sphere of government in this country.

The terms of the matter of public importance talk about the third referendum question being a dangerous proposal. I defy Senator Calvert, as I did Senator Chaney as he left the chamber, to argue how this proposal can be both empty and dangerous. What is dangerous-an example of which I would like to table today-is the advertising strategy of the Liberal Party's coalition partner in Queensland. The Queensland Government is spending hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money on misleading advertising. Not only is it misleading, it is also offensive because it uses a very violent symbol. I display it now for those Opposition senators who have not yet seen it. The wording is, `You are looking down the barrel at propositions to change Australia forever-Vote No . . .'. This is the first time in the history of the Westminster system that such a symbol of violence, a gun pointed directly at the reader, has been used in trying to persuade voters to vote in a certain way, as the people of Queensland are being persuaded to vote in the way the National Party Government wishes. I think that Senator Calvert, as a reasonable individual, would not condone this kind of advertising.

It is not really necessary in this debate for me to speak on behalf of the Government because I have so much material with which to speak on behalf of local government. Honourable senators can take their choice. I can speak on behalf of the Government, but most of my material comes directly from local government. I start with a letter from the Australian Local Government Association (ALGA) dated 25 August, addressed to the Hon. J. W. Howard, M.P. It states:
Dear Mr Howard

I am writing to appeal to your sense of fair play. On the 7.30 Report on 22 August the Shadow Attorney General said that many Local Governments across Australia were defecting from the official Local Government position in support of referendum Question 3. This morning on the Mike Carlton radio show Mr Reith stated that Local Government Associations around the country are dumping the Yes Case.

Nothing could be further from the truth, and Mr Reith knows that full well. He has deliberately misrepresented the facts. He obviously is concerned that he cannot justify the No vote in regard to the local government question so he has to misrepresent his case. The letter from the Local Government Association to John Howard went on:
These are blatant lies which will do an enormous amount of damage to the Liberal Party's credibility with Local Government both in the short and long term.

Let me assure members of the Opposition, and particularly members of the Liberal Party-because I think many members of the Liberal Party are quite genuine in their commitment to the recognition of local government; it is just that their Party has made a foolish decision, having been knocked into submission by the National Party-that they will receive an enormous backlash all around the country because of the totally illogical stance they have taken. The Local Government Association went on to say:

ALGA is extremely concerned at the extent to which actions such as this are souring our relationship with the Opposition. The facts are as follows. The ALGA and eight of our nine constituent State-based member associations are actively promoting the Yes Case for Question 3. The Western Australian Country Shire Councils Association, whose members represent 20 per cent of that State's population, agreed at their Annual Conference on 28 August to take no public position on the referendum by virtue of the Conference's defeating the following two motions:

`That this Conference fully supports the referendum proposal to alter the Federal Constitution to recognise Local Government, and calls on the people of Western Australia to register a `yes' vote on this question'.

We acknowledge that that Association has agreed to that position. We state that as a fact. But to say that all over the country local government is changing its mind is absolute rot and is absolutely incorrect. The letter continues:
I enclose for your information a copy of our media release issued yesterday concerning the comments by Mr Reith on the 7.30 Report.

That letter is just the first indication of the support this question has in the community. Let us consider the kinds of statements that are being made about this question. It is interesting to note that three people who have had a very high profile in campaigning for the Yes vote are members of the Liberal Party. The first is Mr Peter Kyle, who is also Chairperson of the Local Government Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the Chairman, actually, not Chairperson.
—In my language he is the Chairperson. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Constitution was framed 90 years ago the role of Local Government has been transformed. It now has the responsibility to provide a tremendous range of services to the people and community facilities which I suspect most of us often simply take for granted. Local Government is an increasingly important part of the structure of government in Australia but it is still the level of government most in touch with the people. Australian Local Government deserves the recognition and protection of the Australian Constitution.

The President of the Municipal Association of Tasmania, Councillor Jim Mooney, has also had links with the Liberal Party, at least in the past-I am not quite sure how he feels about that Party at the moment. Jim Mooney says:

Local Government has always been of special importance to Tasmania. Local Government is small government. It is government working with the community and serving people's needs. It is independent of the big governments that operate far from where most of us live. The big breakthrough for my council and my community will come when Local Government has gained recognition-long overdue recognition-in the Australian Constitution.

I just add, as an aside, that a number of members of the Opposition have behaved in this debate as if the question of constitutional recognition is something new, something dreamed up by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or by me, the present Minister for Local Government. Local government in Australia has been campaigning for 40 years for constitutional recognition. This is a fact. There has been a long-standing debate within local governments. They object to not being recognised in the Constitution.

I move on to another very prominent member of the Liberal Party, the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson, who, I understand, is to be invited into Federal Parliament because it is believed that she has a very influential profile and commitment to Liberal Party values. She is seen as a future leader of the Liberal Party. I note that Senator Calvert is nodding. He obviously agrees with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —She would make a good Minister for Local Government.
—She would make an excellent leader of the Liberal Party and certainly will always speak out in support of local government. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: Brisbane City Council administers an annual budget of-
many millions of dollars-
and we provide a wide range of community service to three-quarters of a million people.

Our responsibilities increase year by year. Today's system of government in Australia is a partnership between federal, State and Local Governments. It is a partnership which has made Expo such a triumph.
That partnership between our governments should be recognised in the Australian Constitution.
When it is recognised, Local Government will be in a much stronger position to help the other governments eliminate waste and duplication and we will all be better off for that.

I think it would be appropriate at this stage in the debate to go through a number of significant councils. I will start with a letter from Senator Calvert's home State. The following letter comes from the Municipality of Kingborough. The honourable senator will be aware that the Municipality of Kingborough has taken a very firm stance on this matter. It says:

The Kingborough Council firmly supports the Municipal Association of Tasmania's view that the amendment is a realistic and appropriate recognition of the role of Local Government as the third sphere of government in Australia.

Council believes that there should be non-partisan support for the inclusion of this item in the referendum and in fact should be active support from both sides of Parliament for the `Yes' vote. It is disappointing that to date so few politicians have come out in support of recognition. The arguments against the proposed referendum question were recently put to the Annual Conference of the Municipal Association of Tasmania by Senator Shirley Walters. The delegates present, who were representative of over 90 per cent of the Councils in the State, soundly rejected the arguments.

In other words, Senator Walters, despite her very vociferous and, I am sure, well-prepared arguments, could not persuade the Municipal Association of Tasmania. At that conference, the Association was representative of over 90 per cent of Tasmanian councils. The letter continues:

As the President of the Australian Local Government Association, Mr Peter Kyle, said at the Annual Conference, Local Government has been doggedly pursuing Constitutional Recognition for over 20 years and this will be the last opportunity for many years to achieve that aim-46.9 per cent of the electorate supported the amendment proposed in 1984 and over 66 per cent of the electorate supported Constitutional Recognition of Local Government in May this year according to the poll published in `The Australian', with Tasmania polling highest of all the States.

This Council therefore gives its overwhelming support for the inclusion of the Local Government Recognition question in the September referendum and will strongly urge the Opposition to seriously review its position on this subject.
I know that honourable senators would be most interested to hear me read from dozens and dozens of similar letters, but I will not take the time to go any further in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the average voter?

—What I would like to quote from, for the benefit of Senator Panizza, is a pamphlet that has been put out by the local government association in his State, because it goes through precisely the furphies, red herrings and completely illogical arguments that Opposition members have tried to put across to the electorate. It puts them in perspective because local government in Western Australia, and indeed around the country, knows that there is no risk, no danger and no threat.
—You are a joke!
—If it is a joke, I am not the joke. Senator Knowles is saying that local government throughout Australia is a joke.
—Don't misrepresent me. I said that you are the joke.

—I am quoting all my material from local government. It is not material that I or my Department have dreamed up. It is not material that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has dreamed up. Everything I have in front of me at the moment comes from local government. The referendum question is about local government, and local government is entitled to have its views put-and that is what I will try to do in the last few minutes. Some of the statements and questions asked in the pamphlet are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: What it will do for local communities and residents.
Senator Calvert said that he had not been able to get a satisfactory answer to this. The answer is under the heading `Protection':

Local government does exist and should exist. Constitutional recognition will guarantee that it continues to exist thereby ensuring that citizens have the right to determine how their local community is run.

Although the State Government will still have the power to sack councils, the Constitution will demand that democratically elected local government is returned to the community. However, a community whose council has been sacked and new elections are not called within a reasonable time, could take the matter to the High Court.
Constitutional recognition will guarantee that councils are elected rather than appointed.
What about the question of money, finances? Of course we would all like to see more money available for local government and other sectors of the community. The answer is:

In itself, constitutional recognition will not automatically bring more taxes back to local communities, but with enhanced legitimacy, local government can negotiate with other spheres of government as a partner . . .
A legitimate three-way partnership will help to ensure that proper agreements are reached to avoid duplication or overlap of government services . . .
To the question, `But isn't this an attack on state's rights?' the reply is:
The Federal Coalition has claimed so, but have you heard any of the State Governments say this.
The exception, of course, is Queensland. The reply continues:
If there was the slightest hint of an attack on state's rights wouldn't you expect the states to defend themselves?
Even with constitutional recognition, the structure and functions of local government will still be prescribed by state legislation.

I am certainly very disappointed in the Opposition. It has lost an enormous amount of credibility. It has lost an enormous opportunity to enter this debate with the Government on a genuine bipartisan basis. On Sunday it will see that the proposal has the community's support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure, at least in one respect, that I engage in this discussion of matter of public importance, the terms of which read:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to oppose Labor's empty but dangerous proposal for local government by voting no to the third referendum.

I echo the comments of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) in that I have great difficulty in understanding how something which is empty can be dangerous. We all know, however, that empty vessels make the most noise. It is not surprising that we should be faced, so close to the actual referendum date, with a proposal for discussion which is so difficult to understand. The whole argument of the No case for the third referendum question has been difficult to understand all along. That will become evident during the time that is at my disposal in this debate and no doubt during the rest of the debate as members of the Opposition attempt to make some sort of coherent contribution. I should point out, as the Minister did, that we do not have three referendums; we have only one. We do, however, have four questions.

The proposition that is before us would be laughable if it was not so tragic, at least from the point of view of local government. I would like to make a general comment on the way in which the referendum debate seems to have unfolded during the past many weeks. It seems to me that, on the one hand, people who support the Yes case seem to need sworn affidavits, High Court judgments, almost tablets from on high, in order to be able to convince some people of the value of these changes to the Constitution. On the other hand, people who support the No case seem to need not one shred of real evidence in putting their case. This will become clearly evident, if it has not already done so, to anyone who reads the transcript of the debates or who listens to the debates.

I should make it clear at this point that the Australian Democrats are very strongly in favour of constitutional recognition of local government. It has been a matter of policy for us for the entire period of our party's existence during the past 11 years. It used to be a matter of policy for the Liberal Party, of course-and still is, for some pretty prominent members of the Liberal Party. I begin my substantive comments on this question by quoting the former Liberal leader in the Victorian Legislative Council, the Honourable Alan Hunt. On 17 June this year he said:
The arguments against recognition are the arguments of the seventies, not the eighties.

I would have thought that that was quite complimentary to the people who are putting the No case. I have never heard such a bunch of troglodytes in my life as I heard last night in Cooma when I had the pleasure of being engaged in a debate on this matter. I congratulate the Farmers Association of New South Wales for organising it. The arguments of the troglodytes were that the Founding Fathers-I remind the Senate that they were all `fathers'-had a set of ideas and we should be in fear and trepidation of changing anything that they put in place at that time. That is the attitude of people whose vision looks backwards and who wish to remain in the past. That is certainly not the sort of approach that the Democrats would take. I think that Alan Hunt was actually being complimentary by saying that the Liberal and National parties have taken a position that belongs in the seventies. Maybe he meant the 1870s.

I would like to refer briefly to the purpose of the referendum. As has already been said in this debate-and it will be said again-local government, the oldest form of representative government in Australia, is not mentioned in the Commonwealth Constitution. That is a fact. Recognition of local government is about being fair to the level of government which-and I will say a few things about what local government does-looks after $40 billion worth of roads, buildings and public property; found jobs for a quarter of those unemployed people who were given work in the public sector during the last five years; is involved in providing most of the family welfare programs and most of the services for children, the disabled and the aged; and employs more than 160,000 people around Australia. Those are just a few of the contributions by local government in our society.

Local government has come a long way since it was first established as a road-making authority. In many areas local authorities were called road boards during the last century and early this century. In 1900 when those Founding Fathers were writing our Constitution they could perhaps have been forgiven for not mentioning local government, but today we are the people charged with overseeing the Constitution and putting propositions before the people. The Australian Democrats are strongly in support of a range of propositions being put before the people of this country. We have faith in the ability of people, given information and not garbage, to make decisions. The Australian Democrats would do so on a range of matters beyond constitutional matters. In contrast to the situation in the early 1900s, we believe that there is no reason why we should not accept that local government plea of 40 years standing that such recognition be given.

Local government's request for constitutional recognition is, I think the Senate needs to be reminded, supported by the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations, the Constitutional Convention and, until recently, the Liberal Party of Australia, not to mention all the local government organisations around this country. As the Minister has said, significant Liberal Party figures are still on record as supporting this proposition. They include the Lord Mayor of the great city of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson, who has, on platforms with my colleague Senator Macklin from Queensland, strongly supported this case. I think it would be a great enhancement to this Parliament if she were to accept an invitation which I am sure, particularly this week, must be handed out by her Liberal Party colleagues to come down here to try to knock a bit of sense into this lot.

The Leader of the Opposition in my State of Victoria might, were he to look at Hansard, be quite surprised to see me making some positive comments about a contribution that he has made recently in any political debate, but he has come out strongly against the No case and in favour of the Yes case. If there is one thing that can be said about Jeff Kennett it is that from time to time he does see where political advantage lies. In this case he has decided to add his voice against the voices of his Federal colleagues in support of constitutional recognition of local government. I have mentioned Alan Hunt. The list goes on, right down to local government level.

In my travels not only around my State of Victoria, in discussions I have had with individual councils and local government organisations, but also in discussions with city and shire councils and local government organisations in a number of other States, particularly in the cities of Hobart and Perth in recent weeks, I have found members of the Liberal Party and National Party who are elected members of local government bodies who are somewhat astonished to be talking to a member of the Australian Democrats who is pleading for support for an Australian Labor Party Government proposition for constitutional change. These people seem somewhat bemused, demoralised and, in fact, angry at the position that is being taken by the Opposition. These people are disappointed with the political parties which have had in their policies until now strong support for constitutional recognition of local government. Of course, we are seeing in a number of other policy areas how quickly and expeditiously-though not without blood on the floor-those parties can change their policies in some cases for disgraceful political reasons in accordance with what is imposed from the top.

Constitutional recognition will add to the status of local government in its dealings with politicians and bureaucrats. Unfortunately, this is needed today because we have politicians, especially here in Canberra, who think they know what is best for local government. They think they know better than the elected councillors. (Quorum formed) Some fairly extraordinary claims were made by Senator Calvert in his contribution to this debate and, in the time remaining to me, I would like to address a couple of them. He asked, for instance `What is local government looking for?' It is a simple matter of looking at the evidence to see what local government has said it is looking for. He obviously does not want to do that any more. I think it is a shame that former local government members come into this place and suddenly their ears get blocked with the wax of Federal parliamentary ego.

To make matters worse, Senator Calvert accused local government of operating on an ego base for status and importance. Certainly local government deserves status but it is not the ego of local government councillors that is pursuing this. Senator Calvert then said that perhaps they do not understand. On both counts I think those are insults to his former local government colleagues. He complained that the Federal Government, through this proposal, would not be imposing a particular electoral system. But that would be interfering with State powers. He has also complained about the Government doing that, which it does not, because this proposition would insert something into the Constitution which would guarantee the current position of the States with relation to local government.

Another accusation that is made concerning the No case is that this is merely tokenism. I will not respond to that because Opposition senators might get oversensitive and call a quorum again but I will let the local government bodies themselves respond to that. The Municipal Association of Victoria issued a Press statement in May, after some discussions at a conference, in which it said:

Some Liberals have told us privately that they support the notion of constitutional recognition for local government but they think people will be confused if they advocate a `no' vote for some questions and a `yes' vote for others.
Now that's real tokenism. And its an insult to the collective intelligence of local communities.
A bit of respect for the rights of local communities is not too much to expect and I would urge the Opposition to change its stance on this issue.

I echo that urging of the Municipal Association of Victoria and municipal associations all round Australia who are not being listened to by the arrogant Federal politicians on the Opposition side. They ought to be listened to. They are the oldest form of representational government in this nation. The whole of the No case has been an insult to them in particular and to the community in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Powell leaves the chamber-which, no doubt, she will do along with her supporters-I would just like to shoot down in flames her ridicule of the words `empty but dangerous' in the Opposition's matter of public importance. Has a woman such as Senator Powell, who represents the whole of Victoria and who talks on agriculture and everything that may be going, not heard of anything being empty but dangerous? Mr Acting Deputy President, even you as a former metal worker, or whatever you were, would know what that means.
—I would not call you empty and dangerous; just empty.

—Okay. Honourable senators know how dangerous a full 200-litre petrol drum is. There are different degrees of danger. If it is emptied it is 10 times more dangerous. So much for Senator Powell ridiculing the statement in our matter of public importance, and so much for the statement of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds). Let me carry on further.
—You are carrying on all right.

—I can carry on all right. It has been argued that Opposition senators do not recognise the work of local government. I am the biggest expounder of the work of local government. In Western Australia the theme at government conferences used to be the three tiers of government-Federal, State and local. We tried to reverse that to make it local, State and Federal. The present Minister for Local Government then agreed that the three tiers of government were equally important. I have always reckoned that local government is the most important sort of government as it is nearest the people. I recognise the work that local government does. As I have pointed out, I was in local government for 13 years and I was president of a shire council for three years. I know what local government does. It is the government that is nearest to the people, it listens to the people more and it spends its dollars far more wisely than any other government or any parliament, including this Parliament.
—You are denying them their rights under the Constitution.

—No, I am not. Let us forget those bunkum stories that we on this side of the chamber are not interested in what local government is doing. We recognise local government and I will continue to recognise it time and again. If I were not in this place I would still be in local government. As I have said, before I came to this place, when I was part of local government, I tended to agree with that idea of recognition and so did the local government association that I belonged to-the Country Shire Councils Association of Western Australia. The Minister for Local Government said that that association represents only 30 per cent of local government electors in Western Australia. That may be so, but it represents 115 local governments out of a total of 139. The association that Peter Kyle belongs to represents about 15 local governments. Another association, the Urban Shire Councils Association, represents the other four or five. The platform of that association has been more or less the recognition of local government over the years-certainly over the years that I was a member of local government and a delegate at meetings of the Country Shire Council Association. This is a situation like the Australia Card, and I think even Senator Powell disagreed with that. When the full facts of that matter were brought to the attention of that association it gradually lost support. Last weekend the association of about 115 shire councils failed to pass a motion to support the Yes case.
—It did not pass the motion.

—Yes, I know it did not, so their Yes case has gone down. As far as I am concerned and as far as it is concerned the Country Shire Councils Association of Western Australia is definitely not supporting the yes vote. I will go back to the empty 200 litre drum of petrol illustration: it is dangerous because we do not know what is in it. This proposal for the recognition of local government is dangerous because we do not know what is in it. It is as simple as all that. Senator Reynolds, when reading the local government association pamphlet of Peter Kyle from Perth, pointed out what it would have to gain. Peter Kyle is a fellow whom I respect very much in his profession and in local government. All of those things she read out are not in the legislation. So what do we know? I know that all the questions in this referendum are put up as an empty sort of thing; misleading, just motherhood questions. But it does not tell us what is in the proposal. Having looked at what is in it I consider it is dangerous.
—And you know what is in it?

—I know what? I do not know what is in it; that is why I am against it. That is what I am coming to. What does the proposal give to local government and what has local government got to gain? After all if Canberra wants any more power it is like my wanting a favour out of someone or wanting something in a business deal. There has to be something in it for me; otherwise I will not get into it and nor would this Government get into it.
—We are not like that.
—The Government is not like that? It would be making a big turnaround if it were not like that.
—Do not judge everybody by yourself.

—Yes, all right but I like to know what I am being let in for. There is nothing in it whatsoever. It is an empty show to placate local government officers. When talking about local government councillors and all local government it turns out that most of the local governments do not want this proposition. Do not let us forget that beyond local government we have the ratepayers who as electors will be voting next Saturday. So exactly what local government wants and what the ratepayers want could quite easily be two different things. Certainly in different publications in Western Australia it has been pointed out that local government has enough power as it is. I shall quote an article from the Australian Financial Review of 25 August 1988 by Padraic McGuinness. Incidentally, I believe he was an adviser to Bill Hayden, so he is hardly likely to be a great supporter of our side. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the biggest problem with the third referendum question is, what on earth is the point of it? Why is it important that the existence of local government should be explicitly recognised in the Constitution?

The question which will be put to the electors begins to answer these questions. Like all the other questions, it is dishonestly and misleadingly framed. The electorate will be asked whether it approves of a proposed law `to alter the Constitution to recognise local government'.
In itself, this is totally meaningless and anodyne, and it would seem to have no other function but to cater to the vanity of local government representatives and officials.
This is not my quote, but the quote of Mr McGuinness. He continues:
But the actual amendment proposed to the Constitution says rather more.

The new section 119A to be added reads: `Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State'.
The first thing we notice about this that it is far more than simple `recognition' of local government. It will if this proposal is passed-
which is unlikely-
be mandatory for the State to set up systems of elected local government bodies regardless of their own wishes.

I emphasise: regardless of their own wishes. Of course while the Government is placating local government with this sort of question it is taking away other benefits. It does not mean that there even will be local government; it does not say what sort of local government there will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—Yes, rubbish. We will have rubbish. Seeing that the honourable senator has called it rubbish I will quote from the Australian newspaper of 2 August 1988. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment provides no definition of local government or local government bodies, which means that, if there is litigation, definitions will have to be constructed by the courts. And it fails to provide machinery for the enforcement of the new section of the Constitution if a State ignores it or appears to ignore it.

Professor Winterton carries on to something else. So if it is rubbish that is Professor Winterton saying that it is rubbish. Getting back to the government, it could be government by an administrator or by a government dominated board. It could be local government by an amalgamation of several shires with no common interest. Amalgamating small shires with a common interest can be an advantage. An amalgamation of a lot of shires with no common interests is a great disadvantage. If Senator Powell has ever been in local government she should know that. This could reach such proportions that it will achieve the region proportions Prime Minister Whitlam was looking for many years ago. It could lead to the eventual elimination of State governments.

If the honourable senator does not agree with this she should show me where the protection is indicated. It could result in the same situation as the Minister for Local Government in Western Australia found himself in. He had put a few worthwhile amendments in the local government Bill, but it interfered with boundaries and interfered with ward representation within the boundaries. It does not give protection against dismissal as has happened under Labor governments in New South Wales; in Melbourne, I believe; and, as I have already said, in Western Australia. There is no guarantee of funding. This so-called recognition will open the way for local government control from Canberra. Senator Tate conceded that in the Senate, if I remember rightly. What a situation: being controlled from Canberra rather than from one's own capital city and I already prefer not to be controlled from my own State capital city.

Local government is already recognised in most State constitutions. Having been told that our side of politics does not care for local government, honourable senators will remember that the Fraser Government gave local government 2 per cent of personal income tax revenue. This was wrecked by this Government. It set up the Australian bicentennial road development program but this Government interfered with this when it indexed the 2c per litre on fuel and then kept the rest for itself. We formed an advisory council but this Government did away with it. What else did it do? In the last four years it has reduced local government road funding by 40 per cent and so it goes on. The way the Government carries on one may be excused for thinking that it owns the money in Treasury, just like some banks.

Under a Labor Government proposal Canberra will dictate to remote areas how they spend their money-that is, if they have any. So with recognition, if there should be such an unlikely result, where will we stand? As I have said before, we do not know where we will stand. I have already told honourable senators that local government councils do not speak for all ratepayers and all electors. I have already mentioned Peter Kyle and the work he has done but, as I say, he represents only 20 local government councils out of 139 in Western Australia. One can hardly claim that a certain number of councils amongst that small 20 represent the thinking of local government in Western Australia. I conclude with a quotation from the Perth Sunday Times of 28 August 1988. Under the headline `The answers: no, no, no-and why?', the article stated:
Like the road to hell, the path to constitutional reform in Australia is paved with good intentions.
This proposal probably has good intentions. The article continued:

If politicians would say what they mean and mean what they say, the journey would be a lot easier than it has proved over the years. Sadly, that is not the case. There has been a lot of double-talk about the propositions in next Saturday's referendums, and some of them are more notable for what they omit than for what they state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has heard two Opposition senators speak on this matter. To take up the point that was raised first by the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), certainly those Opposition members have failed to convince me that the matter of public importance is logical when it speaks of an empty but dangerous proposal for local government. What Opposition arguments have convinced me about is the old saying that an empty vessel makes most noise. That certainly has been true of the two Opposition speakers we have heard so far in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: One or two of the comments made so far in the debate should be noted. Senator Panizza asked Senator Reynolds about the standing of the Liberal representatives she quoted. It will interest the Senate to note that Jim Mooney, President of the Municipal Association in Tasmania, was a former frontbench Liberal member of Parliament in Tasmania. At the time he was in Parliament under Max Bingham's leadership he was regarded as the third-ranking Liberal Party frontbencher. Therefore, to say that he has no great standing in the Liberal Party is stretching it a little.

Both Opposition speakers spent the first four or five minutes of their speeches telling the Senate about their wonderful exploits and all they had done for local government. In view of some of their comments in this place, they ought not seek re-election. They went in for a fair amount of breast beating about their exploits, but clearly they have forgotten how they reached this place and the people who supported them. Judging by the nonsense we have heard in this debate so far, they are no longer looking to the interests of local government. It is significant to note that-no matter how many interjections asked for it-not once was a local government authority quoted by either of those two speakers. They quoted the views of journalists and pulled various furphies out of the woodwork, but not once did we hear a quotation from anyone in local government. I suggest that those honourable senators should go back and talk to people in local government again instead of talking to themselves.

We have heard a good deal of scaremongering about possible legal action. That falls into the same category as all the scaremongering on the other three referendum questions. What takes the cake in this debate-it falls into the same category as the matter of public importance and has certainly caused great confusion-is Senator Calvert's statement, quoting a number of authorities, that if this referendum is passed State governments will lose their power. He made that point on a couple of occasions during his speech. I admit to being a little confused about that. On 31 May 1988 in the Senate, Senator Calvert when speaking to the Bill accused the Government of changing certain words in the Constitution Commission's recommendations. He went on to say that enshrinement of local government in the Constitution would only make the powers of the States stronger. I do not understand that argument and I am sure that at some stage Senator Calvert will be able to explain what he means. Perhaps I will be more confused if he does.

The Opposition has been putting forward a convoluted and hopeless argument on this matter which is no more than simple scaremongering. Coming from the area I do, which is very close to the area from which Senator Calvert comes, I found it extraordinary to read the wording of his matter of public importance. It is true, as Senator Calvert said, that he is an ex-warden of Clarence and for some 12 years served on the Clarence Council. With that sort of record, he must now be regarded as the great deserter. The Clarence Council decided to support the Yes proposition. The area from which Senator Calvert comes takes in the city of Hobart, Glenorchy and Kingborough-some of the major local council areas in Tasmania. The Lord Mayor of Hobart, Alderman Doone Kennedy, is on public record as saying that her council supports the Yes case unequivocally, as is the Mayor of Glenorchy, David Shields. Yet in this Senate an ex-warden of Clarence, Senator Calvert, now that he is outside the council, seeks to put forward matters which take the opposite direction to the wishes of people in local government in the area that he comes from.

Senator Reynolds has already quoted from a letter from the Kingborough Council. I remind honourable senators of some parts of that letter from the Council Clerk, Mr Doyle. In that letter of 6 June, Mr Doyle said:

The Kingborough Council firmly supports the Municipal Association of Tasmania's view that the amendment is a realistic and appropriate recognition of the role of local government as the third sphere of government in Australia.

Council believes that there should be non-partisan support for the inclusion of this item in the referendum and in fact should be active support from both sides of Parliament for the `Yes' vote. It is disappointing that to date so few politicians have come out in support of recognition.

The arguments against the proposed referendum question were recently put to the annual conference of the Municipal Association of Tasmania by Senator Shirley Walters. The delegates present, who were representative of over 90 per cent of the councils in the State, soundly rejected the arguments.
One need say no more about the position put forward by Senator Calvert and whether he can claim any support at all from local government in Tasmania.

One can go a little further in considering where Senator Calvert gets his support for this matter. In the debate that has taken place on this matter in Tasmania one may well ask, `Where have Senator Calvert's Liberal colleagues and his State colleagues gone?' The only one I have noticed running around the countryside with any fervour on this question is Senator Shirley Walters. I give her credit for that for she has been out campaigning strongly. The only other Liberal member who has been game to admit that he does not support the decision of the coalition has been Bruce Goodluck. Bruce Goodluck was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 May 1988 as follows:
I was just being consistent with local government. I was a former warden of a municipality, and I pledged my support.

I remind honourable senators that he was a former warden of Clarence, the same municipality of which Senator Calvert claims, with some pride, to be the former warden. At least Bruce Goodluck, to give him his due, is prepared to stand up and not be stood over by the hit men in the National Party.

We wonder what the real reasons are for the attitude that is being displayed by Senator Calvert. He admitted earlier that he did not have much experience in politics. Perhaps he looked at the numbers and thought, `Maybe in another 20 years we may be in government. If I am prepared to speak up on these matters and be seen to be supporting people, maybe I'll get a ministry'.

The reason the conservative parties are supporting a No vote on this proposal is very simple. Everybody who has spoken to reasonable people in the Liberal Party knows that the Party made a decision to support a Yes vote-and the reasonable Liberals made no secret of this fact-but when the coalition parties met, the Liberal Party was clearly told by the National Party once again that if it did not support the No vote-(Quorum formed)

Let us have a closer look at the support in Tasmania for the coalition position on this referendum question. Of the 19 lower House members and eight or nine upper House members who are on the Liberal Party secret list, only the Premier has indicated some support for it. We ought to analyse the Premier's support. He has suddenly discovered that the recognition of local government should be included in the State Constitution. He is a nice sort of a bloke to trust to do that. We know that he spent between $30,000 and $70,000 of Tasmanian taxpayers' money supporting the No campaign when the Liberals were running around the country complaining about the fact that people in the Labor Party might be spending money on a campaign.

Let us examine further what the Premier did-that great protector of the rights of local government. If people have been to Tasmania recently they may have seen that abomination the Sheraton Hotel, which was built on the waterfront. In April 1985 the Premier rushed legislation through parliament. Section 6 of that legislation removed the right in the by-laws of the Hobart City Council for that Council to have any say at all about the siting of that hotel. Section 9 of that legislation required the licensing board to license that hotel, regardless of whether it complied with the Licensing Act. that is the sort of support we have from the Premier of Tasmania and the Liberal Party in Tasmania for local government. Senator Calvert purports to represent the views of people in local government and the Liberal Party in Tasmania. It is just a joke!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to follow Senator Devereux. He has actually found the energy to speak out on the local government issue. He has not been sighted in Tasmania speaking on this issue at all. He has left it all up to Senator Tate. It is a measure of the importance of this Government's retreat on this issue that it has had to stir Senator Devereux to talk about this issue. Senator Devereux's argument fell flat, as the argument will fall flat on Saturday. Senator Devereux should not talk about the National Party rolling people; he is a living monument to the National Party rolling people. With his stupidity and judgment he has led his unionists down the wrong path.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to a couple of comments made by Senator Reynolds. She, of course, spoke with her usual platitudes and rhetoric. It is always pleasing to hear Senator Reynolds, but she was too embarrassed to tackle the real issue-the financing of local government. That is the substance of the issue and that is what the Government is really concerned about.
I am pleased to support my colleagues Senator Panizza and Senator Calvert in the debate on the matter of public importance, which reads:
The need to oppose Labor's empty but dangerous proposal for local government by voting no to the third referendum.

The third referendum question that will be put to the people on Saturday is like the other three questions. The propositions read quite well and, on first impression, a voter may wonder why anyone should take a No stance on the matter. That is the extent of the very fraudulent wording of the referendum questions. It is one that has, no doubt, hoodwinked many councils. All four propositions have been fraudulently put to the people.

Paddy McGuinness, a reporter for the Sun-Herald, could hardly be described as one who writes in favour of any of the strong stances the Liberal and National parties have taken in the past. But this may be the only case in which I could quote him supporting our stance. He said:

The more I have studied and analysed the referendum proposals over the past couple of months, the more appalled I have become at the sheer dishonesty of them. I really wonder about the Government's intentions-they are either stupid or deeply cynical and contemptuous of the Australian people.

I would say to Mr McGuinness that it is the latter: the Government is cynical and contemptuous of the Australian people. I do not think it is stupid; it is contemptuous. The Government has not placed before the people its full and true intentions on this matter. It has not spelt out that there will be 33 changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a hidden agenda.

—There is a hidden agenda. There will be 33 changes to the Constitution-nine deletions, 20 new clauses, and four clauses will be tampered with to effectively change them. It is not just four motherhood questions; it is 33 changes to our Constitution. Like all the other questions, question 3, concerning the so-called recognition of local government, is a plan to fundamentally change the Federal system of government that is upheld in our Constitution. There is no doubt that when the Opposition first took its stance and recommended a No vote on this matter the tide was against us, but we have been proven now to be correct. We have been able to sell our case with great confidence. I have every confidence that this Saturday there will be a majority No vote for question No. 3 and in a majority of the States. That is because we have been able to go out and openly, honestly and effectively campaign on this matter. So for this Government's information, if it cares to listen, the reason is that the majority of Australians believe in our federal system as laid down in our 1901 Constitution. The Government will get that message clearly this Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that a large number of councils now oppose question No. 3. Certainly a greater number of councils which may have originally supported question No. 3 have now gone into a neutral mode and are now saying nothing. There is now a deathly silence with respect to question No. 3 because many of those councils have finally woken up to what this question really means. They see it for what it means.

TALK.START.PARA: —She ought to resign.

—If she does not resign after Saturday, I am quite sure that she will be given the big shove. That has been well reported already. At best, question No. 3 is a self-indulgent exercise by some town clerks and council officers; at worst, it is a legal nightmare that is bound to lead councils into an array of High Court challenges over what is the definition of `a system of local government'. The legal bill for those challenges will be completely funded by the ratepayers. The words of former Chief Justice Sir Henry Gibbs are a guide to the legal minefield that really does lie ahead if the Yes case is successful. Sir Henry Gibbs has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one cannot safely assume that any general provision will have no more than a symbolic effect. One can understand how some may feel that a constitutional provision recognising the existence of local government may in time prove to be the nether millstone on which the power of the States will be ground exceedingly small; the upper stone, the Commonwealth power, being held firmly in place.

There is no doubt that there are many constitutional lawyers in this country who are rubbing their hands with glee, hoping that the Yes case will succeed. However, it will be the ratepayers who will ultimately pay for any High Court challenges that local government may take up on this matter, and it will be our federal system that will suffer.

It should be said that in my own State of Victoria the only council, initially, that really wanted this question to succeed was the Melbourne City Council, the council on which I served as a councillor until only three weeks ago. It really was the Melbourne City Council that ultimately spent the time and the money on reports and lobbied the Minister to include this question in the referendum. It was the Melbourne City Council that convinced the Municipal Association of Victoria (MAV) to support its claim. In fact, the MAV really only supported the Melbourne City Council on this matter because it was trying to keep the Melbourne City Council in the fold. At that time the Melbourne City Council was very disgruntled with the MAV, and at the time it seemed like a way of pleasing the Melbourne City Council and keeping it in the fold. That is the case in Victoria, but I have absolutely no doubt that there is a similar situation in other States.

Referendum question No. 3 has been nothing more than a capital city push for so-called constitutional recognition. Many of the MAV members now openly reject the original stance of the organisation that was in favour of question No. 3. Certainly, most of them have not attempted to levy their ratepayers to pay for the Yes vote fighting fund. Of course, the capital city councils have a self-interest in this matter. Their interest relates to the sacking of councils by State governments. That is quite clear, and I do not think that they even hide that fact. The capital city councils see this referendum question as nothing more than an attempt to challenge the power of the State governments to dismiss a city council. They really only wish to gain stronger ground with respect to their old sparring partners, the State governments. So those councils are willing to tinker with the Federal Constitution and change its fundamental purpose, and commit ratepayers' funds to achieve this political end. Rather, it should be noted that the way a council can show its strength is through the ballot box. History shows that this is a very potent check on any State government that may choose to dismiss a city council unjustly.

The sacking of the Melbourne City Council in 1982, just prior to a State election, became an election issue and I have no doubt that it added to the defeat of the then State government. Similarly, the 1987 sacking of the Sydney City Council, which occurred just prior to an election, became an election issue. I have no doubt that that sacking added to the reasons for the defeat of the then Unsworth Government. There are many other examples where a State government has attempted to ride roughshod over a council and has been turned back by an electoral backlash. In my own State of Victoria the most celebrated case was when John Cain attempted to enforce amalgamations in 1986. As I travel around Victoria I increasingly see the low priority that Labor governments, both State and Federal, place on local government. No form of words set down in this referendum question will cover up that fact. That is the particular area that Senator Reynolds never bothered to tackle at all.

I particularly refer to the shire of Kowree, which happens to be in western Victoria. Its main township of Edenhope has a population of 800. I had the privilege of visiting Edenhope earlier this year and I found a township and district that had been absolutely sold out by the Cain Government. The new system of State grants introduced by the Cain Government left the Kowree shire with at least a 60 per cent cut in funds. There are no prizes for guessing that those funds will be directed back into the city councils from which the State Labor Government wishes to win favour in the forthcoming State election. The tragedy of the Kowree shire and the people of Edenhope is that they are in an isolated area of Victoria and there is no other option for the shire but for it to raise its rates. It cannot amalgamate; that is not a feasible option. Therefore, the shire has had to raise its rates this year and every year, just to survive, by a figure of 14 per cent-double the inflation rate. If that is an example of the State Government's priority for councils, then the Federal Government's is no different.

The May mini-Budget and subsequently the August Budget really showed perverse spending priorities towards local government. Road funding was cut by $50m, and since the Hawke Government was first elected road funding has been cut by 28 per cent in real terms. Overall funds to local government have been reduced from a 2 per cent share of income tax revenue to a 1.6 per cent share. The Government has now decided that it will even stop listening and talking to local government because it has abolished the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. So the Federal Government has failed local government in all areas of substance-in basic services like roads, in overall support funding, and in open communication with the Commonwealth. However, that is not just my opinion but also the opinion of the honourable member for Reid, Mr Tom Uren. An article in a local government magazine states:
Former Federal Minister for Local Government, Tom Uren, says he was concerned at the arrogance of the Executive Government for cutting funds to Local Government.

Mr Uren, commenting on the May Economic Statement, said in a press release that the Federal Government's cut to local government came at a time when substantial hardships were occurring in that sphere of Government.
The article also states:
He said he regretted making such a statement in public during the last days of the old Parliament House, but the arrogance of the Executive had left him no alternative.
It goes on:
Mr Uren said the bills would be guillotined within a strict timetable and would not give elected members time or the right to debate the merits or otherwise of the economic program.
It then states:
The Government has cut Local Government funding under the Act by 4.5 per cent in real terms this year.

And so it goes on. He had a lot to say. I say to Tom Uren about his concerns that the executive government, the Cabinet, has never consulted him, a man of great experience in local government. Why should it, when it is not even listening to local government? It has abolished the Local Government Advisory Council, so why would it listen to an old hack like him? No-one can deny that the belief of any Labor government is that local government should not exist in its current form. We are all aware that that is the philosophy of the Labor Government; let us not kid ourselves. The Government is not interested in local government as it stands today. Rather, the Government's view is towards regionalism. If the Government were honest enough the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) would have said that during the debate. This regionalism is a form of local government attempted by Gough Whitlam and rejected by the people. It is a form of local government attempted by the Cain Government when it set the wheels in motion in attempting forced amalgamation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has put forward this motion today. The key part of its proposal is that the question to be put before the people is empty and at the same time dangerous. That would seem to be a strange contradiction. How can something be dangerous but at the same time empty? Well, there is much more to this proposal than poor use of language. Firstly, why does the Opposition claim that the proposal is empty? It claims that constitutional recognition of local government is meaningless. This shows just what a sham the Opposition is. After 200 years of European settlement, 1988 is indeed a year in which some reflection needs to be made about where we have come from as a society and where we are going. As a consequence the Government has put to the people some suggestions which indeed should be seriously considered for constitutional inclusion. Local government, I believe, is one such item.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of local government in Australia is of paramount importance. The Australian public has been well served by local government in all parts of Australia and has come to recognise local government as an integral part of the community. Much that goes on in a community revolves around local government and it is seen as a focal point in a particular community. Of course, the delivery of vital and essential services is carried out at the local government level. It must not be forgotten that services to the public such as road infrastructure, waste removal, all levels of building surveying, planning and health services are tailored to suit particular communities and are carried out by that arm of government best able to deliver local services-local government.

In our bicentennial year it is most appropriate that this essential role be recognised. Suitable recognition for the meaningful and real role that local government plays should be made constitutionally. Our Constitution is a priceless document which encapsulates the rules by which we are governed. It therefore is obvious that in our Constitution the role of local government needs to be clearly recognised. However, what the Opposition tells us is that such recognition is empty, that local government is not worthy of constitutional recognition. This Government believes that it is essential that people vote yes on Saturday for question three. Such a vote will mean, firstly, that a system of local government elected and accountable to the people will be guaranteed in each State; and secondly, that no local council can be permanently replaced by State-appointed administrators who are not chosen by the local citizens and ratepayers. Thirdly, recognising local authorities in the Constitution will guarantee a decentralised system of government.

What the Opposition has been saying during this referenda campaign is that it is good enough for the States, but not the Commonwealth, to grant the recognition local government deserves. The Government does not believe that this is sufficient. State constitutions can be altered simply by an Act of Parliament, so what guarantees can the Opposition offer local government that it will not be abolished? The answer: none at all. It is the Opposition's approach to this question which is empty. It believes that local government can be denied rightful recognition in our Constitution and that local government will lie down and not complain.

Not all Liberals, though, feel so strongly about denying recognition of local government. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) appears to have changed some of his views in the course of the year. He has not changed his attitude just to immigration but also to the recognition of local government. In a letter to the Ryde Municipal Council on 10 February this year Mr Howard stated:
I fully support Council's request that a chapter should be inserted in the Constitution dealing with local government.

It is important to stress that passage. It appears that something has happened since February this year because Mr Howard obviously does not fully support the Council's request any more. What has happened? Councillor Peter Kyle, President of the Australian Local Government Association, has shed some light on this question:

Although there was strong support within the Coalition parties for the local government question, it appears that a deliberate strategy has been adopted to oppose the package of four questions, regardless of their individual merits. This attitude is an insult to the intelligence of the Australian public.

I must confess that I see some merit in the opinion of Mr Kyle. It would appear that the coalition has developed a deliberate strategy to oppose all referenda questions regardless of merit. (Quorum formed) It also appears that the coalition is prepared to insult the intelligence of the Australian public by the mixture of scare tactics and rubbish which it offers as justification for its actions.
Sallyanne Atkinson, Liberal Lord Mayor of Brisbane, stated on 26 May:
I know constitutional recognition is not supported by my Federal colleagues but I represent the people of Brisbane and local government and I will continue to do so.

So, there we have it clearly stated-Ms Atkinson will continue to represent the people of Brisbane and local government and support constitutional recognition of local government. Other Liberals also have called into question the curious way in which the Opposition appears to be handling this issue. Mr Ian Wilson, MHR, member for Sturt in my home State of South Australia, abstained from voting on two of the referenda Bills when they came before the other place. He made his position clear, and that of many other members of the Opposition. In an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program AM, Mr Wilson was asked why he abstained. I quote from a transcript of that program:
Wilson: Because I support giving constitutional recognition to local government and I was not prepared to vote against giving of the people the opportunity to vote on that question.
Stuart Heather: Even though your leader, Mr Howard says that, that particular proposal was totally meaningless.
Wilson: I don't believe it is totally meaningless. It's suggested that it's a token. Well tokens can be real tokens and have great significance.
In that interview Mr Wilson went on to make some more telling points. On the referenda questions as a whole, the transcript states:

Wilson: Well, you have to remember that in the first instance, the shadow ministry recommended a no-no, yes-yes vote on the four referenda. In other words the shadow ministry was advocating in the first instance that we support the rights referendum.
Heather: Are you disappointed that others didn't join you, didn't put what you're saying were their principles, didn't put those first.
Wilson: Yes I am.

I must say that I agree with Mr Wilson that it is a pity that principles did not come first in Opposition ranks. However, if we look at the contemporary immigration debate we see that many Liberals are becoming restive on that issue, too. It appears that the temporary leader of the coalition forces will do almost anything so as not to upset his National Party mates.

On the referenda question it is the same. The National Party is consistently paranoid about hidden agendas and some of its debates on this and on the other matters obviously reflect some strange views of the world. Mr Howard, it appears, is much happier appeasing the Nationals than his own. Well, that is for him and the Liberals to work out. But the problem in the meantime is that an issue as important as constitutional recognition of local government may be sacrificed at the altar of incompetent leadership.
Mr Wilson again shows us the problem. I quote again from the same interview on why other members of the coalition did not follow his lead:
Heather: Why didn't they?

Wilson: Well that's a matter for them to decide but I think on matters of constitutional reform people should be looking at the issues on their merits and as matters of principle in the interests of the Australian people for the present and for the future and that they should be influenced by the more simplistic approach of contemporary party politics. And there was a view amongst some of my colleagues that it's easier to defeat the most objectionable of the referendum proposals, mainly the first one that would reduce the terms of the Senate to a single term rather than two terms of the House of Representatives by having a no vote on all proposals.
Heather: So as far as the Opposition's policies are concerned, have the last 2 referendum questions been sacrificed to make sure that the first 2 are defeated?
Wilson: That is an interpretation that can be placed on the action taken . . .
Heather: Is that your interpretation?

Wilson: Yes in a way, because it has been our policy to give political guarantees, constitutional guarantees for trial by jury, political guarantees for freedom of religion and political guarantees in respect of acquisition only on just and fair terms.
Heather: So is now the Liberal Party going back on its own principles.
Wilson: It's certainly going back on the policies announced at the previous election in the eyes of some of trying to defeat the first referendum proposal about the 4 year terms for the Senate.

Of course, the Opposition is desperate to get some credibility for its stand. Of the many letters that have come into my office on this question from local government, all have asked for my support to see that this referendum question is passed next Saturday. I noticed that Joy Baluch, Mayor of Port Augusta-a previous coalition candidate-in my home State of South Australia, has objected to Opposition claims that the Port Augusta council supports its stand. Quite clearly, local government is enraged at the opportunistic way in which the coalition has gone about this question. The Opposition stands simply for cheap political capital, and I am sure that the Australian public will see through it. In the meantime, it is the Opposition which is empty and it is the policies of John Howard whilst clutching the straws that are dangerous.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill is to reduce the quorum of the House of Representatives from one-third to one-fifth. On 9 December 1987 the House of Representatives resolved to endorse the principle of a reduction in the quorum for that House from one-third to one-fifth as recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure in its report Days and hours of sitting and the effective use of the time of the House. Until now, the quorum of the House of Representatives has been laid down by section 39 of the Constitution which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Until the Parliament otherwise provides, the presence of at least one-third of the whole number of the members of the House of Representatives shall be necessary to constitute a meeting of the House for the exercise of its powers.

The object of this Bill is to provide otherwise. The effect of the Bill is to reduce the quorum to 30 members or 20 per cent of the membership of the House of Representatives. Members have many demands on their time-as Senator Vanstone obviously has if she is leaving the chamber and is not interested in this speech-and it is generally accepted that they need to spend more time on electorate and family responsibilities. That objective can be achieved only if the time of the House, when it is sitting, is used effectively.

While the House is sitting, members have many calls on their time in addition to chamber responsibilities. These include Cabinet and Cabinet committee work for Ministers, parliamentary and party committee work for all members, correspondence and visitors. The need for one-third of members to answer quorum calls is an harassment of members discharging legitimate duties outside the chamber.

The quorum requirement cannot of itself affect the number of members who remain in the chamber during a debate. This is determined by the nature and quality of the debate. Lowering the quorum will not affect overall attendance in the chamber. Reducing the size of the quorum and perhaps consequentially the number of quorum calls members feel it necessary to make, will allow more members effective use of their time outside the chamber. Although quorum calls do not take up a great amount of time in total, they may take up critical time and there is additional time lost through the disruption of activities which must be resumed after the quorum call.

The Bill is a significant step towards ensuring that the time of the House is not taken up with procedural trivia when it should be directed towards consideration of the major issues affecting the nation. As the Committee noted in its report, the rationale behind the quorum requirement is to ensure that the number of members present in the House and voting on any decision is reasonably substantial. A 20 per cent requirement is substantial. It was so considered by the previous Government when it introduced Bills in 1970 and 1971 to reduce the quorum to one-fifth. To be consistent with the intent of the Bill, I commend it to the chamber.
