TALK.START.PARA: —To continue my contribution on the Industrial Relations Bill, I was talking about the Menzies years and the way people who found themselves in front of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, when in dispute, were not asked why they were there or about the issue, the merit of any dispute or the cause-that was never considered. There was a rigid question, `Were you in dispute?'-regardless of the provocation. If it were so, people were in breach of the Act and could be fined-at that time $500-and each day was a separate breach. In some of those cases it was a question of industrial health and safety, when people's lives were at stake.

SPEECH.PARA: That sort of situation is long gone-and so it should be. It is interesting to note the legal action that was taken in the late 1950s by the boilermakers union, which questioned the constitutional right of the Commission to make awards and then penalise people if those awards were breached. The High Court of Australia found in favour of the boilermakers and said that constitutionally that should not have been done. All of the thousands of pounds in fines that were paid over that time were never refunded. The Commission and the Court were reconstituted under new legislation that enabled them to use those penalties.

The development took place in the trade union movement generally and amongst workers who were not trade unionists, in opposition and objection to the harsh way the penalties were used. They were used to prevent people from taking part in legitimate struggles, at a time when many employers did not want to negotiate because all they needed to do was run to the court and get penalties against unions. They felt negotiations were unnecessary. The struggle built up until there was a 24-hour stoppage throughout the nation and the name Clarrie O'Shea was written into the history of this country. That did not happen overnight; it happened because of the way people felt they were denied their rights by use of that legislation.

I say to this chamber and to anybody who wants to consider this matter that the trade union movement is not there to aggrandise any person but is there because of a real need and real reason for workers and labour to be represented. No force in this country, legal or otherwise, will create a position where workers will not be able to struggle. If a confrontation develops it will not be the workers who will lose. I do not say that to be confrontationist or provocative; I say it in a very definite way about how people feel. People in the Opposition and those amongst employer groups talk about personal contracts. I want to go back to the situation we had probably 100 years ago. I would like to quote to the Senate what a person named Keir Hardie, the first Labour member of the House of Commons in Great Britain, said when he remembered his days as a young person. I will quote from a book about his life:

Those were the days of unemployment and no insurance pay for the out-of-work, and at the age of eight years and nine months, young Keir Hardie was sent out as a baker's boy to add to the family income. He was keenly sensitive and the memories of the baker's shop remained with him for life. Fifty years after, he described how he was sacked:

``I sometimes think if the ministers of our churches and those who profess to be workers of Christ only realised all that it meant to be poor under our present system, they would bestir themselves to find out and remove the cause. Without any egotism, let me recall this incident from my own boyhood.

`The year 1866 was nearing its close. Owing to a lock-out in the shipbuilding yards on the Clyde, my father had been out of employment for nearly six months. The funds of the Union were so exhausted that the benefits were reduced to 1/6 and 2/- a week. I was the only breadwinner, being employed by a high-class baker in Lancefield Street, Glasgow, for 3/6 a week. My hours were from 7 a.m. to 7.30 p.m., 12 1/2 hours each day. I was the eldest of a family of three, and the brother next to me was down with fever, from which he never recovered, though his life dragged on for two years thereafter. As most of the neighbourhood had children, they feared coming into the house because of the danger of contagion, and my mother, who was very near her confinement, was in delicate health. It was the last week in the year.
Obviously, Christmas.

Father had been away for two or three days in search of work. Towards the end of the week, having been up most of the night, I got to the shop fifteen minutes late, and was told by the young lady in charge that if that occurred again I would be punished. I made no reply. I couldn't. I felt like crying. Next morning the same thing happened. I could tell why, but that was neither here nor there. It was a very wet morning, and when I reached the shop I was drenched to the skin, barefooted and hungry. There had not been a crust of bread in the house that morning.

But that was pay-day, and I was filled with hope. ``You are wanted upstairs by the master,'' said the girl behind the counter, and my heart almost stopped beating. Outside the dining-room door a servant bade me wait till `master had finished prayers.' (He was noted for his piety.) At length the girl opened the door, and the sight of that room is fresh in my memory even as I write, nearly fifty years after. Round the great mahogany table sat the members of the family, with the father at the top. In front of him was a very wonderful-looking coffee boiler, in the great glass bowl of which the coffee was bubbling. The table was loaded with dainties. My master looked at me over his glasses, and said in quite a pleasant tone of voice: ``Boy, this is the second morning you have been late, and my customers leave me if they are kept waiting for their hot breakfast rolls. I therefore dismiss you, and, to make you more careful in the future, I have decided to fine you a week's wages. And now you may go!'' '

Some people want us to return to that situation. I do not accuse all employers of being capable of that sort of treatment, but I certainly accuse some of them of wanting to return to those days when they had total control.

A book has been written which puts in perspective in general terms the way in which many employers look at people as workers. That book is entitled Worker's Control and was edited by Ken Coates and Tony Topham. Its cover reads:
Know thy enemy.
He does not care what colour you are provided you work for him;
he does not care how much you earn provided you earn more for him;
he does not care who lives in the room at the top provided he owns the building;
he will let you say what you like against him provided you do not act against him;
he sings the praises of humanity but knows machines cost more than men;
bargain with him he laughs and beats you at it;
challenge him and he kills;
sooner than lose the things he owns he will destroy the world.

Those are just a couple of messages that I give honourable senators who think that trade unions are built on what happens today, who do not have an understanding of the past and who would like to return to the master and servant situation.

If we look at what has happened in recent times, there has been the experience of the metal workers unions which sought a supplementary payment to enable people on lower wages to receive an amount nearer to the going rate in the industry. Employers opposed the idea of a supplementary payment and said that they could not afford it. The Commission at the time said, `Those people who say they can't afford it will be given exemptions and they will be given an opportunity to show the Commission why they can't afford to pay it'. In the final wash-up, not one of them was prepared to argue that they were not able to pay it. Again, this was a situation in which people were not fair dinkum. They were trying to maximise their profits and had no concern for their workers.

Let us look at the current attitude of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to the restructuring of awards and the way in which labour relations are operating at present. The metal trades industry award is a very fine example. Hundreds of classifications are being reduced to a very small number of about 10 or 15. Ralph Willis, in his speech, stated:

More importantly perhaps than either of these changes has been the attitudinal change of the parties. Although there are some spectacular exceptions on both sides, there is now, in general, a much more constructive, cooperative attitude by the parties than previously prevailed.
I believe that attitudes are tremendously important. We can do what we like about upgrading technology, but attitudes are tremendously important because life is about people, not machines.

Senator Hill talked about flexibility and multiskilling. I agree with that point. Indeed, it was the trade unions which introduced into the debate in recent times the idea of multiskilling, of skilling vertically and horizontally, in order to make work more interesting for people and make them more valuable as a labour resource for the employer. They also talked about career paths so that people do not remain in one job all their lives, without the opportunity to be given credit for skills that they have developed and qualifications that they have, so that they can move upwards into areas of higher technical skill, for which they would be paid additional rates, which would enhance their feeling of being useful human beings and, obviously, make them more attractive as employees.

People talk about productivity bargaining and the need to bargain at the enterprise level. In fact, the metal unions first introduced the idea of productivity bargaining in the 4 per cent second tier wage increase case, which involved an increase of 4 per cent to employees who were prepared to, and could, bring about improvements in productivity within the enterprise, whether it be by way of better management or changed work practices at the workplace. In many cases that was done fairly quickly and effectively. However, employers were much slower off the mark in understanding what this offered them and what gains could be made collectively by both labour and capital. When some of them realised what opportunities were available, of course, they got greedy and grasping, and some friction developed. But in the main the bargains were made and kept.

There is also this attitude by members of the Opposition and those whom they represent: `Let's get away from the big unions'. One of the obvious difficulties for trade union members in having direct negotiations with management without the assistance of the unions-negotiation at the plant level-is the possible inequity in that management can afford professional advice and has access to advice through its business associations while members of the work force may not be able to draw on the same sort of expertise. Laurie Carmichael, the Assistant Secretary of the ACTU, put it as follows:

The trade unions represent that professional advice to the workforce and to deny the workforce the right to that trade union representation is to deny equity and to confirm the inequality of power in the workplace.

Senator Knowles referred to Australia Reconstructed and was very disparaging about it. She said that it should be entitled `Australia Unconstructed'-I think that was the term that she used. Of course, she is very careful not to read the report. It is a worthwhile document and it makes some very important points. Recommendation 2.3 shows even-handedness, and an effort to get to a proper basis for discussion, at least where one has an agreed position. It states:
The Government, ACTU, BCA and CAI should liaise to build a common data base to facilitate wage negotiations, particularly with respect to non-national adjustments.
That means that participants work out what the figures are and reach some agreement as to fact so that they are not talking about two different sets of figures. The recommendation continues:
The make-up of such a data base would need to be both comprehensive and acceptable to all parties. This would involve:
(a) extensive tripartite discussion with respect to the composition and timing of Australian Bureau of Statistics' surveys; and
(b) the establishment of agreed procedures on collection and compilation, by one or other of the parties, of individual sets of statistics relevant to industry and enterprise level wage negotiations.
That is an even-handed approach; it is tripartite; and it is an attempt to reach a proper basis for understanding by people.

Senator Hill talked about getting away from conflict. That is what the trade unions are all about these days. However, I must say that I cannot stand here and suggest that all in the trade union movement are perfect; that they are all totally honest; that they all understand the complicated questions that have to be answered and are prepared to make the changes necessary not only on behalf of their members but on behalf of the community as a whole. Many people within the trade union movement-and more and more people are joining this group-are beginning to understand that we have to look at the common good but on the basis of equality in negotiation and on the basis that, if one agrees to changes and one agrees to contribute to the betterment of everyone, one has to get some guarantees from the other side that people will not be exploited and robbed.

Senator Boswell, bless his heart, was involved in a little exercise some time ago-I did not think he was capable of playing the role of a conciliator, but more strength to him; I hope that he does it again-being instrumental in getting the waterside workers in Mackay and one of the stevedoring people together. They now have a joint company in which the waterside workers operate without supervision; it is totally worker controlled. They have reduced the cost of freight and increased the volume of freight across the wharf, and the stevedoring company and the Mackay branch of the waterside workers are making a reasonable profit. We have always talked about the need to look after people in retirement, and the unions have been responsible for bringing that about.

In closing, one of the most important aspects of this legislation concerns amalgamations. If unions go about amalgamations in a proper way, if they create a structure within each union that guarantees involvement and proper democracy at all levels of membership, the allegation that because they are large and bureaucratic they would not be able to look after their membership in that way would not arise. Enterprise unions would be a total failure but there is nothing wrong with enterprise negotiations that take into account the overall role of a union on behalf of its members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to participate in this cognate debate on the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 and the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988. It is likely to be a long debate. Senator Chaney, in his opening remarks, made the comment that the House of Representatives had devoted a mere 3 1/2 hours to this vitally important question. Judging by the speakers list for the second reading debate and the more than 50 amendments of which we have been advised so far, this chamber is likely to debate these Bills for several days.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats acknowledge this legislation as the beginning of a new era in industrial relations. Industrial relations will always be contentious. It is an area where, even though the two principal sides, the employers and the employees, are likely to have widely divergent views at their extremes-and we certainly hear the extreme position often in this place-most participants in the system must realise that eventually the economy cannot function without essential compromise in this critical area. Industrial relations is a business of compromise and I sense that we will have to be involved in a great deal of compromise in the passage of this legislation as well. As a document outlining the intended parameters of industrial relations in this new era in Australia, this legislation could not possibly please all unions or all employers.

Few things in life are perfect-especially legislation, I think we would agree-so we in the Australian Democrats do not expect this legislation to be perfect at this stage, or probably at any stage. We expect that it will evolve over time just as the 1904 Act that it is to replace evolved over time and after some 80-odd amendments. The Opposition has decided to move a plethora of amendments, only some of which, up until a few moments ago, we have seen. If accepted, these amendments would amount to a radical overhaul of industrial relations in this country towards a deregulated system in which sanctions and penalties would substantially increase the power of employers at the expense of unions. I think Senator Chaney and the Opposition would not contest that the effect of those 50 amendments would be to reverse dramatically the nature of the legislation. Apart from the industrial chaos into which Australia would be plunged, I believe that Senator Chaney would accept that it is quite unrealistic to expect that the Opposition's blueprint for industrial relations should pass into legislation while a Labor government is in power. So we in the Democrats simply see the proposing of 50 amendments as being a fairly opportunistic exercise whereby Senator Chaney and the Opposition will roll by this chamber and the Australian public what they see as the alternative blueprint-the other legislation. Perhaps Senator Chaney, as an industrial relations Minister or perhaps even as a Prime Minister, will be given the opportunity to introduce this legislation at some time in the future. We do not consider this to be the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not won a seat yet.
—That is true. I said at some time in the future. I did not suggest the near future.
—I think it is a very distant future, Senator.

—It could be a distant future, yes. There are those in the Liberal Party of Australia who are still prepared to speak against the ideologically driven extremism that members of the Opposition are continually espousing in more and more areas. On 26 April this year, in an article in the Melbourne Herald, the member for Goldstein, the Hon. Ian Macphee, who is a former coalition industrial relations Minister, contrasted the difference between the coalition and the Australian Labor Party in the industrial relations area in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: I frankly am in no doubt that the wages outcome which has been delivered so far by the Government could not have been achieved by a Coalition Government.

In that interview Mr Macphee praised the union movement for developing a more enlightened approach to wages growth through its participation in government consultative forums, and he argued that `you cannot suddenly change by slogan'. The Opposition's amendments are essentially based on its slogans, which we have heard for so long. They have some value as possible goals towards which we might move, but they do nothing to sustain the admirable industrial relations record achieved by this Government and acknowledged by Mr Macphee in that article.

John Beggs and Bruce Chapman of the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the Australian National University recently published a paper entitled `Industrial strikes still down 5 years later'. They found that, including the 1986 and 1987 data, the estimated reduction in strike activity during the accord period improved from a reduction of 62 per cent to a reduction of 82 per cent. They concluded:

The industrial relations improvements achieved between 1983 and 1985 have strengthened during 1986 and 1987. It seems that the previously seemingly inevitable structural trend increases in disputation over the period between 1964 and 1982 have been brought under control. It is important to recognize the extent of the improvement in the post-1983 era; yet still be mindful of the potential policies which further reduce strike levels.

The Opposition's amendments-I have said that there are in the vicinity of 50-are a prescription for increased industrial disputation and are in direct contrast to the extra object which the Opposition seeks to add to the objects of the Act; that is, `to encourage the growth, development, productivity and international competitiveness of Australian industry'. We must accept the fact that this Government has managed to achieve simultaneously a reduction in real wages and a reduction in industrial disputation. This contributes to our growth, development, productivity and international competitiveness. The thrust of most of the Opposition's amendments would be potentially to destroy this considerable achievement. I am sure that Senator Chaney will not be surprised that the Australian Democrats will therefore, in essence, be supporting the legislation as an adequate and responsible beginning to a new industrial relations system. I am also sure that many employers who have benefited from this era of falling real wages and lower levels of industrial disputation will welcome our decision to do so.

Honourable senators will remember that in July 1983 the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, having taken the advice of the National Labour Consultative Council, set up a committee comprising three distinguished Australians: one, an academic economist, Keith Hancock; another a prominent trade union leader, whose views have been lauded by the present Opposition leader, namely Charles Fitzgibbon; and third, a leading employers advocate of the current era, George Polites. This Committee was asked to conduct the first comprehensive review of the Federal system of industrial relations under the present Act. This Act was piloted through the Parliament by Alfred Deakin, of the old and genuine liberals, in 1904.

So between 1904 and 1985 there had not been a serious comprehensive review of the principal Act under which we resolved industrial disputation in this nation. Throughout the period between 1904 and 1983, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-the Act this Bill seeks to replace-has been the subject of an almost unending series of amendments which, to quote His Honour Mr Justice Deane of the High Court of Australia, has reduced the present Act to `an outmoded patchwork'. The legislation introduced into the Parliament in May 1987 and reintroduced in its current amended form in May 1988 has the basic support of the Australian Democrats for several reasons. First of all, it provides the scope for a further managed and measured freeing up of the industrial relations system which is not provided for by the extreme and confrontationist policies advocated by the coalition in its present Thatcherite mode. The second reason the Australian Democrats support in essence this legislation is that it retains the best features of the system of conciliation and arbitration which was developed back in 1904 and which initially served us well but increasingly has posed difficulties as it increasingly became the patchwork of amendments to which I referred earlier. The third reason we support it in essence is that it has been developed in consultation with the relevant industrial organisations. There has been considerable consultation in the process leading up to the tabling of this legislation in its present form in May of this year. It also reflects the advice of the Committee known as the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems to which I have just referred. It was a committee of experts appointed by the Government to review the Act. We consider it a reasonable and legitimate position for the Government to take in having formulated this legislation, to base the legislation essentially upon the recommendations of that eminent Committee.

It returns the law to a state of cohesion although it does have some inherent complexities. In that process of 80-odd amendments the law governing industrial relations in this country had lacked cohesion, had gradually spread and lacked an essential logic. One of the intentions of this Bill is to draw it back into a state of cohesion and indeed the intention of the second of the Bills which we are debating, namely the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988, is to transmit that new cohesiveness and to put it in place.

Firstly, while expressing basic support for both pieces of legislation, we acknowledge that much of what was controversial in the Bill of 1987, as well as some which ought not to have been, has been removed in the transition between the Bill of 1987 and the Bill of 1988 which we now have before us. Secondly, that the controversial material which remains was given an ample and prominent public hearing during the last Federal election campaign and has been the subject of further consultation with the industrial parties concerned. It was a healthy process that occurred during the campaign. There was the opportunity for the Opposition to take the more controversial aspects of the Bill, for the people to react and for that reaction to be taken into account by the Minister in redrafting the present Bill. We do not say that that process has totally been taken account of, but the opportunity did exist and the process did occur and that has been a healthy process.

The Australian Democrats will be moving some amendments, five in fact, around three essential principles. We will be moving some amendments of our own in areas in which we feel the Government has missed important opportunities for change such as to the collegiate system and to secret ballots; in which we have been heavily lobbied by responsible elements of the union movement in relation to these aspects of the Bill; and in which we believe the Government and the Opposition have both, not unexpectedly, taken extreme positions such as those in relation to amalgamations.

The Australian Democrats have held discussions with all of the major players in the industrial relations arena: the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU); the employer groups such as the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Chambers of Commerce and Manufacturing; and major employers such as Westpac Banking Corporations and Unilever Australia Ltd. The Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations, Senator Chaney, has consulted us about his amendments; we have had discussions with him progressively and of course with the Minister and his advisers. It is clear to us from these discussions that there is no agreement between these divergent groups on some of the major and most controversial aspects of the legislation and that no agreement is indeed possible under the present circumstances. The objective of the Australian Democrats is to get into place the best legislation that we can get there under the present circumstances. We see it as a starting point, we see it as a process of evolution and a process by which we move into the second era of industrial relations. As I said earlier, we do not expect perfection now-we probably do not expect perfection ever-but we see this as being a responsible and constructive start to this second era of industrial relations. That is why it is important to see this legislation and the recent national wage decisions of the Commission as part of an evolutionary process towards improving Australia's industrial relations.

There are several structural problems in the legislation. Union amalgamations are favoured by those who believe that there are too many unions in Australia-somewhere in the vicinity of 160 registered Federal unions. When we consider those registered under State jurisdiction the number rises to 300 or thereabouts. I am told that in Germany, for instance, there are 25 unions. Certainly 300 by any standard is an extraordinary number of unions and it creates difficulties. Some experts and participants view amalgamations as a way of reducing demarcation disputes and by reducing the number of registered unions. Their arguments point to fewer and bigger unions in the future. The formula that is inherent in this legislation of 3,000-the 3,000 figure which I will return to in detail in the committee stage-is aimed at reducing the number of unions at the Federal level to in the vicinity of 20.

Against this we have the leaders of the small unions who have approached us in strength. They claim to represent their members' interests better now than would be the case if they merged with bigger unions and so became bigger unions. They also argue that enforced amalgamations threaten the International Labour Organisation convention's guarantee of freedom of association. We in the Democrats have not heard anyone arguing for the registration of associations with one, two or three members: so all participants tend to agree that some figure has to be arrived at. At present the figure is 100, this legislation suggests 3,000, and the suggested figure in the 1987 Bill was 1,000. It is agreed that a cut-off figure has to be decided, and it is a question of where one draws the line. Obviously there will be argument on that topic and no doubt that argument will proceed in the next few days.

Some employers also argue against the amalgamation proposals because they support enterprise as opposed to industry based unions. It is our belief that the choice of either enterprise or industry based unions will evolve. It has been suggested to us by the Minister's advisers, and it strikes us as logical, that if we move towards, as this legislation hopes, a vertical union structure-in other words, an industrial structure-within that context we shall see signs, as we are already seeing signs, of enterprise agreements arrived at within the industry based, vertical structure. The transition from our present craft or horizontal structure to the vertical will not be easy. It may falter. It will have its problems. But we suggest that it is rational, it makes sense, and sooner or later within that context it will provide-we accept the Minister's advisers' argument-an opportunity for a context within which enterprise agreements may even flourish. We do not see the industry vertical structure as being in any way contrary to the needs of those who pursue the alternative model.

Another contentious issue is the extent of the powers of the new commission. Some employers have argued that the powers of the commission are too expansive and that trouble will flow from too broad a definition of the commission's powers. Employers complain that the commission that is born out of this legislation will be an even more all-embracing institution than the one that it is replacing and that the Bill undermines the possibility of a shift to the enterprise level. We are not convinced by that argument. It is interesting to note that in this context the two recent national wage case decisions have thrown wage increases back to a direct negotiation between employers and employees to implement productivity and restructuring trade-offs. It is that rationale that the recent wage judgment pursued: it was passed back and it was said `We trust you to negotiate and to talk'-in other words, to do precisely what this proposed legislation intends.

We also argue that this is likely to be the future path of the industrial relations scene. It is working at the moment because it has the imprimatur of the Commission. To reduce the powers of the Commission now and to throw all negotiations onto the employer and employee at the enterprise level would be a radical lurch away from the path that we have already travelled with some success recently. Such a radical move would endanger this success. It would destroy the current conciliatory attitude of the ACTU leadership and create industrial chaos which would undermine our international trading position. Surely an evolutionary process that is working is preferable to that.

It is also useful to remember that many who now complain that the Commission's foreseen powers will be too great have complained in the past that the Commission had had no teeth. In fact, they would seek to give the Commission more teeth by increasing the compliance provisions of the Act. This is another problem area to which we shall return in later stages of the debate. We detect an inconsistency in the arguments advanced to us by Opposition members.

It is not surprising that employers tend to regard existing compliance provisions as not good enough. It is similarly not surprising that unions regard the existing compliance procedures as too tough on unions. It is not surprising that compliance was a controversial area of the 1987 Bill. It is not surprising that the Government probably took the easy way out, whipped out the provisions and left the status quo. So far as we are concerned that is probably a reasonable starting point. Because we are evolutionists, we consider that we are moving forward into the second phase of industrial relations and, it is hoped, by a process of evolution rather than confrontation.

In the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill, to satisfy employers' demands, the Government proposed a new directions and injunctions process with higher monetary penalties for non-compliance. It also introduced a more efficient process for resolving secondary boycotts before sanctions were necessary. Potentially, that was the most controversial aspect of the 1987 legislation. I do not think it is irresponsible for the Government to have avoided that controversy at the beginning of the new stage. In fact, I think that it probably is quite responsible to say that if there are highly contentious issues, let us start in the best way we can, capitalise on the gains made, and take advantage of the goodwill that exists, because one does not see much goodwill in this arena. The Government can proceed from there to address the more controversial issues as we move down the line. The option of constant amendment, if the Opposition assumes government, is exactly the same option that has existed throughout the last 70 to 80 years of the previous legislation. That is the nature of the process. We are simply acknowledging the responsibility and positive potential of this legislation.

Some of the Opposition amendments-and there are approaching 50 amendments before us-are designed to introduce a compliance system which is heavily weighted towards employers. We do not believe that all employers would welcome this as the reaction of unions would create industrial chaos. Frankly, we believe that employers are among the greatest beneficiaries of what has been achieved in the last four to five years. It is the employers who have reaped the benefits of the period of relative industrial calm. I understand that the Opposition must attempt to woo back to its fold business people who increasingly prefer a Labor government to the ideology of the new Rightists who seem to have hijacked the Liberal and National leadership. Their amendments cannot be seen as a constructive addition, however, to a sensible industrial relations policy in the late 1980s with our economy under stress. I suppose they could be viewed, in the worst light, as a play to the whims of the business community, but I prefer to see the many Opposition amendments as a genuine attempt to ensure that, at least in this forum, both sides of the argument are extensively aired and considered. We endorse that motive, even though we may not eventually endorse many of the amendments themselves.

In summary, the Australian Democrats identify with this legislation, not because we consider it to be perfect by any stretch of the imagination. It contains controversial aspects. We hope to address those in some of our amendments. We hope that some of the Opposition amendments will also address them. We see the legislation as being a positive and constructive attempt by the Government to capitalise on what has occurred and the advantages that have been gained in our economy in recent years to put in place a sensible, workable foundation for the second era of industrial relations. It is a foundation which this Government, the Democrats, the Opposition and subsequent governments can address positively to the advantage of Australians generally, and Australian industry in particular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 because I believe it is a matter of great significance to the Parliament and it is an area that the media would say must remain contentious. It is regrettable that there are those, even in this Parliament, who seem to think that somehow industrial relations has to be seen as a zero sum game, that somehow there are winners and losers. Even the Australian Democrats talk in terms of this perhaps benefiting employers more than employees, as though somehow this is just a naked contest. That was certainly the line that used to be pushed by lecturers at Melbourne University when I studied industrial relations; if one were to have any sensible understanding of industrial relations one had to understand that effectively it was a class struggle and that there would always be those who would be pressing for more and more and those who would be wanting to give them as little as possible.
—It was in those days.
—I doubt that the views of academics have changed greatly.
—Or Liberal senators.

—There has been a measure of enlightenment on all sides in this area in recent years. There are those in the trade union movement who understand the notions of productivity and mutual benefit and who see this as an area in which Australia can be the winner. Certainly workers as well as corporations can prosper. Unfortunately, those people are not necessarily the ones who drive the ultimate form of legislation. That is really our concern with this Bill; it does not address, or it deliberately chooses to avoid, some of the most obvious areas that would appeal in any other arena. The principle here, as to the rule of law, is accepted as trite in any other area. But somehow in industrial relations we are constantly told that we have to make special arrangements, that we have to concede the game that if there are those who feel so strongly about the matter or, as the Democrats would say, it is sufficiently contentious that we have to take the least controversial path.
—We even had the Hancock Committee saying that the rule of law could not obtain in this area.

—Indeed. The end result was that the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, loaded as it was from the outset, took the line of least resistance and favoured the maintenance of the present system. One can understand why it took that view because it comprised those who had been steeped in the culture of industrial relations, who understood that it would be all too difficult to predict the outcome if one were to allow competitive forces to reign, and that implicit--
—Including, not the least, the so-called employer representatives.

—That is possibly true, too. The end result certainly suggests that. It is regrettable if we have to see the game in that light. But that is undoubtedly the way in which those who ultimately make the decisions in the trade union movement still approach the game, or else they could not have objected to notions which in themselves amount to an attempt simply to treat trade unions in the same way as any other group in society. Nonetheless, we have the determined refusal to allow persons not to join trade unions. We still have this charade of conscientious objection that is so loaded it is almost impossible to succeed. One has to show a deep and bitter resentment to belonging to any form of trade union, not just to a particular trade union that might have given offence. One can see time and again that this is simply the result of pressure from those who want to keep the game to themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember that years ago when I tried to get a job on a building site I was told not to bother coming because I did not have a union card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you were so lazy.

—I was not. I was there at 7 o'clock in the morning, and there was a substantial queue even at that time. I was told that if I was really determined to get a guernsey I should come back after lunch. I discovered the reason for that was that if one worked half a day one got a full day's pay. A lot of the chaps went to the pub at lunch time and did not return; they had enough to keep them going. I was able to get a job but, of course, I was forced to join the Builders Labourers Federation. I laboured very hard and long at Scotch College building the swimming pool for about three months. I will always remember that a couple of years after that when I went back to university I received a notice of intention to prosecute from Paddy Malone, the then secretary of the union. I rang him and asked, `What's this all about?' He said, `Don't take it to heart, Tony, this is just our way of catching up with people. We want to know whether they are still on the books. We are not going to chase you for your back dues, but thanks for telling us.' I thought that was probably one of the more moderate approaches to try to keep the forces in line.
—What is the relevance of this anecdotal material? The union no longer exists.
—I suppose its ghost is still with us. It seems to have infiltrated into other areas.
—The union no longer exists.
—Indeed, but I would not have thought that it was wholly unrepresentative of the Building Workers Industrial Union.
—Order!
—I am glad that the Acting Deputy President is impartial in a debate such as this.
—In all debates, senator.

—Particularly this one. I recall your vigorous questioning, Mr Acting Deputy President, of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) who is at the table in Estimates Committee A on matters relating to union powers. This is highly relevant because of the deliberate refusal to recognise the right of persons not to join trade unions. It seems, in this day and age, an extraordinary proposition that somehow people have to be coerced, that the virtues are not sufficiently apparent. People have to be told, `No card, no pay' and they are not given the opportunity to decide whether they want to join. The right to join or not to join can have tremendously competitive effects. We wax lyrical about the virtues of competition, but the level at which union membership is set may well be a deterrent factor if one has a free and voluntary choice in the matter. If one is effectively told, `You have to work in a closed shop', what is the incentive for a union to keep the rates down?
—Like in here. This is a closed shop. Were you a member of the Liberal Party when you contested pre-selection?

—I certainly was, but I chose to join. I got appointed to this place on the recommendation of the Labor Premier of Victoria. My colleagues were very concerned at some of the things that Mr Cain had to say about me. He made very uncharitable and unfair comments about me at the time. I did not have any choice about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I should also deal with some of the other controversial aspects which I do not think are sufficient to deflect us from what are very important deficiencies in the legislation. The compliance provisions are obviously crucial in that area. It was catalogued very well by my colleague Mr Shack in the House of Representatives on 23 May when he went through the gymnastics that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) went through. I suppose that he is grateful that he is now moving on to more placid waters. It is stark when one looks at the comments of the Minister that the system of compliance was substantially moribund, that the bans clause procedure had long since fallen into disrepute. I would have thought that in the normal course of events, despite the passing of Clarrie O'Shea, there is a great majority in the community who believe that there should be the ability for a court to enforce its orders, that if one loses one pays costs, if one fails to comply with an order sanctions will be imposed. But somehow in this area everything is different. That was not even the view of the Minister at the time. I thought he made it fairly plain to all that he believed that there was a case for an array of penalties for non-compliance with Commission decisions and orders. Yet he retained that view only so long as the trade union movement was prepared to wear it. On 17 August Simon Crean said:
Our position is that if the Bill does not touch common law or the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act then it must not increase or strengthen sanctions.
That meant that there shall be none. He continued:
They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

Of course, that was game, set and match. From then on the Minister for Industrial Relations threw in the towel and shortly afterwards he said: `We do not believe it is appropriate to be amending the provisions within the arbitration system now.'

TALK.START.PARA: —A very unfair characterisation, and you know it.

—I would be delighted to hear the way in which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) would explain it, even with his great ability in this area. I would have thought that the facts speak for themselves. One simply cannot move--
—Don't hold your breath.

—I would have thought that it was a great challenge to be able to explain how one can go through these contortions in such a short period. We do not need to look at the way the Minister is left swinging in the wind with respect to this issue. We need look only at the simple proposition that sanctions are the obvious other side of the coin. If one is going to put in certain requirements that one expects people to adhere to, one obviously expects to induce them to comply by providing penalties if they do not. It is a fairly straightforward proposition in any other area. For some reason the Government is not prepared to accept that in this area. The reason is that members of the trade union movement, many of whom I suppose are the real conservatives in society these days, do not think that the risk is worth taking; that somehow, if one opens the system to competition, removes many of the protective barriers and takes them out of the sheltered work shops, they might not be able to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the telecommunications industry, something like 10,000 people might be at risk according to the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association (ATEA) if we removed the first telephone monopoly. It is demonstrably untrue that those persons would be placed on the scrap heap-they would probably receive fairly generous redundancy payments. More importantly, more business would be generated in the private sector. They would all find work and would probably be better off than they are now.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would not have to belong to the union, either.

—Indeed, so they would save money in that area, as well. The fact is that they are simply afraid to take the plunge. That is what I think is so tragic about the attitude of some of the neanderthals who obviously have been able to prevail upon the Minister for Industrial Relations in this very important area. So, if we look at the fact that the Government will not outlaw closed shops-and despite the semantics that are engaged in by some from time to time, it is quite clear that we still have forms of compulsory unionism in Australia, that there are a number of areas where it is effectively impossible to get a guernsey unless you already have a guernsey-while that sort of approach prevails, while there are these ineffective or non-existent compliance provisions and there is no attempt to restructure the movement in such a way that there is a concentration on productivity gains and effective bargaining units, I would have thought that there are some very real deficiencies in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested in the area of union amalgamations because I seem to recall that some years ago Mr Fraser thought that it was not a bad idea to shrink the number of unions. It is interesting, because I think probably in good faith at the time he thought that it was simply a matter of reducing the number of unions because somehow 300 must be inefficient. We know that in West Germany there are only 16 or 17 unions. All this was a plausible reason why there were so many disputes: They were running off in different directions and having demarcation disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the kind of proposition that I think would appeal to Mr Fraser.

—I will not go into that area. I think closer examination reveals a different picture. What we now find is that it is really the larger unions which are most inclined to indulge in demarcation disputes and body snatching arrangements, and it is they who are the most militant. —You have been on the waterfront over the past decade and yet you still stand there and say that.

—You are putting a bit more power in the hands of the union boss concerned.

—It is still a very heterogeneous outfit. —Both Germany and Japan were occupied countries that had their industrial systems forced on them, particularly their arrangement of unions. That is why it looks like that. It is not comparable.

—It has been 40 years since then. They could have done whatever they wanted to do about it, but chose not to. Generally it is a pretty productive result, I would have thought. I will now turn to some of the industries that still have a long way to go and I will discuss some of the ways that this Bill does not address the problems confronting those industries. I think that the coal industry is a very good starting point. I note that the mine workers have just resolved to leave the Australian Labor Party (ALP). I do not think that that says much for their intelligence. It probably means that they are lemmings who cannot even recognise a good clip when they see one.
—You have to give them one mark at least.

—I do not think that they are showing too many signs of enlightenment. Perhaps leaving the ALP is a last desperate ploy, but I do not think that it will deliver much to them. I note that weekly wages and bonuses for most coal workers approach $1,000, while average weekly pay exceeds $800. They are very large sums of money in an industry that is supposedly not protected and in a market which is highly competitive. Certainly we are very familiar, I think, with the Japanese practice of playing us off against others and deliberately seeking alternative sources of supply. One can understand why they do that. —Do you think that they are threatened by superconductivity?

—I do not know. I do not think that they have touched anything that has given them much of a shock in recent times. Maybe they could do with a bit of hardening up intellectually. To the extent that that might help, they could benefit from talking to the Minister. So one can say that here is an industry that really does have its head in the sand, or its body in the coalmine, in that it is not prepared to face up to the need for change, which I think in a number of other industries is increasingly being recognised. Certainly, the so-called national marketing strategy will do nothing to improve productivity or indeed industrial relations in the industry. It is quite clear that employers will continue to insist not only on effective compliance provisions but also on reforms which will generate a great deal of cost saving. Whilst I think it is inevitable that there will be reductions in employment in the industry, it will simply exacerbate the problem if these reforms are not achieved.

Amongst the most important of these reforms is the introduction of a seven-day mining operation to replace the existing wasteful weekend shutdown. It is regrettable that to date there has not been enthusiasm for that proposition. It is akin to the idea that one can pretend that if someone works after 5 o'clock at night somehow that is fundamentally different and therefore deserving of a much higher wage remuneration than is given to those who work before 5 o'clock. The whole notion of penalties and weekend remuneration is very much in need of review.

There are other areas about which we have a great deal of concern and disappointment, especially if one takes account of the scathing attack of Senator Robert Ray, who normally is able to bring a degree of enlightenment to debates in this chamber. I can recall his being very quick off the mark in kicking to death the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) recommendations, making it very clear that he was not prepared to allow any more competitive pressures or better work practices to be introduced onto the waterfront. That was a very disappointing response. Through our rorts committee we have identified a number of the more extravagant methods of work without pay-or rather, pay without work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Work without pay is what you stand for.
—I suppose we are all in the same boat. There are no incentives in this game in terms of remuneration.
—Look at the overtime for last week. We sat right through until Friday morning.
—I have not got my cheque yet. I will be delighted if there is something extra for all of that toil.
—It is on merit.

—Well, that would cut out the honourable senator. I am sure we would be prepared to help the honourable senator if need be. The IAC draft report on the waterfront recommended that there should be a series of measures which would at least try to come to grips with some of the excessive coastal shipping freight rates, which it estimated wiped out between $300m and $700m from Australian gross domestic product on an annual basis. It is entirely regrettable, and almost unbelievable, that the unions refused to take any part in the IAC inquiry. The fact that the Government could be so dismissive of the recommendations of the IAC, simply because they did not suit sections of the trade union movement, is a reflection of the fact that when the heat gets turned up a little too high the Government is not prepared to endure the short term pain.

SPEECH.PARA: There was, indeed, a classic example of that with the bounty ship repair scheme. After a prolonged campaign by waterside workers involving the hijacking of foreign vessels for unnecessary repair work the scheme was introduced to encourage-or in effect bribe-workers into taking a more rational approach. Nonetheless, it was symptomatic of adopting shortsighted and short term solutions rather than addressing the need for introducing real competitive pressures. Given that, once again, shipping costs cannot be insulated from export costs and the competitive structures we face in shipping around the world, it is a matter for concern that this area was once again put in the too hard basket.

Grain handling and storage again are examples of matters that have been identified by the recent royal commission as areas where there would be considerable cost savings if a competitive environment could be introduced. To date, there has not been a great deal of encouragement in that area either. The royal commission identified overmanning on the waterfront and railways, unnecessary interruptions to ship loading operations, and significant industrial disruption and high absenteeism in some ports as the major causes of inefficiency. Boiling it down, it is once again a problem of the lack of competitive pressure coupled with the pursuit of the path of least resistance by authorities when dealing with unions, no doubt aided and abetted by the cosy arrangements that continue to persist in that area as well.

If we are serious about making Australia more competitive and providing rewards for workers as well as benefits to the community at large, then we have to do away with the division mentality-dividing workers from employers, regarding this as somehow a zero sum game when it is not and embrace the notion that cooperation can achieve very significant productivity gains on all fronts.

I regret that this Industrial Relations Bill does not tackle the fundamental issues. The Government has not been prepared to grapple with some of the very real concerns which the more enlightened members of the Government recognise but are afraid to tackle in the face of some fairly high levels of intransigence in certain sections of the union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin the substance of my speech, I certainly agree with Senator Alston in one sense: the Industrial Relations Bill is a compromise. The problem is that many of the Opposition's speakers view a compromise as something rather distasteful. Yet we are dealing with the very area, that is, industrial relations, where compromise, negotiation and consensus are very much an end result of most activities. Industrial relations is not a matter of people being totally right or totally wrong on one issue. It may well be that, on balance, when there are competing interests between various groups, one group tends to be slightly more moral than another, that its cases are more often than not justified, that sometimes it is more reasonable than the other side. On the whole the industrial relations system tries to take that into account, but inevitably one ends up with some form of compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Conciliation and Arbitration Act at its inception was a world leader in terms of the type of legislation that existed then, and even the legislation that now exists. The Conciliation and Arbitration Act was a genuine attempt by a pioneering country to establish a new structure for wage and condition fixing for all people throughout the nation. It has given Australia a unique system which did not just grow up like Topsy; it grew up with a certain principle, a certain morality, a certain community respect behind it. It has been altered from time to time. That system has grown up in accordance with the wishes of those people who are the major players in the game and, I dare say, the community of all Australians.

To come forward with totally radical proposals, whether they be proposals from either the Left or the extreme Right, to propose changes to this system as if those structural changes alone were going to change the nature of industrial relations in this country, the nature, scope and efficiency of our economic activity, is to kid oneself. We have a system that is a product of compromise, of community respect. We have some of the most eminent people in our community on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They are not all perfect by any means but they are, on the whole, people who have shown respect and responsibility for the total community interest and not just concern for the specific interests of specific interest groups that come before them.

So when we talk about changing this system, overhauling it-and it is time for a certain overhaul-we are not talking about throwing everything out, the baby with the bath water. We are talking about something that has had community acceptance for a long period, and that in many ways has worked over the years, not just in pounds, shillings and pence, or in dollars and cents, but that has worked to preserve a relationship between labour and capital in this country that in many cases has not existed for consistent periods in most other developed countries. Through our history there has been genuine respect between capital and labour in a way that, as I said, has not been found for as long and as consistently in many other countries.

There are people who will test the system. There are those on the Right, whether they call themselves the New Right or whatever, who are challenging the system. In some cases there is a seed of correctness in their viewpoint. Sometimes there has to be an opening up to the market-place of these structures. There has to be a breath of fresh air coming through. Certain pressure has to be accepted.

On the Left, for example, there has been a view that the whole thing should be restructured very tightly to guarantee all workers, regardless of how they work, think or put into their enterprise, a basic and in some cases reasonably prosperous life without effort. We can disparage both viewpoints because they do not fit into the central vision of what the arbitration system in this country is all about. But from time to time their views have to be taken on board. What we cannot afford to do is let either of the extremes hijack the system we have now.

It is incumbent upon us-all the practitioners in the industrial relations system and us as legislators-to ensure that our system is renewed from time to time through consultation and consensus. That does not mean to say that governments should sit back and say, `You lot out there oppose this, therefore we are not going to move'. It means that if a government moves in terms of changing the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, if it moves in terms of restructuring industrial relations in this country, it must do so following proper consultation with the practitioners, with the unions, with management, with those who are going to be affected by that restructuring.

Unfortunately, changes to the Arbitration Act have not always been made with that philosophy in mind. Time after time-for example, during the Fraser period-there was intervention in industrial relations, in many cases philosophically motivated but in many other cases motivated by nothing but a political view in mind, particularly a view to succeeding at the next election.

I will give Malcolm Fraser his due. In many ways he was a very good Prime Minister for the Liberal Party. He taught it how to win. He taught it how to win elections over and over again, sometimes in reasonably difficult circumstances. He has been regarded as a fairly weak man in some ways in terms of the carrying forth of a dry Liberal approach. But in industrial relations he was a congenital intervener. He was the fifth industrial relations Minister the Liberals had. The Fraser Government had four, at least in the time when I was a State industrial relations Minister: Tony Street, Andrew Peacock, Ian Macphee and Ian Viner. Then there was Malcolm Fraser, who was a de facto Minister for Industrial Relations.

The history of that period, from 1975 to 1983, is a history of interventions by the Prime Minister of the day, in many cases without consultation with the interested groups. That applied not just to the union movement, with whom Malcolm Fraser shared very few sympathies, but also to employers throughout Australia. I remember being at a significant number of meetings during those days. We had a lot of them in the last few years of the Fraser Government, usually in response to his call to change legislation, to move in a particular area, to create initiatives. At those meetings I remember a significant number of employers, important people in this country who have to make major managerial decisions that affect this economy, saying, `Where the hell is this man going?'.

I am making this point not necessarily in order to attack the Liberal Government of the day; it is an attack upon an interventionist style which is based upon ad hoc principles, regardless of whether those ad hoc principles are put into effect to amend legislation or to bear upon government activity. It was a very sad period. The reason I am mentioning it now, at the outset of my speech, is that I believe that that period, and the Whitlam period in terms of industrial relations, should stand as historical contrasts to what has been achieved under this Government.

I will start with the Whitlam Government. I think we ought to be honest in this chamber. The Whitlam Government's industrial policies, as opposed to some of its other policies, like Medibank and so on, were fairly dreadful. We had Public Service wage increases-massive increases in the Public Service sector-firing and fuelling wage increases in the private sector that this community could not afford. Consultation was fairly negligible. On the whole, the record was not a happy one. We thought that was bad enough, in a sense, and a lot of people in the Labor Party learned from the mistakes of that period, including the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). But the record of the Fraser period was even worse. I quote the words of Charles Dickens at the beginning of A Tale of Two Cities:
It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness . . .

One could talk about the Fraser period as encompassing that description-certainly the foolishness and the difficulties. As the Fraser Government neared the end of its time in office one could see that the writing was on the wall. It had failed in industrial relations, one of the key components of strategies for managing an economy. The $39 a week pay increase in the metal trades industry was flowing through to other industries, especially the transport industry. The record of strikes then has been unparalleled over the last decade, standing at about 3 1/2 times the number of working days lost compared with the situation last year under this Government. Inflation was out of hand. Unemployment was going through the roof and standing at historic levels.

Ministers bumbled from pillar to post. A couple of incidents demonstrate that point pretty clearly. The industrial relations Minister Mr Viner, the second last industrial relations Minister of the Fraser era, towards the end of his time in 1981-82 made some terrible blunders. All Ministers make mistakes, but these mistakes were made because he was bringing aggression into the management of industrial relations. He was bringing confrontation into industrial relations as a major principle of Government activity.

Honourable senators will recall that it was the Liberal Government that set out to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF), but totally fouled up that activity. The deregistration finally occurred when the Hawke Government decided to do it properly. Let us recall the case of Costain Australia Ltd, the company whose title and name was tabled in the Parliament by Ian Viner, after he had given an absolute promise to all employer groups that if they cooperated with the Government in providing information about breaches of the Act and other illegalities on the part of the BLF their names would be kept secret. Yet Minister Viner tabled in the House the name of a company, which was then subjected to some of the grossest behaviour on the part of the Builders Labourers Federation. He set it up; and the BLF knocked it down.

Similarly, in a desperate attempt to bring in legislation aimed at destroying the union movement's power, or its place in the industrial relations framework, Minister Viner caused to be leaked-I could use the words strategically leaked-details of the Government's new tough anti-union legislation. But that just happened to be done on the eve of the meeting of the National Labour Consultative Council, the body established to look at industrial relations. It represented employers, government and employees and it was expected to try to make the system work, to advise the Government and discuss with the Government how the system ought to work. It was a total slap in the face to that very important and influential body, all in the interests of winning against the unions. One can imagine the effect that had on the industrial relations climate of the day. It was totally unworkable. There could have been eight Ministers rather than four and the situation would have been the same.

I must say that there was some hope on the horizon. This relates to the theme of what this Government is trying to do in this Bill. Ian Macphee became Minister for Industrial Relations when the hapless and, I must say, deceitful Ian Viner finally left office. Ian Macphee made one particular statement when he came to office which I thought was interesting in terms of its approach. I will read it because it stands as a monument to someone who at least tried, and who is still trying, to impose on his fellow Liberals a view about the way industrial relations should work, a realistic and commonsense view. I quote what he said a day or so after he became Minister:

I have never been a confrontationist and I am a great believer in the power of reason. I believe that the only way to have sensible industrial relations is to have a legislative framework which provides means of people getting together and talking through their problems. Then it rests on the calibre of leadership on both sides of the industrial fence and in the tribunals to bring about a common solution. That commonsense result will be produced by the commonsense of people, and not by legislative provisions.

That is the reason why this Government decided to amend the Act in a significant way only when it came to an understanding of what was the commonsense ground to take in industrial relations. We have been in office for nearly five years. This Bill is coming before the Senate five years after our election to office because we wanted to ensure that there was significant agreement about the restructuring of the whole system. Some of the disagreement has been expressed in strong tones, from both the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and employer organisations. But on the whole they have accepted that this is the most workable rearrangement of the current Act that is possible.

A number of people have talked in this debate, most of them from the other side, representing the Nationals and the Liberals. A number of them are new people to this chamber without industrial relations experience. They have never had the job of sitting down in a meeting and saying, `How do we sort this out so that the ships sail, the planes fly, goods end up in factories and shops are not black-banned?'. They have not had to work out, for example, how people who are unfairly dismissed can be protected and how a union can represent its workers in the most effective and reasonable way. The majority of people on the other side have had no practical experience in that area. Most of them have never had the spotlight descend on their head and seen the message on the wall, `What are you going to do about getting this problem solved?'.

It is only in those sorts of situations, where there is a clash of interests, that one gets the practical experience and the philosophical viewpoint which teaches about the rights of other people and that no-one is totally right or wrong in the industrial relations arena. Knowing that, one starts to restructure what has to be restructured and the rest of it one tries to change, as a government, through the creation of a climate of consideration and understanding. That is a realistic way to get over confrontation and, when there is confrontation, a workable way of resolving it.

Central to the philosophy of this Government is the prices and incomes accord, which is embodied in this Bill and the way we work. The accord was negotiated between the ACTU and significant people in the Australian Labor Party prior to the Labor Party being elected. It was a response to Australia's industrial relations difficulties. It was a response by many people in the Labor Party to the ineffective way industrial relations was run in the Whitlam period and the confrontationist way it was run during the Fraser period. It was an attempt to say, `Industrial relations is an essential part of the management of an economy'. If there is no wages and conditions policy for workers, this country will go down the banana republic road-and we were close to it. Everyone in this chamber knows that Australia's competitiveness and standard of living relative to other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries were declining-and had declined from the time when I was a teenager.

We remember the relative affluence of the community, not in terms of what we have on hire purchase but in the way, for example, Australia had the capacity to pay its bills and to be competitive. So the union movement and the Labor Party that was to become the Government agreed on the prices and incomes accord-an historic document, historic in the first place in the sense that an agreement was reached and, in the second place, because it did provide a workable blueprint for this country to remain competitive through extremely difficult times: for example, through the commodity price disaster in 1984-85.

It also provided a breathing space for the economy, where wages were not chasing prices and prices were not chasing wages, and where strikes were reduced to one-third of the figure in the Fraser period. Unions, for example, said, `Chasing wages is not our single concern any more. Our concern is to ensure that, through cooperation with employers but, on the whole, with government as well, we are able to get trade-offs by way of tax trade-offs, through government expenditure on health, education and social welfare areas'. Unions could start to look to the overall management of the economy, the overall interests of the community, rather than to the question of whether they got another $5 a week in the pockets of their members, much of which would be swallowed up by taxation and increased inflation anyway. So the union movement benefited from the accord because it learnt to look beyond its own immediate interests. It started to see itself in a new role.

Despite the factual results, the statistics that show that industrial relations improved, despite the dramatic improvement in the economy and our competitiveness, our ability to restructure the economy to be competitive overseas, there are those among the Nationals and Liberals on the other side of the chamber who say that it is wrong to give the union movement access to the Government in terms of consultation and discussion. There are simple phrases for that view. One can call it right wing ideology, the New Right, the ginger group or the dries-whatever name one prefers to call it. Those people who say that the union movement has no right to be involved in intimate discussions with the Government about the role that it can play in helping to shape this economy are snobs. Basically, their view stems from the fact that, on the whole, union members are less well paid and may be socially inferior, in their terms, to them. If honourable senators opposite personally do not believe that, by accepting right wing ideology in this area they are certainly accepting it de facto.

One has only to look, for example, at the attempts by the union movement to gain superannuation for women in the work force, most of whom have never been adequately covered. I have had members of management tell me that the opposition to superannuation is basically a question of prestige. They say, `What is the value of giving a superannuation package, no matter how generous, to a manager if he knows that a superannuation package is being handed to the lowest employee in the company?' Some have admitted that it is based on snobbery.

It is all very well to talk about some of the other parts of the Opposition's package, such as enterprise bargaining and that type of thing. But at the heart of it all is the question of where it wants to strike the balance between the roles and rights of employers and the roles, rights and relative power of employees and the organisations that represent them. Quite simply, one cannot tip that balance too far either way. If that happens, one loses that sense of consensus that is such a vital part of the Australian economic and political system. We take it for granted that that consensus will be here forever. The events of 1975 showed that consensus is a very delicate thing. If one cuts out people forever from having a role to play, they will simply not accept it. Their actions, the approach that they take, for example, to industrial relations, will become more irresponsible year by year.

The Bill that is before the Senate has been explained by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in his second reading speech. The provisions that it contains have been detailed for some time. I shall comment on those in the committee stage. I conclude my remarks by making the following point: one of the major considerations of this Bill is the question of amalgamations. Some time ago Senator Alston opposed the idea of amalgamations on the basis that, inevitably, it is the big unions that will get bigger as a result of amalgamation, that they are the ones which are irresponsible and which have the clout. The small unions, on the whole, do not do any harm to the economy; they really go along with things as they are. I said to Senator Alston by way of interjection, `Where have you been in the last decade as far as the waterfront or the maritime industry are concerned?'

Let us look at the maritime industry: seven unions and, in the last 20 years, strike after strike and delay after delay. On the whole, those unions have a very poor industrial relations record. It has been incredibly difficult for a Minister or a government to deal with them. How does one even contact the secretary of a union who is part time and who puts his phone on an answering device for most of the week? I have experienced that difficulty. How does one discipline or contact a union that allows its shop steward on board a ship to decide whether a whole port stands idle? The answer is that one cannot, because the unions are too small. There must be a minimum size and there must be amalgamation.

The maritime industry was covered by about seven unions. They wished to amalgamate because they knew that their behaviour was being affected by the fact that they were small, piddling unions that did not count for two bob in the overall scheme of things, but who could be a nuisance to each other, and who knew that their structure was impossible. Yet under amendments brought in by the Liberals to the previous Act, it took them three years to amalgamate, despite the fact that not one of those unions opposed the amalgamation. These key provisions in the legislation seek to reduce the number of unions in Australia through amalgamation into bigger unions and through the elimination of unions whose membership is below a certain number-a key component. Yet even that sensible view which is embodied in this Bill is opposed by the Opposition. I cannot understand that that could be opposed, yet that is the case. And for what reasons? It is for reasons akin to the Bill of Rights I guess; an act of faith on the part of the Right, which is now dominating the industrial relations viewpoints of the Liberal Party and the Nationals.
