SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of industrial relations Bill would one expect from a government that cannot even solve a demarcation dispute between Bob and Paul as to who gets the Prime Minister's job? It is no wonder that we find ourselves debating a new industrial relations Bill for a second year in a row. That fact alone is an acknowledgment by the Labor Government of the failures and inadequacies of the present legislation. Last year's Bill was withdrawn after enormous public outcry, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) opportunistically called yet another early election. Now, with the election safely out of the way, we find that a new Bill has been introduced which is only slightly different from last year's, which correctly drew such public outrage.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in this debate Senator Burns claimed that the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 is a result of `cooperation and consultation' between the Government, the trade union movement and employer organisations, and that it embodies many of the recommendations of the report of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. Let us remember that the Hancock report is widely regarded as the last hurrah of the industrial relations club rather than being a blueprint for the future. The fact is that, contrary to Senator Burns's claims, organisations such as the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce are highly critical of both the Hancock report and this Bill. Senator Burns demonstrated the incapacity of the Australian Labor Party and of many trade union leaders to extract themselves from the nineteenth century. He quoted Keir Hardie in relation to industrial conditions in Britain of long ago. Those conditions have never been relevant to Australia and they are certainly not applicable as we head towards the twenty-first century. But this legislation reflects that sort of out of date, unAustralian, nineteenth century thinking exemplified by Senator Burns. This is nineteenth century legislation, not twentieth or twenty-first century legislation.

This new Bill fails to implement the reforms that industrial relations experts, economists and many unionists and employers agree are so necessary to remedy the problems that are inherent in the current system. This Bill is a classic case of a grossly mismanaged opportunity for real reform at a time when industrial relations all over the world are taking on a more flexible, non-confrontationist approach. Economic analysis shows conclusively that the future prosperity of Australia's economy is dependent on the introduction of a flexible enterprise-oriented industrial relations system. Even the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has acknowledged the need for reform. In an address to the National Press Club after the Budget statement last May, Mr Keating said that labour market reform is `the last great area of change to be overcome'. But instead of grasping the opportunity to revamp the whole system towards a more equitable and flexible arrangement, the Labor Government has put forward a piece of legislation that will further reinforce the existing centralised control system and inflexible labour market.

Government senators who have already spoken in this debate have claimed that the legislation is far reaching and constructive and will make great changes to the face of industrial relations in Australia. It will do nothing of the sort. On the contrary, it will further entrench excessive union power. It is obvious by now that the scope for criticism of this Bill is enormous. In fact, I would suggest that it is the second worst Bill the Hawke Government has ever tried to send to Yarralumla-and I am not referring to the Governor-General designate.

If there were unlimited time in this debate, one could speak at length on the whole spectrum of adverse implications of this proposed legislation, but I shall limit myself to those areas which I believe are the most severely detrimental. These are: firstly, the amalgamation of unions; secondly, the support given to compulsory unionism; thirdly, the unequal and ineffective compliance provision; fourthly, the sanctioning of strike pay; and, finally, the issue of secret ballots. Statistics show that the majority of demarcation disputes involve unions with more than 3,000 members, such as the metal workers, the storemen and packers and the building and transport workers unions. In a survey of 32 recent demarcation disputes it was found that only one involved a union with a membership of less than 3,000 members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why 32? Why not 35? Why not 40?

—Because they were the most recent. This indicates that the provisions of this Bill, which would create bigger unions, will only increase the likelihood of these costly and destructive disputes. With a larger membership spread over a wider range of industries, it is inevitable that demarcation disputes will spread out throughout the workplace in a ripple effect, eventually crippling many industries, many of which will not be involved in the original dispute. We have already seen this occur in the past in the car industry, where production lines are frequently brought to a halt and thousands of workers are stood down because of the actions of one union operating in one small area of the production line.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt, in advocating union amalgamations, referred to the small number of unions in countries such as West Germany which have good industrial relations records. He has completely ignored the fact that those unions are industry based and enterprise-oriented rather than craft based super unions as envisaged by this legislation. The Liberal Party of Australia advocates industry or enterprise unions as a better structure for good industrial relations. Some Australian companies have as many as 20 or 30 unions with which to contend. It is no wonder that inter-union disputes are so rife in this country. We should be aiming for a single union at each work place through the creation of either enterprise or industry based unions rather than legislating to create huge, unwieldy craft-based unions that stretch across a multitude of enterprises.

To cap it all off, this Government has the arrogance to proclaim that the Australian taxpayer will foot the bill for retirement pay for trade union leaders and officials who lose their jobs through union amalgamations. It is a travesty and an outrage that public money should be used for what amounts to bribes to unions to ensure that they offer no resistance to this Government's plans for union amalgamation. Why not go all the way and build them a beach house?

Another aspect of the creation of fewer and larger unions is the complete disregard for the principle of freedom of association. Australia, as we all know, is a member of the International Labour Organisation (ILO). For the past 70-odd years the ILO has been adopting conventions and recommendations on labour and welfare issues. These conventions, when ratified by member states, are intended to create binding legal obligations on those member states to implement their terms. A member state which ratifies such conventions binds itself to apply the provisions of the convention within its territory and accepts international supervision in relation to its efforts to do so.

Although the Hawke Labor Government has ratified a number of these conventions and has done more than is required to maintain minimum ILO convention standards, it appears to have done so on a selective basis. Shipping, for example, has received a lot of attention from the ILO and this Government has been scrupulous about enforcing the terms of the convention which happen to suit local vested interests with much to gain from uncompetitive work and management practices. However, when it comes to ILO convention No. 87 on Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, which provides that workers, without distinction whatsoever, shall have the right to establish and join organisations of their choosing, the Government has done nothing. Australian workers do not have the right to establish and join trade unions of their own choosing, or at least they do not have the ability freely to establish and join organisations that can be registered to operate within the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The current Act prevents employees from forming or joining enterprise or multi-skilled unions and forces them into big trade unions already established and registered in respect of their particular trade.

The new Industrial Relations Bill before us restricts this freedom to establish and join a registered union even further. Clause 189 of this Bill prohibits the registration of a new union, except in very special circumstances: unless it has more than 3,000 members, it is industry-based and there is no existing union to which the members might conveniently belong. So the `conveniently belong' clause of the old Act, which protected vested interests of existing unions and which has been the subject of much industrial litigation, is more strongly entrenched in this legislation. Thus clause 189 also prevents registration of unions for those sharing particular religious or political beliefs not already adequately catered for by existing unions. Clause 261 denies union members the right to decide who should and who should not join the union by requiring the union to enrol anyone who applies and is eligible for membership, unless they are of a general bad character. The amalgamation provision is also a matter of major concern to smaller unions, many of which have already approached the Opposition to voice their fears of being swallowed up by large, impersonal unions whose management has little regard for the interests and concerns of the individual worker.

Article 4 of the ILO convention provides that workers' and employers' organisations shall not be liable to be dissolved or suspended by administrative authority. But clause 193 of this Bill requires the Commission to deregister small unions after three years unless there are special circumstances which make continuance of registration in the public interest. `Small' in these terms means less than 3,000 members. Registration is essential for a union to be able to represent its members before the Commission, so deregistration is equivalent to dissolution or suspension. The question is whether the Commissioner who decides whether special circumstances exist is exercising administrative authority. In the context of an international convention, the Australian distinctions between executive and judicial power are not relevant and the decision counts as an exercise of administrative authority which here almost means government power. Consequently, the Bill violates article 4 of the convention. That is not merely my opinion; I am reliably informed that the Treasurer is so concerned he cannot wait for Hawkie to start his new job at the ILO and sort it all out.

Furthermore, the creation of larger unions is a move towards increased centralised control rather than a more flexible system which would be more responsive to local enterprise and industry needs. We should not be aiming for bigger unions and uniformity. It puts more power into the hands of fewer union officials who will be less inclined to look after their member's interests than they will be in entrenching their own positions. This whole matter of union leadership leads me to another important area of civil liberties; that of de facto compulsory union membership which of course means compulsory donations for the Labor Party. Earlier in this debate Senator Cooney was quite correct when he said:
It would be wrong to regard labour and workers simply as commodities.

He is quite right to intimate that workers must be regarded as individual human beings, yet this Government totally ignores this basic respect for human dignity by its failure in this legislation to protect the rights of the individual worker to either join a union or not to join as he sees fit. It is a direct contravention of article 20 item 2 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which states:
. . . no one may be compelled to belong to an association.

Although there is no legislation enforcing compulsory union membership, union pressure and closed shops make it a practical reality in many industries in this country. For the Prime Minister and others in his Government to state, as they have on many occasions, that there is no such thing as compulsory unionism in this country is a total fallacy.

The building industry is a prime example of this where the general rule rigidly enforced by unions and employers is, no ticket no work. One has only to look at the notices posted on all major building sites to see the truth of this. You can get into Japan without a passport but you cannot get on to a building site without a union ticket. This practice is a gross violation of civil liberties both for the employee and the employer who is forced by the threat of intimidation and industrial action to hire only union members. The right not to belong to a trade union should be protected just as much as the right to belong.

Another argument for voluntary unionism is that it makes union officials far more accountable to their members than they are at present. If unions had to work to really provide service to attract members, they would be far more inclined to listen to their members and their concerns. It is this fundamental belief in individual rights that prompts the Opposition to put forward an amendment to this Bill that seeks to preserve those rights. It is not acceptable that a government that professes concern about human rights in other countries and that wants selected rights entrenched in our Australian Constitution should put up legislation that ignores human rights and international conventions as this Bill does.

The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 should be opposed for this reason. This Bill does nothing to remedy the impotence of the Arbitration Commission to enforce its decisions. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in his second reading speech of the first version of this Bill on 14 May 1987, described compliance provisions as an essential element of the industrial relations system. He went on to point out that the current bans clause procedure was `disreputable' and `substantially moribund'. In the original Bill of 1987 a range of penalties to be imposed were to be tougher than those under the existing Act. They were to include fines, alterations to an organisation's eligibility rules to exclude specified groups from membership, and the imposition of conditions as to future industrial conduct.

A serious continuing breach of direction by an organisation or its members would lead to deregulation. However, when this Government shelved that Bill for its own electoral convenience, it also dropped these tougher compliance provisions. The Government is now blaming the employers for this, but it is quite obvious that it was pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) which forced the Government to back down on this question. The President of the ACTU, Mr Simon Crean, is quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 17 August 1987 as saying:
They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

In the same month the ACTU assistant secretary, Mr Garry Weaven, claimed that the shelved Bill should be scrapped because it held `little comfort for unions'. If this does not spell out the intentions of the ACTU, then I do not know what does. Moreover, many employer groups including the Confederation of Australian Industry expressed opposition to the original Bill on the grounds, among others, that it did not do enough to strengthen enforcement provisions. The end result is that we are now faced with a piece of legislation which nominally gives the Commission a great number of powers but which does not back those powers up with effective enforcement mechanisms-except oddly enough against unions which decline to amalgamate.

The Opposition's policy is that employers and employees should be free to make their own agreements on employment conditions and wages. Nevertheless, while we have a system of conciliation and arbitration, there must be some provisions to ensure that its parties, subject to Commission rulings, comply with its directions. When the Liberal-National Party coalition wins government at the next election it will enact legislation already introduced in the Senate to ensure that there are effective sanctions for those who fail to comply with the decisions and orders of the Commission. This will enable the Commission to issue directions to stop or prevent industrial action. Such directions would be enforceable by injunctions issued by the Federal Court of Australia. Failure to comply with injunctions will constitute contempt of court. In addition, any person who suffers loss or damage as a result of industrial action in breach of a direction would be able to sue the responsible organisation for damages in the Federal Court. We will also review all penalties under the Act to ensure that they are appropriate and effective.

Under the current legislation, unions or employers for that matter are free to flout those decisions with impunity. Only with enforceable and equitable compliance provisions can an industrial relations system involving arbitration operate fairly and effectively. The provision of this Bill which gives support to strike pay is a backward step from the present Act. It proposes to allow the Commission to award strike pay in disputes where it is:

. . . satisfied that the industrial action was justified by a concern on the part of the employees (a) that was reasonable; (b) that was about their health and safety; and (c) that arose in relation to matters within the reasonable responsibility of the employer concerned.

These guidelines are open to wide interpretation and in practice it will be very difficult for the Commission to restrict the awarding of strike pay to disputes concerned solely or primarily with these criteria. This is already exemplified in the building industry where this principle is widely accepted and is a matter of major concern. But of course, the concept of strike pay represents perfect Labor logic. After all, if one can pick up a travel allowance for not travelling, why not a working wage for not working? What next? I predict an extension of the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading, namely strike pay for workers on holidays who do not have the opportunity of going on strike.

Liberal-National Party policy on this question is that health and safety issues should be resolved by appropriate inspection and mediation, not by unilateral industrial action. Yet there are any number of cases in the building industry where stop-work action has been taken in the name of health and safety or employer negligence but which was, in fact, little more than an excuse to have a paid day off work. For example, there have been instances of workers refusing to walk even short distances to building work areas in the rain, or to take alternative, drier routes. There have been other cases where if two or three people could not work in a certain area because of adverse weather conditions everyone on the site has walked off, even though the alleged safety issue did not affect the majority.

Even very minor or irrelevant issues are often used as an excuse to pull everyone off the job-a temporary loss of power to a first aid shed or a lunch area, or the fact that a qualified first aid person on the site is not a union member, for example; hardly issues which qualify as a big enough threat to health and safety to justify the total closure of a large building project with all the attendant costs involved. These and other examples I could cite are the cause of major concern among employer groups and indeed among many others in the community who are growing increasingly tired of being held to ransom by large union groups for no apparent worthwhile reason. It is because this Bill offers what amounts to a virtual open invitation to unions to go on strike that the Opposition opposes this provision to give the Commission the power to fund strikes.

The Liberal and National parties take the issue of strike pay very seriously. Our policy is to make it an offence for any employer to pay, or any employee to accept, strike pay and we would amend the Act to prohibit a union from taking industrial action in pursuit of a demand for strike pay. In our view, the granting of power to the Commission to award strike pay is immoral and unacceptable and will only lead to an unprecedented wave of strikes across the nation.

In Britain, where the Thatcher Government has since the early 1980s introduced a series of legislation which has deregulated the labour market, a new trade unionism is rapidly emerging, bringing with it a degree of cooperation and good employer-employee relations not seen before in industrial times. Many workers, such as electricians and engineers, are forming themselves into single-industry organisations rather than craft-based unions spread over a wide range of industries. These new unions favour privatisation and a strong free market economy and worker profit-sharing. Many are making no-strike agreements and the number of industrial disputes is at its lowest level in Britain since 1936. The remarkable growth in the British economy has been well documented in recent months. Much of the credit for this economic turnaround has been attributed to the new unionism and changed attitudes in industrial relations which have laid the foundations for increased productivity and other economic reforms.

This is all a lot easier in the United Kingdom, where the elected government runs the country, not the trade union apparatchiks. What a revelation it was to see Prime Minister Thatcher here recently. She not only towered over our Prime Minister both literally and metaphorically, she even had a deeper voice. The point I am making here in talking about British trade unionism and the British economy is that it is indicative of the direction in which we in Australia should be heading. Of course, conditions are somewhat different in Australia and we should not be seeking blindly to follow the British model. But we should be looking at what will work for us, and use selective judgment in adopting what we consider appropriate.

Much of what the Opposition has put forward in its industrial relations policy, and some of the amendments we propose for this Bill, have already been implemented with great effect in Britain. I cite as one example the question of secret ballots before strikes. In Britain in 1984, the Thatcher Government made it illegal for unions to call a strike without consulting their members by ballot. It is this piece of legislation which has been attributed as a major factor behind the dramatic decrease in the number of strikes in Britain, and was partly responsible for the large number of miners who kept working through the disastrous miners' strike of 1984 and 1985.

Liberal-National Party coalition industrial relations policy is that it should be compulsory to hold secret ballots before industrial action is undertaken. Under current legislation there are no such provisions, and many workers are forced to go on strike unwillingly in Australia either without consultation or because they have to vote on a show of hands, which leaves them open to intimidation if they disagree with union officials.

I urge honourable senators to consider carefully the implications of this Bill if it is passed without the amendments proposed by the Opposition. If it is, we shall end up with an industrial relations Act as moribund and as ineffective as the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has said the present one is. The Minister has been quoted as saying that Australia `should develop over the next few years a more skilled, flexible and productive work force'.

The Bill he is introducing here will do nothing of the sort. One has only to look at the recent wages decision to realise the extent of the effects that such a piece of legislation will have on the economy. The new wages accord is a good example of the way the present system is weighted in favour of the trade union movement and its capacity to apply pressure through union strength.

The wages decision has given in to the ACTU and fails to deliver what it promised-that is, it fails to trade off productivity for wages; it does nothing to contain inflation, and in fact it is based on the extraordinary premise of expected inflation. According to the Confederation of Australian Industry report, this wages system which was preferred by the ACTU is remarkably similar to the wages system in place in two of the poorest economies in Europe-Spain and Portugal. The Government claims that this new wages decision paves the way for a more flexible wages structure and better employee-employer relations. Yet it does nothing of the sort, and even if it did this Bill before us would undermine any gains in that direction, anyway.

I reiterate that the Opposition is opposed to so many of the aspects of this Industrial Relations Bill that we consider it necessary to introduce some 39 amendments. Many provisions of the new Bill contravene the terms of the International Labour Organisation convention concerning freedom of association and protection of the right to organise, among others. The current industrial relations system does not comply with the convention and the Bill would make things a good deal worse.

Even if they disagree on the economic effects of the Bill's becoming law, or on whether or not industrial relations should be managed through an arbitration system, all civil libertarians can and should unite to oppose this freedom-reducing legislation. The Liberal-National Party coalition is opposed to the aspects of this Bill which do nothing to curb union power to coerce and intimidate both employers and union members; which give power to the Commission to award strike pay while doing nothing to increase compliance provisions; which give more power to fewer and bigger unions; and which, in essence, are a violation of fundamental rights to freedom of association and choice.

I hear the term `super unions' being bandied about by the Government. Why not come clean and call them what they are really meant to be `soviets', the cornerstone of the socialist corporate state? Earlier in the debate Senator Aulich said that in the interests of good industrial relations, the balance of industrial power must not move too far either way-too far towards employers or too far towards trade unions. The fact is in our current circumstances industrial power has moved much too far towards trade unions and they can hold the community and employers to ransom. We need to restore the balance of power between those two groups. This Bill will not achieve that desirable goal, whereas the Opposition policy, which has been announced and well received in the community, will do exactly that.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly, this Bill is a tragically missed opportunity to bring real and much needed reform to our industrial relations arbitration system. Let us do more than just change the name of the Arbitration Commission. Let us have a complete rethink on the whole question of industrial relations and let us restructure a more flexible and more equitable system that will lead Australia into the modern industrialised world. It seems beyond hope that this Government is capable of achieving that if this legislation is any example of its approach to industrial relations. Therefore, it seems that we must await the election of the next Liberal-National Party Government to achieve real industrial relations reform which will provide the basis for effective economic growth in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate continues its debate on the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 and associated legislation. It is a lengthy and worthwhile debate. Unfortunately, it is one-sided. I say unfortunately because all sides of Australian society today need to get involved in this matter. One thing that the Hawke Labor Government has proved in its 5 1/2 years in office is that we need the involvement of as many people and as many groups and associations as possible in order to reach a resolution of difficulties and conflicts. It is regrettable that it is a one-sided debate-regrettable because the Opposition in its 5 1/2 years on the opposition benches has proved yet again that it has learned absolutely nothing about industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall refrain from taking up some of the comments made by Senator Chapman, who preceded me in the debate. I will emphasise one instance of the measurement of industrial relations in this country. I will use one set of statistics in order to measure the conflict and how things have improved since we came to office. During the life of the previous conservative coalition Government, under the prime ministership of Malcolm Fraser, from January 1976 to February 1983 there were 249,200 working days lost on average per month-almost a quarter of a million. Over a similar timeframe, from March 1983 to April 1988, under the Hawke Government there were 112,100 working days lost on average per month. It is still far too many, but it is representative of a 55 per cent reduction in the instances of industrial strikes on the job. That has to be regarded as good by anybody's standards. It has to be considered good as a measure of this Government's achievements. I emphasise the relations aspect of industrial relations. Strike activity results from a breakdown in relationships. We all realise how delicate relationships can be from time to time, whether they be relationships with our parents, with our offspring, with our spouses, or with less immediate family-our uncles and aunts. All these relationships have to be handled separately, delicately and sensitively. That is how the Minister, Ralph Willis, and the Government have handled industrial relations.

There is no one single broad brush solution to the conflicts that occur between workers and management. There cannot be, because in some instances when a strike occurs it is the worker that is at fault; in other instances it is the management that is at fault. In 1976 the Federal Government was at fault. In my State of Western Australia in 1979 the State Government was at fault. So how can we bring down one single solution to deal with each and every problem that arises in industrial relations? We cannot.

We have been able to address a whole host of problems that arise in industry, not only through the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), not only through the State branches of the labour councils throughout Australia but also through the trade union movement as individuals and as groups of individuals. We have gone out and consulted and brought them in and consulted. In some instances the achievements came very fast. In some cases no industrial disputation occurred; in others, unfortunately, it was not possible to achieve that end immediately. The statistics to which I referred earlier, the 55 per cent reduction in the rate of industrial disputes over the time the Hawke Government has been in office compared with that which occurred when the Fraser Government was in office, speak for themselves.

In this one-sided debate there has not been a tremendous amount of attention given to the resolution of disputes. I cannot recall one person from the Opposition benches mentioning in this debate that the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 is actually a replacement of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Act which went through the Commonwealth Parliament in 1904-84 years ago. It took the Hawke Labor Government to address the problems. We have had many conservative governments, coalition and otherwise, in office in that time, but it is a Labor government that seeks to address the problems.

This is not a perfect Bill. I worked long and hard with many of my colleagues in the Caucus committee system on the previous Bill that was dropped prior to the last election. That went a lot closer to meeting the needs of the trade union movement, industry and the employers than does this piece of legislation. Whilst this Bill does not go as far as I would like it to, I accept it because it is not just the subject of a one-sided set of consultations between the Government and the ACTU; many employer organisations have also been consulted. Not all of those people who have been consulted have had their wish list met. It is just not the name of the game. We know that from our own party rooms. Opposition members have probably experienced this better than we have in the last week, although from time to time we have our difficulties as well.

The Bill has been drafted after very extensive consultation with the union movement and with employer groups, with the aim to produce more coherent Federal industrial legislation which will meet current and future demands in society. Not only are we looking to address the difficulties and problems that we have at the moment but also we are seeking to look ahead. Our major objective is the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes within the Federal conciliation and arbitration jurisdiction. In my opening remarks I stressed the problem of strikes. There are many people within the union movement-which I am proud to have come from and proud to be still a paid up member of-who, like the fighter pilots in the world wars who chalked up their number of hits, mark up the winning of disputes as though they record some form of advancement. But this Government is not about that, we are about the prevention of disputes in the first instance. If we cannot prevent them we want to bring about as speedy as possible a resolution of the conflicts that occur. We will follow through with what the old Act said about the registration and regulations of organisations not only of unions but also of employers. We will institute the protection of individuals' rights under the Federal system.

The Bill provides for a replacement of the current Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which will have an enhanced role in dispute settlement by conciliation. The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 emphasises the need for non-legalistic dispute settlement procedures, particularly at the workplace level-not necessarily in front of the Commission, not necessarily in the boardrooms of the head offices in Melbourne, Sydney or Perth, but at the work place. Rather than develop that point I will digress because there are a few other remarks I want to make after I conclude my remarks on the Bill itself.

There are a number of functions that the new Commission will take over also which are now separate from the conciliation and arbitration process such as the Flight Crew Officers Industrial Tribunal, the Academic Salaries Tribunal, and the Australian Federal Police Arbitral Tribunal. We are still negotiating with the New South Wales Government about the possible abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal. The industrial division of the Federal Court will continue to deal with industrial matters arising under the Industrial Relations Bill, including matters such as election inquiries, membership entitlements and the enforcement of rules. Perhaps that is one of the areas with which I have some difficulty in this Bill. I did favour the establishment of a labour court. I recognise that there have been problems in the past, from the union and from the employer point of view, with the handling of these matters through the Federal Court. A lot is to be said for giving the resolution and settlement of industrial disputes to experienced practitioners in the field rather than to judges who may be well versed in other spheres of law. So be it. That is how the negotiations and consultations have worked out, and I think we accept that. There will be a wider jurisdiction than that which we have experienced before. The new Commission will deal with all industrial disputes arising from relationships between employers and employees, including the reinstatement of dismissed employees. The wider jurisdiction reflects recent High Court interpretations of the jurisdiction of Federal industrial tribunals. I dare say that there are not too many on the Opposition benches who would know first hand what that particular clause is all about. As an individual-and I suppose in those days one could have called me a militant shop steward in a militant union-I knew about it on three occasions, even though on each occasion proceedings did not actually reach the Commission for settlement.

One of the very important-and for an isolated State like Western Australia it is of crucial importance-provisions in the legislation is the improved interaction between the Federal and State industrial relations systems. In an isolated State like Western Australia there is a tendency to feel locked off and remote from things, as indeed we do from time to time, particularly when one is delayed on an aircraft going either one way or the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Northern Territory.

—And the Northern Territory, as well. So it will also be of advantage to Senator Tambling and to the workers and employers in the Northern Territory. It will improve interaction in the settlement and resolution of industrial conflict and dispute. The Bill will enable a member of the Commission to hold a concurrent appointment on a State tribunal, and vice-versa, allowing for greater consistency in formulating and amending awards. A majority of States have given in principle agreement to the concept of dual appointments and intend to pass complementary legislation to give effect to the proposal. The Bill will also provide for increased emphasis on public interest and economic factors. The Commission will have to demonstrate that it has taken account of the public interest-including the state of the economy-when carrying out its functions. It must also show that it has considered the effect of any proposed awards on employment and inflation. The Bill will also encourage the use of grievance procedures and give formal recognition to grievance procedures as a form of dispute settlement at the workplace level. The Commission will also encourage the insertion of such procedures into awards or, where such procedures already form part of an award, the Commission will be required to ensure that they are being followed before it becomes involved in a dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: The emphasis here is on resolution in the workplace, on the shop floor. Of course, that seems to have gone over the head of so many senators opposite who have already spoken. We have heard a lot from the other side about demarcation disputes and, in fact, mention was made of 32 recent disputes. However, no explanation has been given of this magic figure of 32 demarcation disputes. We could be talking about the past 32 demarcation disputes, but what about doing an analysis of the number of demarcation disputes that have arisen under the life of the Hawke Government compared with those that occurred during the term of the Fraser Government, and it could be done on either a monthly or annual basis. That is when statistics of that nature will be of use. We would need to examine and detail the 32 disputes to see whether or not they have any meaning with respect to this legislation.

The Government has looked at this matter with respect to the expanded role of the Commission and when dealing with demarcation disputes the Commission will be able to change union rules permanently to give effect to its decisions. It will also have the discretion to allow the Australian Council of Trade Unions to settle a demarcation dispute before using its own powers. A previous speaker in this debate talked about demarcation disputes, instancing something in the motor vehicle industry. In doing so he proved to all and sundry that he just does not know what a demarcation dispute is about. He probably would not recognise that the vast majority-and I hazard a guess that it would be 90 per cent to 95 per cent-of demarcation problems are actually resolved before they earn the title of dispute with time being lost from work. The Government has thought ahead about that and has taken it into account in framing this Bill.

A lot of emphasis has been given to what the Government has done with respect to giving the Commission the ability to deal with claims for payment when employees have taken industrial action because of a justifiable concern about their health and safety, which is the responsibility of their employer. We have not said that in every instance when a claim for lost wages is made following strike activity there will be payment. Indeed, it would be irresponsible to do so. There are not too many union officials-and I know quite a few-who would actually follow through and say that we should do that in this legislation. The Government has taken the responsible attitude on this matter and has given the Commission the ability to examine the claims that are made. If it considers that a claim is fair, it can offer to make payment-it can order that payment be made for the time lost with respect to a dispute. Industry, including the building industry, is still a very hazardous area in which some people spend a great deal of their lives. In fact, about one-third of their lives is spent working in industry. There are many hazards, and anyone who has spent time in industry has the scars to prove it.

The Bill also deals with the question of amalgamation and, in fact, makes it easier to amalgamate. It sets a limit on the number of members who can be in a union registered by the Commission. Initially, the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems recommended-and indeed this was provided in the first Bill-a minimum level of 1,000 members. This Bill raises that level to 3,000 members apart from exceptional or special circumstances. In taking this action we are addressing a problem that has been vocalised to the Government and to the community continuously by employers, employees, employee organisations, Opposition spokespersons and by all and sundry including the trade union movement.

There are far too many unions in Australia. By undertaking this action we are allowing smaller organisations-in many cases they do not have the ability or the assets to look after themselves or service the needs of members-to come together and service the needs of the membership. There will be an easing of the restrictions on the amalgamation of unions and on how the voting on amalgamations will occur. The requirement for amalgamation ballots will also be eased where a community of interest has been declared. While at present 50 per cent of the members of each of the relevant unions are required to vote in order for the ballot to be valid in such a circumstance, in future only 25 per cent of members will be required to vote. Those who know anything about trade unions would recognise that 25 per cent is still a difficult target to achieve. Those of us who have played a role in union elections from time to time would know how difficult that is.

There is also very specific reference in the Bill to the rules of organisations. There have been abuses previously by some not too reputable unions and mistakes have been made by reputable unions. The Government is addressing this under the clauses dealing with the rules of an organisation. The compliance provisions, which are continually raised by senators opposite, are retained in this Bill even though there are some people in this Parliament and in the trade union movement who wish perhaps that we could have addressed this matter in another way; in fact, who wish that we could have removed the provision which makes clear the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act-that is, they believe that the infamous sections 45d and 45e and the associated enforcement provisions should not override what is contained in the Bill. We say that they would be better served under the labour court, but unfortunately that is not to be the case and we accept that.

I want to address some of the points that Senator Chaney, the Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations, emphasised in his speech. He made a comparison of statistics on industrial disputes in Australia with those from the International Labour Organisation (ILO) year book of 1987. He put great emphasis on those statistics. The implication was that Australia, in international terms, is pretty bloody-minded when it comes to industrial activity. On the bland figures that Senator Chaney recited in this chamber and on the document he had incorporated in Hansard, it does look pretty bad. It looks very sick indeed. But Senator Chaney failed to tell us about the different methods of collecting statistics in the countries that supplied them to the International Labour Organisation. Many different methods are used. There are no consistent criteria in those countries for the collection of the statistics. Merely comparing the strike data is an inadequate method of determining whether a country has a high incidence of industrial disputation. What is counted as a strike in Australia is not necessarily counted as a strike in Japan.

Let me enlarge on that. In France, Japan, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, about which we have heard something, and the United States of America a political stoppage is not included. A political stoppage such as the one related to the late Clarrie O'Shea in 1969, the Medibank stoppages in 1976, and the 54b stoppages in Western Australia in 1979 would not be included in those countries but they are in Australia. Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan, Norway and Sweden do not include in their statistics the lay-offs and those workers in the same firm who are indirectly affected.

It is quite clear to anybody who wants to follow this through and accurately report on the statistics that the fact that Australia does not include such workers industrial disputes data relatively inflates the dimensions of the stoppages. That makes Australia look particularly bad, of course.

The figures I am referring to and the analysis I am putting comes from an excellent discussion paper prepared by John J. Beggs and Bruce J. Chapman from the Australian National University Centre for Economic Policy Research entitled Australia's Strike Activity in International Context: 1964-1985, Discussion Paper No. 159. They reached some conclusions in an in depth analysis of what happened. Because it is a lengthy paper, I shall only quote in part from their conclusions. The major findings are as follows:

If the Australian industrial relations system had been hypothetically transposed to other countries the English speaking and Southern European countries in the sample would have experienced fewer working days lost per employee from strikes than was their actual historical record. Conversely, Northern European countries and Japan would have experienced higher levels of industrial disputation with the Australian system than was the case.

A lot more needs to be said on this point than has been being said up to this time. I shall cite some more statistics to reinforce my point about the record of the Hawke Government. The annual average of working days lost per thousand employees over the period 1976 to 1982 was 591 under the prime ministership of Malcolm Fraser. Under the Hawke Government the annual average of working days lost per thousand employees from 1983 to 1987 was 238. Even using the inflated system which the Australian Bureau of Statistics uses, that is a 60 per cent change over that period. That proves to one and all that this Government has the runs on the board. It still has a lot to do, but certainly the runs are there. It is something we can rightly be proud of, although there is no question that there is still a lot of work to be done.

I opened my contribution tonight with some criticisms of the one-sided debate. I think it is unfortunate that that was the case, but it was not unexpected. I, with a number of others, studied with interest the Liberal Party industrial relations policy which was released just a couple of months ago. The release of the policy document attracted minimal attention from the media outlets in this country; it got a little attention but not a tremendous amount. It was not newsworthy. It did not change a great deal. The Opposition parties, in 5 1/2 years of sitting on the Opposition benches, have really learned nothing. They are hell bent on confrontation. Although it has not been mentioned tonight it does pay us to go back 12 months and recall the words of John Howard, who said that there would be a thousand more Mudginberris. That was not a promise of conflict resolution or of dispute settlement but a promise of confrontation. Unfortunately, that has been reinforced in this very worthwhile but absolutely one-sided debate this evening.

I conclude by trying to define the power of union officials. For those who do not know or understand industrial relations or do not know union officials, the Opposition often distorts the power that union officials have. Indeed, very recently in this chamber Senator Stone made some remarks about a comrade and colleague and friend of mine, Jack Marks, who is State secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. Jack has been known from time to time as Back to work Jack. He spends most of his time in the resolution of disputes, in conflict with his membership. What he sees as responsible action in getting a dispute resolved is not always seen that way by the membership, the workers he represents. It is unfortunate that those things get distorted from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. Perhaps I ought to commence my speech on this legislation with excerpts of comments that were made by Alfred Deakin during the second reading debate on the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill 1904. He, typical of the optimism that was current at that time, said during his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Bill is to peremptorily forbid strikes and lock-outs. What is the radical reform which this measure, if passed, will effect? There will be no more strikes or lock-outs.

The other great proponent of the legislation, H. B. Higgins, also had equal expectations for what he described as the `new province for law and order' that the Bill was supposed to usher in in the field of industrial relations.

I wonder what would be the thoughts of those gentlemen if they could be reincarnated in this great country of ours and see the mess, the imbroglio, the confusion that has been wreaked upon the Australian society and the industrial relations system generally as a result of a lack of resolution and commitment by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would endorse it.

—If Senator Cook is telling me that Alfred Deakin would endorse it, his history is very poor. His knowledge of the history of politics is fundamentally skewed. There is no prospect that Alfred Deakin would ever endorse anything this socialist Government has cast upon the community like a scourge, or a black cloud. The chief objectives of the founding fathers have not been achieved. There is no prospect of their being achieved under this Government. The vast majority of Australians-in my view, all responsible Australians-recognise that our conciliation and arbitration system, as instigated in 1904, is in dire need of reform, of rewriting and perhaps of reconstruction.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Relations Bill 1988, I take it, is the Government's acknowledgment that there is something fundamentally wrong with the industrial relations system. I take it that this legislation is the Government's aborted attempt to reform the mess of our industrial relations system. Anybody who runs a casual eye over the legislation will see that it does little more than tinker with the system. Sadly, for all of us, it represents a failed opportunity to institute the progressive restructuring of the industrial relations system that is required if we are to enter the twenty-first century in a competitive way. This Bill is the epitome of the ultimate capitulation by this Government to its masters, the trade union movement, to wit the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), Mr Crean and Mr Kelty being its leading lights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Crean and Kelty are great Australians.

—If Senator Cook can look back upon their performance, their record, the runs they have put on the board for industrial relations over the last decade and tell me that they are great Australians, I would find it difficult to guess how he would judge an ordinary man. This Bill is the result of craven cowering by a weak, pathetic government bending before the demands of the labour movement. I can assume only that this Government is not, through this legislation, writing industrial relations Bills that are designed to provide incentive for the work force, for productivity, for the benefit of the individual, the corporation or the firm. It is not seeking to dismantle the rigidity which presently exists right throughout the industrial relations system. This legislation is a reflection of the obsequious, sycophantic fashion in which this Government bends before the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will do two things, if nothing else-perhaps on the part of the ACTU by design rather than by accident. It will certainly guarantee the continuation of the distortions which riddle the industrial relations system and perpetuate the imbalance in responsibilities which, I suspect, is the cause of the cavalier and irresponsible conduct we see in some sections of the union movement, perhaps epitomised by Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets.

We are debating this Bill at a time when the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), in its recently released economic survey for Australia, has called for greater flexibility in our internal labour market. That need has been recognised by all responsible commentators for a long time. It was initiated and articulated by the Opposition a long time ago. The OECD survey concludes that `Australia's present union structure, management methods, narrow work classifications and restrictive work practices have reduced labour market flexibility within the firm'. I suspect that nobody, including Senator Cook, would dispute that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we are moving to remedy that. Look at the last couple of national wage case decisions, aimed at remedying that type of problem by allowing direct negotiation at work face level between the unions in the workplace and productivity give-backs for wage increases. You are speaking about a bygone era, not about modern Australia. Hunt the right wing low road if you wish, but it is irrelevant to modern perspectives in industrial relations.

—It is important that that interjection get in the Hansard. If Senator Cook is calling the certified agreement provisions in the legislation opting out, if he is calling them direct negotiations, if he is telling me that they are in some way deregulating the system--
—Yes.

—I am absolutely staggered that Senator Cook is putting that proposition to the Australian people. If we look at the table prepared by the Confederation of Australian Industry showing unit labour costs for Australia and other OECD countries from 1975 to 1988, we see that unit labour costs in Australia have increased annually at a far greater rate-in some years by three times as much-than those in other OECD countries. I apologise for not having shown this table to Senator Cook, but I ask for leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—If Senator Crichton-Browne will pass it over, I will have a look at it.

—I thank Senator Cook. While he is running his eyes over a pedestrian document which is available to everybody from the Parliamentary Library, I will press on in the presumption that commonsense will prevail in due course. The present centralised system of conciliation and arbitration and wage fixing sacrifices the higher productivity which could otherwise be achieved by Australian business enterprises-productivity which is desperately needed, given the size of our current account deficit and external debt. I have some other statistics which I will come to shortly. Perhaps Senator Cook would be kind enough to allow me to have them incorporated in Hansard, too, otherwise I will have to make a mental note about the next time somebody on his side seeks to have something incorporated in Hansard. Our work and management practices must change. This necessarily involves a shift away from the determination of wages and conditions at a national level and an adjustment to negotiation at an enterprise level.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to clause 181 of the Bill, the bans clause. Surely nobody would seriously argue that sanctions do not have a role in any conciliation and arbitration system. But for sanctions to be effective, for sanctions to have authority, for the system to be maintained and to continue to receive the support and respect of both sides, those sanctions have to be relevant. To this end, perhaps one of the more positive aspects of the Bill in its 1987 draft -that seems a long time away now-was the proposed new directions and injunctions procedure. It was anticipated-not by us in full but primarily by the Government-that this procedure would remedy the selective compliance with which unions tend to treat directions and orders of the Commission. For a recent example of unwillingness on the part of unions to accept the decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, we need look no further than Mudginberri, the dispute in which the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union refused to accept the initial orders of the Commission. The Dollar Sweets case, which I think Senator Short was the first to raise in the Parliament, was also one in which the union paid absolutely no heed to the recommendations of the Commission to lift the picket lines. The Supreme Court stated in the latter case:
Instead they, as it was put, thumbed their noses at the Commission and continued with their picketing and illegal practices, apparently aware that the Commission is powerless to apply any sanction.

Despite some very obvious flaws in the proposed directions procedure, for example the delays implicit between the breach of Commission directions and the injunctive relief, the proposal was at least a relatively effective mechanism for the enforcement of the Commission's decisions because there was a substantial penal provision.

Senator Chaney previously introduced a Bill into this chamber for the purpose of instituting a more streamlined version of the directions and injunctions process without the perceived defects of the Government's 1987 legislation. I have not seen the amendments but the thrust is apparent to me. The contents of Senator Chaney's Conciliation and Arbitration (Compliance Provisions) Amendment Bill form a substantial part of the coalition's amendments that will be moved in the committee stage. The interesting thing is that the reason for the new directions procedure was outlined by Mr Willis in his second reading speech on the 1987 Bill. He said:

The principal initiative is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne, you asked previously to have a document incorporated. There is no objection, and it shall be incorporated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Growth in labour costs in Australia over and above the growth in labour costs elsewhere puts downward pressure on the exchange rate. It may be impossible to specify with any precision when the exchange rate will fall, but if an economy persistently runs more rapid increases in labour costs, eventually the value of its currency will fall.

That is why international comparisons of unit labour costs add an important dimension to an understanding of Australia's economic problems. Such a comparison suggests very strongly that the dollar will remain under pressure because, as the data in Table 1 show, Australia's unit labour costs have been rising more rapidly than those throughout the OECD.
