The type of analysis shown in the table is, it needs to be stressed, only a rough estimate of the underlying reality. To begin with it is not the OECD alone that is our major trade partner nor is it our major trade competitor. Even within the OECD, some relatively smaller economies are more important than others to Australia. For example, New Zealand, while small by OECD standards, is a very important trading partner for Australia.
There are, moreover, other economies outside the OECD which compete on the same markets as Australia and with which we trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the 1988 version of the Bill we now see the deletion of that directive process and the retention of the bans clause procedures. One is tempted to ask what has changed. Presumably the bans clause provisions remain in disrepute. The proposition that is put to us by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is that the blame lies with the employers. Only the most obscure logic and the most fertile mind could come up with that proposition. The Minister, in his 1988 second reading speech, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considered that the employers' intransigent opposition to these provisions-
that is, removing access to common law remedies-

had the capacity to undermine the parties' commitment to, and the public's confidence in, the new industrial relations system. It therefore decided to remove the proposed compliance package from the legislation and to preserve the system which currently exists.

As Senator Chaney quite correctly pointed out in his second reading speech on his compliance provisions Bill, however, the retention of the employers' right to access to common law remedies had already been traded off against removal of the increased monetary penalties against unions for non-compliance. Some months later, Mr Willis continued to stress that a directions process would be maintained in the redrafted Bill. Of course the distinction between the two, even with the penalties removed, is that at least with the directions provision, as distinct from the bans clause, one could expect some quicker action. But the Minister has now changed his mind even on that matter. Once the ACTU applied pressure, that was the end of the matter. The upshot is that our industrial relations system remains afflicted with, to quote the Minister, a `substantially moribund' procedure which is generally in a state of disuse.

I note that of the 154 notifications lodged with the Commission under the existing bans clause provisions in the 17 years to June 1987, only 35 were lodged in the last 10 years. What is the message in that? The message is that it is a total waste of time to seek any relief from the bans clause. Despite the attempts made to rationalise the bans clause procedure in division 2 of part VIII of the Bill, it remains hopelessly cumbersome. It in no way overcomes or provides substantial relief for the very considerable delays-notwithstanding the fact that there are no great penalties. One has only to look at the penalties to see how absurd it is-between $500 and $1,000. The provisions contained in clause 181, subclauses 3 and 4, show the whole process that has to be instigated before any relief can ultimately be found under clause 178. Having finally achieved that, the relief is found not to be of any substance.

I turn to discuss the procedure contained in clause 115 of the Bill, whereby the parties to a dispute may apply to the Commission for fixed term certified agreements. I think that is what Senator Cook was referring to earlier on when he was talking about some flexibility in the labour market. It is a Clayton's opting out provision. It is a provision, as the Government might call it, for direct negotiations-but it really amounts to nothing. So many caveats are included in the provision that it is almost ineffectual. Under section 45d, when the parties are seeking to make applications for a certificate there is a provision for the unions to be party to the hearing. At any time the conditions are subject to public interest and, presumably, public interest is not looking at the larger macroeconomic considerations but at whether it impinges on the general system of industrial relations and on industrial relations harmony.

The Minister may at any time apply to the President for a review by a full bench of the operation of the agreement. The Commission may, on application under a further subsection, being party to the agreement, set the agreement aside. So we have a whole series of processes that, in the end, water down the provision so that ultimately it amounts to absolutely nothing. The policy of the Opposition is to achieve cooperation and a flexible approach with individual enterprises. It is our view that employees and employers should be free as mature people to negotiate directly with each other on wages and conditions which are compatible with the aspirations, views and wishes of both parties. To ensure that there is no exploitation, however that might happen in this modern day and age, of mature men--

TALK.START.PARA: —And women.

—Yes, and women-there is a proposal in our legislation to provide at least the relevant minimum award wage. It is interesting to note that the coalition policy is supported in this regard by recommendation 21 of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems report, which proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . parties who wish to make their own arrangements for the prevention and settlement of disputes by conciliation and arbitration may do so, and that the terms and conditions of employment resulting from those agreed arrangements would be able to operate to the exclusion of Federal awards and State prescriptions. The legislation should ensure that parties who choose to follow this approach do so as a basis for the regulation of all industrial matters involved.

Of course the Government simply rejected that out of hand because it was incompatible with the wants of the monolithic ACTU. The Minister tried to justify flying in the face of logic and in the face of a recommendation of the Hancock report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want the whole Hancock report?
—I have the whole Hancock report.
—Do you want us to adopt the lot?

—No. I am saying, Senator Cook, that the Government sought to pick out certain sections that have general direction while removing one which has suddenly become a hurdle or a barrier. The Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government views this recommendation as being totally contrary to the overall direction supported by the Hancock Committee elsewhere in its report. Such `opting out' arrangements would undermine the proposed institutional framework of the new Industrial Relations Commission . . .
As far as Hancock was concerned, it would not, but as far as the Government is concerned, of course, it would. It would dismantle this centralised monolithic system. The Minister continued:

This would encourage the growth of a `black market' conciliation and arbitration industry which would not be required to pay any attention to the public interest, and would be likely to lead to economically disastrous sweetheart deals for some, and sweatshop deals for others.

In other words, the Minister does not trust the market. He does not trust the maturity of employees, individually or collectively, to negotiate with employers. The fact that the Government dismissed that proposal is hardly surprising. The offhand way in which it did so is typically arrogant, and a well-known hallmark of the Government. The Government's rejection ignores the fundamental benefits which could flow from opting out which were identified by Hancock. At page 367 of volume 2 of the report the Committee stated:

The industrial relations benefits are seen to be the greater commitment which arises from agreement, whilst the economic benefits are seen to reside in the right of the parties to fix wages and conditions in the light of specific economic capacity.

I would have thought that, by any measure, that is the criteria by which negotiations of this nature ought to be taking place. Of course, Hancock also pointed to the provisions of part X of the present Act which already provides for industrial agreements, but which are overriden by Federal awards. His committee made the obvious observation that such provisions have been in the Act since 1904. Accordingly, with a great deal of perception, the Committee noted that it has always been the intention of the Parliament that individuals be entitled to make their own arrangements for conciliation and arbitration without the dead hand of some other overriding group. The use of voluntary agreements, which we propose, has the support of Hancock. I believe it to be a very sensible and responsible step towards decentralised and enterprise oriented industrial relations.

I turn to clause 122, which vests power in the Commission to direct that preference be given to union members. This clause is almost, if not entirely, identical to that which presently exists in the legislation. The truth is that in some cases it makes preference clauses compulsory. Clause 122 (2) of the Bill states:
Whenever, in the opinion of the Commission, it is necessary-
It lists paragraphs (a) to (d) and then states:
. . . to direct that preference shall be given to members of organisations as provided by subsection (1), the Commission shall give the direction.

So it is not an option; there are certain circumstances in which it is compulsory. Anybody who has a spirit, heart or soul for individual rights and responsibilities would find that to be absolutely anathema. Why should anybody who wishes not to be a member of a union be discriminated against? Despite decisions of the High Court refusing power to the Commission to order compulsory unionism, it is estimated by the Business Council of Australia that one-quarter of all Australia's employees are to be found in closed shops. One has only to walk down St George's Terrace in Senator Cook's home town to see signs which state, `No ticket-no start'. In other words, if a person is not prepared to be compulsorily committed to joining a union, paying his dues to the union and having that union commit his money to a political party that may not be of his choice, he will find himself without a job as a result of this legislation given to us by this Government.

I, like all of my colleagues and the vast majority of Australians, am vehemently opposed to compulsory unionism or to compulsory association of any sort. I find it rather cute that this Government has as an intrinsic part of its beliefs the right of all freedoms except when it comes to unionism. Of course, the vast majority of decent Australians endorse the notion that individuals should have a freedom of choice; a freedom that has hitherto been denied in industrial relations, unless that person is prepared to comply with narrow and rigid conscientious objection requirements.

I note that there has been a modest change, from my reading of the legislation, to the extent that the employee has to take objection to only the union itself. He can obtain exemption by way of certification, but the certification lasts only for 12 months. He must go back 12 months later and convince the Commission that he still conscientiously objects to being a member of a union. Just in case he has had a change of heart, it keeps him on a string and says, `Come back in 12 months time and tell us whether you still feel the same. If you do, we'll give you relief. If you don't, you'll get no relief'. I ask: Is that fair dinkum Australian? Surely, it is acceptable that if a trade union provides the services, benefits and goods, if it provides the virtues of its being, it will not need compulsorily to acquire members; they will flock to it. They will join it because they want to. Of course, neither the Government nor the unions are game, prepared or even tempted to test themselves in the marketplace. They are determined to ensure that people will compulsorily join unions; otherwise they will not work in Australian society. That is the tragedy of this Government.

I see that my time has almost expired. I have many more exciting things to say. I will save them for the committee stage. I say to the Government that it is making a grave mistake with this legislation. It flies in the face of the views of all decent Australians, most of all, the views of all working Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 it is very clear that, no matter how much we have tried to reach some compromise with the Opposition, that has been impossible. Obviously, it still believes that the only way to reach any sort of proper industrial relations agreement is by way of a system of penalties and the big stick. This highlights two things about the Opposition: firstly, it is totally and absolutely devoid of any real ideas or vision and simply wants to turn back the clock to the old, worn out approach to industrial relations and industrial development; and, secondly, it is very clear, having regard to the policies that it is espousing, that it has come completely under the control of the extreme right wing H. R. Nicholls Society.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, the motivation for the extreme views of the Opposition is an absolute dislike of workers and a desire to ensure that the people of this country are denied any real say in the use of this country's resources. If we really needed any proof of that all we would need to do would be to recall the opening day of Parliament when the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Fred Chaney, spoke to the motion of thanks for those who worked on the new Parliament House. Even then he could not resist the temptation to attack building workers who had been involved in the construction of this building.

When people on the opposite side talk about industrial disputes, they ought to consider that, as has been said before in this debate, many of those disputes are about safety issues. I doubt whether Opposition senators have ever worked in industry, particularly in the construction industry or the mining industry, as those on this side have. None of them has ever experienced a work mate being electrocuted or killed beside him or underground--(Quorum formed) It is interesting to note that when honourable senators opposite are reminded how little they know of what it is actually like to work in industry, they become rather testy about it.

The underlying purpose of the legislation which I turn to now is to ensure that the overall package of measures that has been put in place by this Government, by the trade union movement and by employers continues in such a way as to further the progress already made to revitalise Australian industry. I think it is important to note that the people involved in this new positive approach towards the development of industry in Australia are the trade unions, the Federal Government, industry, the Public Service and, in particular, those in the education sector. Sadly, there is an absence of any input from the Opposition. Many of the new initiatives in the industry development arena stem from the proposals of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in its document entitled Australia Reconstructed. The basis of the new direction for Australian industry is built around a more cooperative approach rather than the previous `them and us' attitude in the development of the industrial relations area. Tonight time will not permit me to detail all the aspects of Australia Reconstructed but at this stage I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that a consolidation of Australia Reconstructed has been produced by the Trade Union Community Research Centre Inc. in Tasmania and, at this stage, I seek leave to have that summary incorporated in Hansard. If that sort of summary were in Hansard it would give people opposite the opportunity to have a look, in some concise way, at what is contained in Australia Reconstructed as, clearly, many of them have never read it. I seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Not until I have seen it. Not until the document, by courtesy, has been shown to me.
—Leave is not granted at this stage. The honourable senator may ask again later.

—Clearly, there is a need for more productive and efficient industries in Australia. That is recognised in Australia Reconstructed and I believe that it is recognised by the great majority of people throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Productivity can be improved only if all sectors recognise the need for old divisions between workers and management to be broken down. It is also essential that, in doing that, the rights of workers, through their unions, in the development and implementation of industry policy be recognised and accepted. None of these things can be achieved if community leaders continue to make divisive public comments based simply on blind ideology rather than on solid, well thought out policies designed to benefit industry in this country and to develop industrial relations generally.

One of the problems that is always thrown up by people is the problem of restrictive work practices in industry. Of course, none of us could deny that those restrictive work practices exist. I think it must be recognised that they have existed and that they still exist on both sides-workers and management. Of course, many of the more enlightened employers have already recognised that, through old and outdated management policies, they have not been reaching their greatest efficiency. They have looked at the problems that they have had with their middle and lower management systems and there has been an exchange of information with those on the workshop floor and with people at other management levels. In the past in many industries-unfortunately this still exists-the exchange of information has been absolutely nil.

Before we really progress in the area of industry development and industry relations there has to be a recognition at the management and community level of the accumulated knowledge and skills of workers on the workshop floor. From that point on if we do that we will then have a natural move towards the breakdown of many of the barriers that have been the problems we have been facing in industry up until this point in time. In bringing together this whole process one of the essential elements is to provide the opportunity for workers at all levels to continually update and increase their skills.

Those who have worked in industry would be well aware of the fact that some of those barriers exist for tradespeople who face extreme difficulties in being able to progress up to engineering levels. We have put all sorts of stupid barriers in front of them. People on the workshop floor who may have come in as trade assistants have been barred by the very nature of some of the courses that we run from progressing up to trade level. I think they are questions that we need to address and it has got to be done by all sectors of industry not simply just one. In combination with that we also need to recognise the need to increase our manufacturing capacity by processing much more of our raw materials and reaping some real benefit in this country from them instead of the old method of virtually giving them away to other countries.

It is a sad fact that in Australia the only people who seem to fail to recognise these facts are those people in the Opposition who still seem to have the old outdated view that the only wisdom in industry is that contained in the boardrooms of big business. One of the most essential elements of this Bill is the move to make amalgamation of unions easier and it is very clear that we cannot afford, in this country, to continue with the overlap of trade union resources and the hundreds of both federally and State-wide registered unions that currently exist. In the past, it has been extremely difficult under legislation for amalgamation to take place because not only have we had to have 50 per cent of the union membership vote to effect an amalgamation, but also there had to be over 50 per cent in favour of the amalgamation. Anyone who knows anything about trade union affairs and the history of voting at trade union elections would recognise the fact that very rarely in trade union elections does one get any more than about a 45 per cent return in ballots. That in itself was an extremely great barrier to overcome when unions were seeking to amalgamate.

In my view we should move to the situation where there are about 40 unions in this country. Of course if we do that it will provide not only much greater services to individual members of unions-many services that are not recognised by the general community such as legal advice from people who are on workers compensation and those sorts of things-but also people will not be required to pay such high union dues. It also will allow for much more efficiency in the way that unions can conduct research and from there provide a much greater input into the industrial development of this country.

Let us just look for a second or two at some of the policies espoused by the Opposition in this area. Quite clearly, it will lead to the sort of deregulation that the Opposition is putting forward. Very clearly, instead of some 300 unions in this country, we will probably end up with another couple of hundred. If anyone believes that a move to that sort of situation will solve any industrial problems in this country, well then simply he is quite crazy. If we move in that direction we will simply have workers again paying for the inefficiency of management. We will not be moving down the track that has been put forward by this Government and the ACTU of trying to create much more efficient business and management practices.

Again, a proposal that has been put forward in many countries and in many other places in that people in the workplace ought to take out shares or be given shares in companies they are working for. Quite clearly it has failed in other places. In a very short space of time workers are not reaping any benefits at all from those shares because they have got rid of them and such shares are of no long term benefit at all to the workers concerned. The truth is that there is nothing that can substitute for real cooperation and input to industry through a genuine tripartite approach which is the proposition being put forward by this Government by the trade union movement, and by many employers.

In the proposal that has been put forward by this Government and the unions, nobody has suggested that they will meet and cure all of the economic ills of this country in one instant. Quite clearly it is a much more appropriate way and has much more of a chance of working than the old outdated methods that we have previously been operating under. As I see that it is almost 10.30, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will simply conclude by quoting a passage out of Australia Reconstructed which I think really sums up the current situation we are in. It states that Australia Reconstructed is not a blueprint or solution to our economic problem but that it is an approach, a process and an opportunity. I simply conclude by saying that if we do not accept that opportunity and if we do not accept that challenge then we will all have failed in the area of industrial development in this country and in the whole area of industrial relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 which has been brought forward by the Government. Many of my colleagues have already indicated quite strongly the Opposition's objections to the Bill. They have been quite extensive as is seen from the number of amendments which will be put forward, some 50 or more I think from the Opposition, together with a number of amendments from the Australian Democrats, and I think some from the Government itself.

SPEECH.PARA: In our opinion the Bill is significantly flawed in a number of respects. It does not provide for the enforcement by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of its own rulings. It does nothing to prevent compulsory unionism, it attempts to override State legislation; and it proposes the amalgamation of smaller unions into a small number of super unions which will ultimately give more power in certain hands. I wish to contribute to this debate because, being a representative from the Australian Capital Territory, I can talk of what in fact has occurred in the ACT over the five years that this Government has been in power. It has been five years during which time in the ACT we have also had five separate Ministers.

In the ACT the Government has specifically had the power and responsibility to look after industrial relations unfettered by any State legislation. Its failure to do so, in any significant way, I think gives a very good reason for discussing industrial relations as they have occurred in those five years in the ACT and drawing conclusions from those discussions. It highlights also the weaknesses in this Bill when we in fact look at what has occurred in the ACT. Senator Devereux, speaking last for the Government, said in part in his debate that amongst the Opposition senators there showed a dislike of workers. That is not true; that is not the case. We are concerned for workers, for their families, their children, and their ability to get on with their lives, and we are concerned about the Government's attitude to industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity tonight to share a few impressions that I have about this place at the end of one and a half weeks and I wish then to make a recommendation that I hope the President will take favourably. It seemed to me, that at the end of my first week here I could categorise my impressions under three headings. First, there is the overall impression of this building, which I find quite marvellous, particularly its height, space and natural light. I also like the way one can turn a corner and suddenly be struck by yet another delightful piece of architecture, whether it be in the shape of the windows or the pattern of glass, construction materials or whatever. I find a lot of the work very exciting indeed. I particularly like the way in which from many angles and places one can see most of Canberra. Furthermore, anyone who wanders around this place will know what a feast of art and craft is set out in this building. As a senator from South Australia, I am particularly delighted at some of the wonderful contributions from that State. I have in mind some of the tapestries and carpets, and in particular the embroidery organised and overseen by Kay Lawrence from South Australia, who is also responsible for the wonderful tapestry in the Prime Minister's suite. I do not want to go into that aspect at great length, but it is a topic we will be able to talk about as we discover more and more features of this building after we occupy it for longer.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I notice that many of the lifts in this building are still lined with some kind of protective material because much material is being moved in the lifts other than people. I have had occasion to use one lift that is still lined with packing case wood. The lift contains very much evidence of the talents of the construction workers in the way of graffiti, much of which would not bear repeating in this place. But if anybody discovers the same lift as I did, they can no doubt entertain themselves in the way I have. I was particularly struck by one piece of graffiti.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it good enough for an Australia Council grant?

—Now, Senator Puplick, just listen! One piece of graffiti in the lift that I found particularly interesting, spread as it was among all the other contributions, read `His dogma ran over my Karma'. I found quite delightful that little piece of graffiti, intelligent as it is, stuck on the wall of a lift and I did not expect to find it in the new Parliament House.
—Don't put down the intellect of the Australian worker.

—I was not. In fact, I was just commemorating it. The title for a new book might be `Life behind the fire doors'. No doubt many other people besides myself have rushed up to a fire door and found explicit instructions of what will happen to us if we do the wrong thing with the fire door, but with no understanding that behind the fire door is a committee room, corridor or any of the other facilities we sometimes need. I congratulate all the people around here who have displayed a remarkable tolerance in assisting us-and I suppose some of us have shown great tolerance, too-in getting through the first week, including a considerable number of hiccups involving fallen door handles, failing lights and so on. I wish particularly to acknowledge the patience of our Whip. I suspect similar acknow- ledgment is also due to the staff of the Whips of the other parties, but certainly our Whip's clerk found herself without a clock and lights in easy vision and it put extra strains on her. I wish to commend our Whip's clerk for her tolerance.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw to your attention, Mr President, the main point I wish to make this evening. From the front of this Parliament House we gaze at the War Memorial, and listed there are the names of everybody who gave their lives for peace. I find it impressive on the occasions I visit the War Memorial to walk among those names. Others who have visited the War Memorial feel as I do, and that is that there is something very moving and impressive about that simple, uncluttered list of names. It is in some ways very much a monument to peace. At least, it tries to remind us of the price of peace and records the names of all those who gave their lives for peace.

During the opening ceremonies of this Parliament it was said that this place is the symbol of democracy. I would like to see listed in a public place the names of all those who built this symbol of democracy. Not only should we list the names of those who fought for peace, but I should like to see listed the names of those who build democracy, or at least its great symbol. I would like to see listed the names of every one of those people who contributed in any way to the construction of this Parliament House-whether pourers of concrete, runners of electric wire, plumbers, carpenters, gardeners or whatever. I should like to know that all those names were listed in a place that people who visited here could easily see and have access to. It would be splendid if in years to come anybody who had a hand in the construction of this building could bring their families, relatives, sons and daughters and say to them, `Listed there is my name showing that I contributed to the construction of this place'. Often we forget to acknowledge the contribution of those builders-and I include the huge list of workers, which I shall not go through now.

I should also like to see listed under the embroidery I mentioned earlier the names of all the embroiderers-I think essentially women, though I am not absolutely sure of that-who placed the stitches on that tapestry and who produced the quite remarkable embroidery that runs along the first floor wall in the Great Hall. Again, I would have thought that any number of people would be pleased and proud to bring their families to Parliament House so that they could say `There is where I sewed the grain of wheat or stitched the house' or whatever. I think that in those ways we could add to the acknowledgment of people who contributed to this place. We have plaques to acknowledge the famous and recognisable artists, artisans and crafts people, but I would like to see the same kind of recognition given to the less famous who contributed so much to the making of the embroidery and also to the building of this place. I would be pleased, Mr President, to hear your consideration of my proposal at some stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to touch on two matters. The first relates to an answer given by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to Senator Beahan, a Labor senator from Western Australia, during Question Time today, given of course that Senator Walsh is also a Western Australian. The question related to some correspondence that took place between myself and the Hon. J. C. Kerin, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in which I made representations on behalf of a constituent in Western Australia in respect of both drought relief and cyclone assistance. The representation was made on behalf of a gentleman who shares the distinction with eight other pastoralists in the East Gascoyne region of Western Australia, their having been coincidentally affected and afflicted by a number of years of devastating droughts and then a dry cyclone. Senator Walsh thought it very amusing that I should take the trouble to make representations on behalf of these constituents, whom I presumed until today were the joint constituents of Senator Walsh and Senator Beahan and me.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh thought it very amusing that these souls should be beseeching me to make representations on their behalf for drought relief and for cyclone assistance at the same time. I can only assume that this was a cheap shot at me or that Senator Walsh was basking in the total ignorance which is enshrined in most of his answers at Question Time. The Agricultural Department of Western Australia and the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy have made available natural disaster relief for pastoral areas for 1987 and 1988. They make the obvious point, sadly, in the guidelines:

Note: Several pastoral properties which were declared both drought affected and cyclone Herbie affected are not eligible for both drought and cyclone transport subsidies, that is the maximum allowable subsidies of $40,000 under Cyclone Herbie will apply.

That is true of other relief guidelines. These people have suffered far greater afflictions than those caused by one cyclone or a two- or three-year drought. As a result of the drought there has been an enormous amount of wind erosion which has devastated their feed, devastated their windmills, devastated their wells, devastated their fences and destroyed their stock. The relief conditions mean that they are unable to claim or seek assistance greater than that which would apply to somebody who has one bad drought season.

The Department acknowledges that there are people in this circumstance and it includes in its correspondence a list of pastoral leases in arid pastoral zones declared both drought and cyclone Herbie affected. Whilst Senator Walsh may be amused by that, I am sure that these nine people are not, nor are those on the fringe, and nor are those within the immediate region of the eastern Gascoyne. I no longer find it distressing or disappointing nor, if I reflect, surprising, but I find it politically amazing that Senator Walsh would demonstrate mirth when these people's livelihoods, which as I was moved to observe in a personal explanation this afternoon have been created and developed over their lifetime and the lifetime of their parents, can in two short years be absolutely destroyed. Senator Walsh thinks that is very funny; funny enough for a run in the Parliament in Question Time today. He pointed his crooked finger to a provision which says that the relief is not available if the pastoralists have any assets `off farm'. The purists might argue that that is a reasonable proposition but, by way of example, if a pastoralist and his wife own a timber or asbestos home in the Perth metropolitan area so that the wife can live in Perth to mother her children and provide them with an equal opportunity for education, that asset has to be sold, dissolved, liquidated and provided against the property before the loan is made available. There are those who might say that is very reasonable. I have to say that I think it is very unreasonable. I want the record to be clear as to the position of these people and Senator Walsh's position.

In Question Time today I was moved by an article from a Sunday paper in Western Australia to ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health, the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), whether it was the Government's intention to reverse its decision to delist 53 drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Senator Cook answered that question with one word. He said, `No', and felt comfortable enough to sit down. I draw to the Senate's attention a rather large and flamboyant headline in a Sunday paper in Western Australia which says, `I'll swing drugs change: Wilson'. That is the Hon. Keith Wilson, the Labor Minister for Health in the Western Australian State Government. Mr Wilson said that he is confident that he can convince the Federal Government to change its mind over the supply of vital drugs for heart, cancer and epilepsy patients. Mr Wilson is moved, I assume, to do this not by political expediency but by compassion. His Government set up a hotline and in the first two hours it received 50 calls. The article quotes Mr Wilson as saying:
We are now analysing that information so we can continue to press our arguments on the basis of the problems people are facing.

I can draw from that statement one of two conclusions. I can conclude that Senator Cook misled the Senate or that like Senator Walsh he was basking in ignorance, or I can draw the conclusion that Mr Wilson, for quite political reasons, is cruelly, unkindly and not the least unfairly creating a level of expectation in the community by those who suffer from epilepsy, from heart conditions, or from cancer that they will receive relief from the decision that this Government has made. I hope that Mr Wilson would not do that to the people of Western Australia, that he would not, for instance, give hope to the drug users of Western Australia who are dying of cancer when no relief is to be found by this Government, just as I hope Senator Cook would not mislead the Senate. I imagine that if there is a change to the delisting of the 53 drugs it will be not as a result of Mr Wilson or Senator Cook; it will be as a result of a notice of motion for the disallowance of the regulation given by my colleague Senator Puplick and perhaps as a result-common sense prevailing-of the Australian Democrats joining the Opposition to see those drugs reinstated as they properly should be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.47 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 16 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What level of Federal Government funding, either direct or through staff support, has been provided to the Canberra Festival Committee for each of the last 3 years;
(b) What level of corporate sponsorship has the Canberra Festival Committee attracted in each of the last 3 years;
(c) What events apart from the Canberra Festival are organised by the Canberra Festival Committee;
(d) What considerations are taken into account when appointing the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Administration representative to the Canberra Festival Committee;

(e) Is the ACT Administration representative responsible for ensuring that matters of Government policy, such as restriction on the promotion of tobacco products and sponsorships, are made known to the other members of the Canberra Festival Committee;

(f) Does the ACT Administration routinely make any checks that activities organised by the Canberra Festival Committee do not conflict with Government public health initiatives, or with industry codes or marketing or promotional conduct;

(g) Are there Government guidelines relating to the form of sponsorship which would be inappropriate for the Canberra Festival Committee to accept, or to attached conditions of sponsorship which would be inappropriate;
(h) How regularly is the Canberra Festival Committee required to present public reports on its activities or to otherwise account publicly for its handling of Government funds;
(i) What avenues are there for citizens and residents of Canberra to influence the approach to the question of sponsorship taken by the Canberra Festival Committee.
(2) (a) Is the Minister aware that the Canberra Festival includes many activities of a family nature;
(b) Is the Minister concerned that there is quite blatant promotion of cigarettes at activities which form part of the Canberra Festival, and where large numbers of children are present.
(3) (a) Have any tobacco companies provided sponsorship funding for the 1988 Canberra Festival; if so, upon what conditions have these funds been given or accepted, and what is their extent;
(b) Which brands of cigarettes are being given prominent public exposure during the Canberra Festival, and what is the nature of that exposure;

(c) What steps will the Minister take to ensure that the advertising code for tobacco products will not be breached during any Canberra Festival promotions, in particular, the provisions which forbid promotion to children;
(d) What additional tax-deductible expenditure are tobacco companies expected to incur in the course of their Canberra Festival promotions;
(e) What is the expected publicity value which will be derived by tobacco companies as a result of their Canberra Festival sponsorship and promotional activities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Year...Direct Funding

The ACT Administration provides no direct staff support to the Canberra Festival Committee. However it does assist the Committee to stage the Festival by providing logistical support in a number of areas.

(c) The Committee works with the Executive Director of Australia Day in the National Capital to help organise events on Australia Day. It provides some administrative support on a fee-for-service basis to the Canberra Opera Society.

(d) The person occupying the Division Head position with responsibility for community festivals and special events usually has been appointed. Currently, it is the Director, ACT Parks and Conservation.

(e) The ACT Administration representative's role is to facilitate successful conduct of the Festival and provide effective liaison with the Festival Committee. He would advise on any Government policies relevant to the Committee's activities.
(f) The Committee is not bound by any Government public health initiatives or any industry codes.
(g) No.
(h) The Committee publishes an Annual Report. It also is required to properly acquit each annual Government grant before receiving any further such grant.
(i) Any citizen or resident of Canberra may become a member of Canberra Festival Inc and seek to influence its approach to the question of sponsorship.
(2) (a) Yes.
(b) I would prefer it if tobacco products were not promoted before children. However, the involvement of tobacco companies with the Canberra Festival is limited. See also the answer to 3 (a) and (b).

(3) (a) and (b) The WD & HO Wills company sponsored Jazz during a Mardi Gras at lunchtimes from one stage in Garema Place. A banner with the name of Sterling cigarettes was displayed at the rear of that stage during performances-for a total period during the 10 day Festival of 16 hours. Cigarettes were sold by the company at two events-the Mardi Gras and the Food and Wine Frolic, both of which are principally for adults. The amount of sponsorship monies provided by the company for the 1988 Festival was $10,000.

(c) The code has been developed by Industry and adherence to it is not mandatory. I do not have any power in respect of the code and I do not consider it appropriate to seek to direct the Canberra Festival, particularly as sources of sponsorship are limited.
(d) WD & HO Wills was not required to incur any additional deductible expenditure. Only the company could advise whether any such expenditure was incurred.
(e) This is a matter for the company to determine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does a recent Office of the Supervising Scientist report on Coronation Hill state that there is uranium mineralisation at Coronation Hill.
(2) What deposits of uranium exist at Coronation Hill.
(3) What are the sources of the Minister's information on uranium mineralisation.

(4) Have the Coronation Hill Joint Venturers failed to mention the presence of uranium mineralisation, and the potential radiological hazards associated with it, in any of the documents they have so far produced; if so, why.
(5) How does the Government intend to deal with the uranium mineralisation at Coronation Hill in the light of the Government's `no new uranium mines' policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Supervising Scientist has advised that his office is aware that there are traces of uranium mineralisation at Coronation Hill. There are no reports by the Office of the Supervising Scientist documenting substantial uranium mineralisation at the site.

(2) and (3) Coronation Hill was an operating uranium mine in the 1950s. The Bureau of Mineral Resources has advised that results of intense exploration for uranium in the 1960s and 1970s throughout most of the area now included in the Kakadu Conservation Zone, suggests that there is little likelihood of the existence of additional uranium deposits.

BHP Gold Mines Limited personnel have advised my Department and the Office of the Supervising Scientist that the extensive exploration drilling program undertaken at the site in order to define the gold/platinum resource has not identified any significant uranium mineralisation or uranium deposits. I understand that results of analyses of core samples have shown the levels of uranium mineralisation to be low.

(4) BHP has been asked by the Government to prepare an environmental impact statement for the Coronation Hill project. A preliminary draft of this document provided recently to my Department, the Office of the Supervising Scientist and other government agencies for discussion purposes, did not provide information on the uranium or other mineral content of the ore body or the overburden, or address the potential radiological hazards of mining at Coronation Hill.
I understand that data is still being collected and that these aspects will be addressed in the final draft environmental impact statement to be released for public comment later this year.

(5) My Department in discussions and through the environmental impact statement guidelines that it provided to BHP has asked BHP to ensure that any potential radiological hazards, even if they are very low, are addressed fully in the final draft environmental impact statement.

I can assure you that, in line with current ALP policy, there will be no uranium mining at Coronation Hill. No significant uranium mineralisation has been identified to date. The exploration authority issued recently to BHP, which removed any doubts as to the legality of its work at Coronation Hill, specifically excludes exploration for uranium.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 18 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in the process of revising the Code of Practice on the management of wastes from the mining and milling of radioactive ores and is it a fact that as long ago as January 1982, the environment group, Friends of the Earth, in a submission to the then Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, concluded that the `waste code' as it is now called, ought to have contained, but did not contain, the following:
(a) Maximum permissible transport-rates of contaminants away from the site by wind and water;
(b) maximum permissible gamma radiation levels on site, and at specific distances from the site;
(c) maximum permissible deposition-rates for the material from the site in surrounding areas at various distances, and various directions;
(d) maximum permissible levels for radon and its decay products in air and dust within and outside nearby dwellings;
(e) maximum rates of seepage into acquifiers, and rates and directions of movement of contaminated waters;
(f) methods of dealing with contaminated groundwater;
(g) methods for the construction of tailings dams, ore-piles, waste-rock dumps, etc; and
(h) approved materials and depths of coverage for tailings piles, and their effectiveness in cutting down radon emanation.
(2) Will the Minister give an undertaking that all of the above matters will be open to public comment during the review process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1981 the then Minsiter for Home Affairs and Environment arranged for a proposed `Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Wastes from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores' (the Waste Code) to be made available for public comment. In January 1982 Friends of the Earth provided a submission on the proposed Waste Code. Their submission made a number of suggestions in relation to the proposed Code, including those detailed in parts 1 (a) to 1 (h) of the honourable Senator's question.

These suggestions, along with submissions by other interested parties, were evaluated in the course of finalising the Waste Code which was approved on 26 August 1982 by the Governor-General under sub-section 9 (1) of the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978.

My Department has recently asked the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which chairs the Working Group on this Code, about the possible need for a comprehensive review of the 1982 Waste Code. I expect to be provided with advice about this as soon as the Working Group has been able to consider the matter.

(2) The Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 provides for the formulation of proposed codes of practice or of proposed variations of codes of practice and enable me, as the responsible Minister, to make any such code available for public comment if I think it desirable to do so. It has been the general practice to seek public comment on all new and revised codes since 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Consumer Association (ACA) report on food irradiation recommend that approval should be granted to irradiate food up to 10kgy.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement allegedly made by Ms Phillipa Smith of ACA, where Ms Smith is said to have called for a world-wide moratorium on food irradiation.

(3) Would the Minister confirm whether Ms Smith did make such a statement; and if so: (a) does it represent the official policy of ACA; and (b) was it made with the full knowledge and agreement of the scientists who prepared the ACA report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. There is no recommendation in the ACA Report that ``approval should be granted to irradiated food up to 10kgy''.
I am advised that the intent of the ACA's recommendations was that food irradiation may be permitted if, and only if, specified stringent conditions of safety could be met.

It was recommended (assuming that the other conditions could be met) that each item of food be approved and justified on an item by item basis prior to any irradiation. Within that context an upper limit of 10 kilograys was set.
(2) Yes.

(3) I am advised that the statement was made by Ms Smith. I am further advised that (a) The statement does represent the official policy of ACA, and (b) The panel of scientists in the ACA inquiry acted as an advisory committee to ACA for that project only. As such they read and agreed to the Report as printed. All press statements and subsequent policy statements are the responsibility of ACA.
